pageTitle: How to Use Bug Triage Board
content:
Where to Find It

go/aidtriage

How to Use It

AID-PI New Bugs and AID-BI New Bugs for seeing what's been recently submitted and not assigned to anyone. AID Bugs in Sprint and AID Backlog Bugs to get a sense of what bugs may be reviewed this sprint and what's been put on the backlog. AID (BI/PI) Enhancements for enhancements that haven't been assigned to a sprint. All BI Bugs and All PI Bugs for checking that there are no duplicates.

Filing Bugs and Triaging

Usually you'll just do components = "AID" and then either "Business Insights" and "Portfolio Insights". If a bug applies to both, append both as components. The bug should then show up on each board. At standup, one of the components should be removed, leading to the bug only showing up on 'AID-PI New Bugs' or 'AID-BI New Bugs'. MCI Template Bug / Enhancement Filing is a good resource as well for bug filing.

Filtering

AID-PI New Bugs

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status = Submitted AND assignee = Unassigned AND component = "Portfolio Insights" AND (sprint in openSprints() OR sprint is EMPTY) AND created >= -3d ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All submitted, unassigned bugs with "Portfolio Insights" components created within past 3 days.

AID-BI New Bugs

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status = Submitted AND assignee = Unassigned AND component = "Business Insights" AND (sprint in openSprints() OR sprint is EMPTY) AND created >= -3d ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All submitted, unassigned bugs with "Business Insights" components created within past 3 days.

AID Bugs in Sprint

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status != Closed AND (component = AID OR component = "Portfolio Insights" OR component = "Business Insights") AND Sprint in openSprints() ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All unclosed bugs belonging to AID, BI, or PI that are within the sprint.

AID Backlog Bugs

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status != Closed AND component in (AID, "Portfolio Insights", "Business Insights") AND Sprint is EMPTY ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All unclosed bugs belonging to AID, BI, or PI that do not have a sprint.

AID (BI/PI) Enhancements

component in ("Portfolio Insights", "Business Insights", AID) AND issuetype in ("Enhancement / Feedback") AND status in (Submitted) AND Sprint is EMPTY ORDER BY created DESC

 

All submitted enhancements belonging to AID, BI, or PI that do not have a sprint.

All PI Bugs

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status != Closed AND component != "Business Insights" AND component = "Portfolio Insights" ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All unclosed PI bugs. Used by QAs to ensure no duplicate bugs between PI and BI.

All BI Bugs

project = APT AND issuetype in (Bug, "Feature Bug") AND status != Closed AND component != "Portfolio Insights" AND component = "Business Insights" ORDER BY createdDate DESC

 

All unclosed BI bugs. Used by QAs to ensure no duplicate bugs between PI and BI.

Objective

The QA team is working towards a more defined QA allocation, however, currently it is inevitable that we function as a semi-QA pool across all MC Growth teams.

This page is to make sure: (updated bi-weekly.) 

  • we are not stretching our allocation across too many teams
  • QAs are communicating information that could affect other parts of MC Growth teams
  • decide who will be responsible for next AID-Release
  • we don't fall into the trap of focusing just on manual team testing

  • 2017-07-24: QA E Sprint
  • 2017-08-08: QA F Sprint

  • PAC Meetings
    • 2017-01-18 PAC Meeting
    • 2018-02-08 PAC Meeting

Attendees

  • Dave Kreps
  • Saptagiri Tangudu
  • Sean Feeney
  • Nick Shumeyko
  • Alex Franz
  • Nick Sidawy

Subject

This group met to discuss what server resources we have available to the AID project and how to best allocate those moving forward. We also discussed details of how outputs of data from MCDI should be transferred over to the AID instance.

Notes & Next Steps

The user "@"ed in the major task bullets is in charge of managing the process even if individual tasks within the workstream are carried out by other groups 

  • Move Marsh to Gouda Nick Sidawy11 Nov 2016
    • Run full backup of Marsh.TransactionAttributes to be used as seed data for Gouda Sean Feeney 07 Nov 2016
    • Coordinate w/ Ops on what MC_ETL_* databases will be needed on Gouda to support calculations Nick Sidawy08 Nov 2016
    • Physically move Gouda into the Kirk environment & provision it Sean Feeney 10 Nov 2016 
      • Move Gouda
      • Provision it
    • Add Gouda as a Subscribing server and set up all the necessary imports, views etc. to recieve data updates. date <TBD>. cc: Ji Dong, Apurva Rathi, Jaideep Sethi
  • Create fake transaction attribute data set on Titan to be used for performance data set Nick Sidawy10 Nov 2016
    • This data set should be completely compatible with the API that MCDI has provided the team
    • We should make sure to include fake versions of IsCiti, IsBarclays, etc along with other required columns
    • Ticket to create the database for this data
      • OPS-39421 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Fake data creation story
      • APT-103346 - Getting issue details... STATUS
  • Move front-end AID databases from Titan to Marsh Alex Franz11 Nov 2016
    • In order to reduce impact of upcoming performance testing by AID Calc on AID Web, we would like to physically separate their databases & workloads
    • The application code is already configured to enable running against separate data sources
    • Given the relatively lower processing needs of the AID Web application, moving them to Marsh should be more than sufficient
    • Alex Franz: Feel free to create checklist items for this work as you see fit
  • Set up the pipes to move final transaction attribute result set from Gouda to Titan Sean Feeney 10 Nov 2016 
    • Options:
      1. Use new Dell array technology to share an array between Gouda & Titan
        • Each server will have a set of dedicated local drives that they can utilize
          • This means that there should be no I/O contention between the two servers' workloads
        • There will be shared set of drives that both can reach into that will allow us to transfer the calculated data (either backups or copied MDF files) between the instances
        • This technology is new to APT. We have not used it before but it seems pretty appropriate for our needs
      2. Use the SAN
      3. Standard backup & restore operations to move the data
        • "This would be slow and not good" -Sean
      4. BCP raw data from one server to the other
        • Pro: This would allow us to move data as its calculated most easily
        • Con: It would require us to index and create statistics on the data once it reaches Titan
          • This could result in resource contention as AID does performance testing

pageTitle: How to Create a Testing Task
content:
Where to Start

  1. go/aidbi, go/aidpi
  2. Click 'Backlog'
  3. Click 'Create'

Fields

Project: APT (APT)

Issue Type: Test

Summary: (AID-X) Test 'Feature To Be Tested'

Components: 

  • If a BI feature: AID, Business Insights
  • If a PI feature: AID, Portfolio Insights

Description:

  • Links to
    • Requirements / Documentation
    • Engineering Tasks
  • Testing Task Template Questions: 
    • What is the toggle name? 
    • What branch is the code in?
    • Does it affect the other BI/PI team? 
    • Who is the Dev to reach out to bug, technical clairfications? 
    • Who is the PM to reach out for UX, enhancements, requirements questions?

Sprint: Relevant sprint

After Hitting Create

There's not a way to assign the epic while creating the task, so you'll have to:

  • Drag it from the 'Issues Without Epics' epic and move it to the relevant location. 
  • Hit 'Edit', and add the label 'testingtask'.
  • Assign it to the relevant QA.

pageTitle: 2016-09-19 Meeting notes - Transaction Attribute Calculation Engine
content:
Date

19 Sep 2016

Attendees

  • Nick Sidawy

  • Andrew Adamshick

  • Dustin Tiedemann
  • Pan Wang

  • Dave Kreps

Goals

  • Brainstorm transaction attribute calculation infrastructure
  • Determine what the main modules of the engine are and hopefully assign different engineers the task of thinking about them in more detail/come up with proposals.

Discussion Questions

  • How should we run these calculations?
    • Should we stick to SQL CLR and manage runs through Data Import?
    • Should we use a calc app and the Job Queue? 
      • Would this require a front end app?
  • Should the calculation handle everything on its own or should it use other calculated data sets as inputs?
    • For example, should the restaurant segment attribute be calculated on-the-fly or should the calculation use the replicated Customer Segments database as input
  • How do we manage & track calculations so, for example, each night, when it runs, the correct new data is calculated?
    • If a new attribute it added to our list, should our calculation handle calculating it for all of history?
    • If the last 3 months of data is restated, does this engine know that and kick off the correct set of calculations on its own?
    • What did we do poorly for site metrics that can be improved?
  • What do we consider a unit of calculation?
    • In site level metrics, the smallest "unit" would be a fiscal frequency for all split types assigned to a client.
    • Is a single frequency period & attribute the right unit? Will we want to be able to batch some calculations together?
      • For example, all the prior spend calculations can be done more efficiently in batch.
    • Should the engine be responsible for running everything? Should it farm out smaller calculations?
  • Where do the results of the calculation go when its finished?
    • Should they go directly into the finalized transaction attribute tables?
    • Should we store them in run tables and then materialize the transaction attribute tables as a separate step?
      • If so, when does this step run? After the calculations? Or should we just run this periodically? If periodically, then we may run the risk of some attributes have less dates calculated than others?
      • This might give us more flexibility into how attribute are grouped together after calculation.
  • Should the calculation always work on the entire TLog?
    • We know that only a subset of transactions is need to for AID; should we calculate attributes for only this subset? Do we want that flexibility at least?
  • How do we handle different entities?
  • What haven't we considered!?

Notes

  • What are the inputs to this calculation
    • Data provided by MasterCard
    • Our own derived data: Customer Segments, etc
  • How do we coordinate calculation of different attributes?
    • Calculation of each attribute should essentially happen independently
      • This will be the best way to be able to scale out the calculations
      • Calculating them all at once and in queue will be slow and very brittle
      • This means that different attributes will be available at different times
      • It may be worth batching SOME attributes:
        • For performance
        • Because some attributes might be expected to be available at the same time
          • It would be weird if prior spend for grocery was available for 90 days and 180 days at different times
  • What delineates an input to this engine vs something that is an output
    • We have talked about top of wallet as a trx attribute, but why isnt this an input like Customer Segments/Resi Zips?
    • We could start with a bottom up approach
  • All data sets that we calculate as inputs to this process should record what "version" was produced and when?
  • How do we distribute calculations?
    • Do we shard the TLOG?
  • Why would we persist a customer-date attribute?
    • If there is a consumer for it
    • For debugging reasons
    • To satisfy our coding souls
    • We don't have it if we are concerned about performance, space or time.
  • We would like to use the platform and take advantage of things like the exception framework, job queue, etc.
    • Do we have support for anonymous job queue?
    • We have anonymous exception handling
  • We should consider whether its worth having views of the TLog that limit the scope of transactions for performance reasons

 

Action items

  • We should go through the exercise of mapping out what and when things would be calculated starting from the "first of the month"
  • Create a flow for how a Prior Spend transaction attribute value gets created from the TLog
    • What API calls are made, what do they return, what data gets persisted at each step

What were the pain points?

  • Code was difficult to review
  • The other bar was a moving target for the kpi branch
  • The other bar was done in conjunction with the tree refactor
  • Massive refactors on a feature branch resulted in conflicts
    • Merge conflicts
    • Random breaking tests
    • The feature branch author didn't always have the context that the master commiter did to fix
  • Both refactors dragged on a held up other features
    • other → kpi
    • kpi → permissioning
  • Backend node process was tossed in also
  • The tasking at the start did not encompass all of the work done
  • front end unit testing / mocking is limited 
  • Testing

What can we do better ? 

  • Code review-ability
    • Breaking the refactor into small isolated units of work (such that random changes below - make code easier to review)
    • More granular pull requests (pull request by subtask)
    • Any random changes on feature branch that are not related to the refactor should be pushed on a separate branch and merged in to master rather than clubbed in with refactor. These changes added a lot of noise when reviewing code. Some examples from the refactor are
      • ALDP change (removing reference to the package in all apps)
      • Removing unused usings from files that are otherwise not being touched in the refactor
      • Refactoring components that are not related to functionality
        1. UserInfoTypeProvider
        2. ResxDictionaryProvider
        3. EnvironmentInfoProvider
        4. ClientInfoProvider
        5. SmallEntityCache - EntityModeCache
        6. Removing fractional cache from bunch of components
  • We can get these done faster
    • Allocate the entire team / majority of the team towards pushing the story over the line
  • Isolated units of work
  • Timing when we take these on
    • Pre-task the story and identify the appropriate work to occur prior and table other work until the refactor is done to ensure minimal disruption
  • Make sure everyone understands the impact and new design pattern
  • More unit testing
    • This feature branch was missing unit tests that covered major parts of its business logic. No toggle plus no unit test coverage is like the perfect storm.
  • Toggling the refactor
    • We should go for staged release
      • Stage -1 - Determine what parts of the old data model will be impacted and ensure any "version bits" are added to entities and the "old functionatity" has been changed to factor in those bits.
      • Stage 0 - only use old functionality
      • Stage 1 - "Saving" writes to old and new data model. When Toggle is off, we read from old data model, when toggle is on we read from new data model
      • Stage 2 - Toggle on, continue to write to old data model but everyone is transitioned to toggle on state
      • Stage 3 - Toggle deprecated and deleted and we clean up old data model

Lessons learned 

  • Major refactors should be provided more manpower to limit their disruptive duration
  • We need to do a better job to identify situations which will touch vast parts of the codebase
    • The traditional feature branch model may not work as smoothly for these stories
  • We don't need weekly deployments and should feel comfortable postponing them in the event of large refactors (or cut a branch for priority features that are happening in tandem)
  • We should go over how things work after the refactor is done with the whole team - so that everyone can resolve their own merge conflicts correctly and understand how the new paradigm works, etc.

Next time there is a situation like this we will...

Follow the steps outlined in https://confluence/display/AIDPAE/AID+Tasking+Don%27t+Forget+List

Actionable Next Steps

  • Jackson Hamburger fill in MCI Tasking Don't Forget List section

The Mastercard Growth Project Process page and folder is edit-restricted. This is because we'd like to maintain these pages as an accurate reflection of the current process, rather than a brainstorming space. Process brainstorming should happen here: Mastercard Growth Project Process Brainstorming

Reach out to Alex Franz if you have a reason to edit and I'll give you access.

Overview

The MC Growth team will begin trying a project-based approach to team organization.

This means:

  • Rather than thinking about the MC Growth product area as three teams, we are going to consider it a single unit.
  • SEs, QAs, and PMs will be staffed to projects, which will be relatively short, focused efforts (we think ~2-4 engineers for ~2-4 weeks will be typical)
    • SEs will be staffed to a single project.
    • QAs will be staffed 2-3 projects.  Projects can have more than one QA.
  • There will be an additional team working on small Quick Wins, Tech Debt tasks, and Support (QTS).  This will be a rotating group (think 2-3 weeks) of at least two SEs, and at least one QE.
    • This will also be the place we expect team members to flexibly role in-and-out of if there is time between a prior project completing and a new one starting.

We think there are several potential upsides to this approach:

  • It should greatly improve the opportunity for focused, efficient development with less distractions.
  • We think it will help get the right people onto projects based on interest and/or expertise.
  • We expect this approach to get projects "over-the-line" faster because it will be less tempting to "dilute" a team with yet another workflow.
  • This should facilitate cross-pollination of ideas and best practices since teammates will frequently change.  This could be especially helpful for New York since it's more difficult to do this organically.
  • The model maintains strong ownership of the end-user goals for each project by pulling together cross-functional teams.

What else should you keep in mind?

  • If you're on a project we want that to be your primary focus.  We also want it to be a team effort.  It's everybody's responsibility to complete the project.  (For example, SEs should help with testing if that is the last piece; or folks more familiar with back-end dev should chip in to get front-end task to complete)
  • We think app ownership is critical to scaling MC Growth in any model - including this one!  The plan is to actively pursue moving toward the app ownership plan discussed here: 2017-10-23 Defining app ownership.   Dustin Tiedemann will be sharing more next week.
  • This is a new concept for our Product Area - and we expect to be agile in developing the process.  There will be a retrospective toward the end of November, and we want everyone to be active in providing feedback!  The idea was to get to an MVP (Minimum Viable Process) to avoid over-planning.  There is no doubt we will need to figure things out as we go and refine.

Quick links

  • Project management:go/mcgprojects
  • JIRA: go/mcgprojectboard
  • Process documentation (this page): go/mcgprocess
  • Continuous feedback:  go/mcgfeedback

Slack channels:

  • #mastercardgrowth: General discussion for the entire Product Area
  • #mcg-process: Discussion / questions about process for the entire Product Area

Project lifecycle

Projects progress through several stages.  The following table outlines the typical project lifecycle and involved team members.  For each stage, view the linked page for the process and best practices around each stage:

StageDescriptionInvolved team members
1. Requirement collectionProject is conceived and requirements created based on business needs, technical debt, etc.PM lead/UX team. App owner(s)
2. Planning, tasking, and estimationProject is planned and tasked. Engineering and QA estimates are provided.Tasking engineer(s) and QA(s). PM lead/UX. Relevant app owner(s).
3. Backlog review and prioritizationProject is prioritized and scheduled based on business needs and staffing.MC Growth leaders (to be refined); Dave
4. Project initializationProject team is organized.Project lead and team members
5. Project executionProject goes through development, testing, and release iteration until complete.All team members. Relevant app owner(s) (to review)
6. Ongoing supportRemaining deployment and rollout steps. Ongoing support.QTS team

QTS process

The "Quick Wins, Technical Debt, and Support" team (QTS; Dave Pacifico is in charge of giving this a new name) will be continually staffed with 2+ engineers and 1+ QA.  This squad is responsible for tackling smaller, high-priority issues and backlog items.  Team members will rotate through this role, and other team members who finish a project early or have some downtime waiting on a dependency can also take advantage of the QTS backlog.

Details on this squad's process can be found here: SWaT Process

App ownership process

App ownership is a critical aspect of the project-based process. 

App owners play three pivitol roles in this process:

  1. Helping project teams plan changes in each app or code area.
  2. Reviewing PRs by individual project teams into that App, ensuring that changes are consistent with the broader vision for the app.
  3. Curating technical debt, and proposing technical projects outside of the regular "business feature" pipeline pertaining to the app.

Feedback and process evolution

As a new process, an important part of making the Project based team process a success will be rapid iteration and refinement.  We are going to try having three avenues for process documentation and feedback:

AvenuePurpose / details
This Confluence documentation
  • The Mastercard Growth Project Process section on confluence outlines our current process. It is used to codify what we see as "best practices" at the moment, and we'll strive to keep it up-to-date as we make adjustments.
  • This isn't a brainstorming area – please do that here: Mastercard Growth Project Process Brainstorming
#mcg-process
  • For quick discussions and questions, use the #mcg-process channel. This is a good place to poll for opinions (/), or raise a point of inquiry
Continuous feedback (go/mcgfeedback) / Retrospectives
  • Use this area for "bigger" feedback, topics of discussion, questions, etc. This page can be used to start longer discussions via Confluence (feel free to make sub-pages!), and we'll review for discussion topics in product area retrospectives. (TBD exactly how these work, but we'll definltely be using retrospectives as a tool to refine the overall process here).

Getting started

Starting 11/6 we're ready to try this out!  We've taken current workstreams and organized into ad-hoc work that needs to be wrapped up, and current, ongoing projects.

Our historic "week1" documentation is here: Getting started

Problem

Many teams at APT have already tried out the concept of a rotating support engineer/on-call engineer who is in-charge of taking up any new external requests/communications for the team, triage new bugs and be point person for deployments. As Mastercard Growth product area tries out the new project-based team organization, we need to come up with an alternate approach to the support role; one where we will still have a subset of engineers across the product area working in the support capacity, thus allowing other project teams to have undivided attention from all engineers. 

Technical debt that is generated during the day-to-day development needs to be owned by the entire product area. In a project based team organization, it will be unlikely for small to medium technical debt issues to get prioritized over feature development. Also, given that a large number of technical debt tasks will require a single engineer, spinning up a new project team for those might also be an overhead. We need a way for the members of the product area to keep working through technical debt without distracting them from the active project development.

Team Roles

The SWaT Team is designed to play following roles:

  1. Own the technical debt for the product area and work on projects that help improve the code and/or improve productivity of the product area
  2. Push on slow-burn projects where having a dedicated project team is not viable (e.g. Monitoring TA calc run for a new client etc)
  3. Be the first point of contact for any support request/deployment issues/high priority bugs etc. such that engineers outside of the support engineer squad should be able to shut down outlook and slack and focus on their project for most of the day

Team Composition

Ideally, the support engineer squad will consist of a 2-3 SEs and 1-2 QAs.  We will rotate the engineers assigned to this role every two weeks. Having a mix of engineers from different teams (BI/PI/MCDI) will allow us to have a good distribution of knowledge about different parts of the product area.

Responsibilities

  1. Technical debt
  2. Pick up small/slow burn projects/"async-await" projects
    1. This will include looking into requests from partner teams (OPS/DEVOPS/DATA team etc)
    2. Work with OPS to create new databases/instances etc
  3. Support
    1. Handle ad-hoc questions/querries about the platform functionality/data
    2. Support sales demo efforts/demos
    3. Monitor error emails for ALL MCG products in all data centers/Monitor prod issues/bugs -  Only support developers will be monitoring the error emails and triage board. If we see a new error/bug or a surge in a particular error, they will work with QA team and app owners to move the issue into one of the following states
      1. This belongs to an active project so it goes on their sprint board
      2. This is a bug that needs to be resolved and we proiritize it on the support team's sprint board
      3. This is a known issue and we are adding an exceptions tag for the error/comment and close-wont-fix the issue
  4. Deployments
    1. Once every two weeks cadence - by end of every support team cycle there should have been at least one deployments to production
  5. Handle post-release tasks 
    1. Deprecating/Deleting toggles
    2. Handle any support questions for the features to the documentation page 
    3. Selenium Tasks

Process

Sprint planning

Since the support engineer squad will follows a 2 week rotation, it makes sense to have a 2 week sprint where the squad that is about to enter the role is able to align on the exact goals they are trying to achieve in the next 2 weeks.

Attendees

  • Current squad
  • Next squad
  • Product area leaders

Agenda

  • Current squad will give a quick update on all the work streams that they have been working on. Anything that is in the current sprint that is not done can be moved to 4 states
    1. It is almost done and the person working on the task will wrap it up as they transition to next project
    2. It is high priority so the new squad needs to include it in their sprint
    3. It is not high priority and we should evaluate it along with other tasks on the backlog
    4. Particular member of the squad was passionate about working on the project so we pulled that into our current sprint. We should park the issue until that member is in the support role again.
  • Current squad/new squad and product area leaders look at the tech debt backlog and decide on a subset of tasks that are high priority/high value or projects that members of the squad are passionate about. 
  • Prior support QA reviews what selenium coverage has been implemented and what should be prioritized for the current sprint.
  • Everyone evaluates the bugs from the backlog that were added in the last sprint to check if any of them need to be addressed in the current sprint.
  • We talk about expected sales support or new instance setup.

Filling an Issue & Triage

Filling an Issue

Best practices fro filling issues are outlined in MCG-Support Process. This included basic questions like "What component should I use to file an MCG issue?" as well as "What should I do if I notice a high-priority issue?". Also has more broken down explanation of how the issues will be triaged. 

Issue Triage

Filed issues will be collected in the triage board (http://jira/secure/Dashboard.jspa?selectPageId=22673). One of the team members should be on point for monitoring this and posting the issue to the slack #mcg-triage board for discussion around priority. This should be done at minimum once daily and ideally throughout the day.

General Triage

Support engineers should monitor error emails, full build results, and deployments. Any bugs found should be converted into a JIRA task and pasted into Slack for discussion. This is helpful even for minor issues as it makes it clear who is on point for the fix.

Stand up

Just like any other "project team", the squad will have pre-determined goals so it will be helpful to have the team meet up every day for stand up to review their sprint board. This will also help the squad feel like a team rather than individual engineers working on disconnected work streams.

Attendees

  • Current Squad

Agenda

  • Review progress on existing tasks
  • Assign any high priority tasks added to the sprint board since last meeting
  • Discuss any issues on the triage board if outcome of slack discussion is not clear

Retrospective

We are trying out a new concept and it is important for us to strive to continously improve the process. After each squad rotation, we should retrospect on how the experience was for the members. We should also make adjustments to the process based on that feedback.

Attendees 

  • Current Squad
  • Pushkar Rege

Agenda

  • What tasks were we able to accomplish?
  • What was the general theme for support issues that came up?
  • What resources, if avaialble, would have helped you in this roles? (e.g. Better documentation on X or Access to Y)
  • What worked well and what could have gone better
  • Was two weeks an adequate amount of time?
  • Did deployments occur as expected?

 

Note: For the first few iteration, we should publish the results of this retrospective so that we can share our experience/learning with the rest of the product area

Support team can be thought of as the first line of defense that is going to shield the rest of the team from any distractions that will take away from developing on the target feature. To exactly identify what falls under the purview of this role, we should work on identifying common distractions for developers that take away from active development of a feature. 

Common distractions

  • I got a request for small project for the product area (e.g. Help QA team with internationalization/ help Firm productivity team by commiting some file in code for their POC etc)
  • We are seeing a sudden surge in error emails for a particular exceptions and we need to investigate the issue
  • Mastercard Partner X/User X is seeing unexpected behavior (w.r.t results) on the front end and we need to investigate on the data side 
  • We just for a request to set up a new client instance and we need to set that up in next few days (assuming the data set is already available in QWEST)
  • PM team/QA team reported a bug that belongs to a project that has been released and we need to triage it/fix it
  • Development work on a feature is complete. The next steps involve coordination with external teams/waiting for some long running operation to complete (e.g. historical data re-roll)
  • There is a demo happening in QWEST and we want to monitor it closely (there is little work here but it will be good to have support team be on-call if we need to help with setup or unblock something during the demo)
  • Monitor our build and deploy jobs on BAMBOO and JENKINS for failures

    (Other developers should add to this list based on their experience)

Responsibilities of support team

  1. Monitor error emails for ALL MCG products in all data centers/Monitor prod issues/bugs -  Only support developers will be monitoring the error emails and triage board. If we see a new error/bug or a surge in a particular error, they will work with QA team and app owners to move the issue into one of the following states
    1. This belongs to an active project so it goes on their sprint board
    2. This is a bug that needs to be resolved and we proiritize it on the support team's sprint board
    3. This is a known issue and we are adding an exceptions tag for the error/comment and close-wont-fix the issue
  2. Pick up small/slow burn projects/"async-await" projects
    1. This will include looking into requests from partner teams (OPS/DEVOPS/DATA team etc)
    2. Work with OPS to create new databases/instances etc
  3. Handle post-release tasks 
    1. Deprecating/Deleting toggles
    2. Handle any support questions for the features to the documentation page 
  4. Support sales demo efforts/demos
  5. Handle ad-hoc questions/querries about the platform functionality/data
  6. Selenium Tasks
  7. Deployments: Staging→ Production (Once every two weeks cadence - by end of every support team cycle there should have been at least one deployments to production) 
    1. Aggregate completed projects in staging (release notes, Toggles etc.)
    2. Follow setup/howTo documentation as necessary when projects are in Production (Follow release plan provided by projects)

 

While the list of responsibilities is pretty long, most of these tasks will not take up a lot of developer time. When support engineers are not working on these, they can pick up issues from the top of a prioritized list of backlog/tech debt items for a given app they are interested in and work on those.

How to File a Support Bug (go/mcgtriage)

Most of the content on: MCI Template Bug / Enhancement Filing should not have changed. However, here are some necessary changes to adapt w/ the project-based model. 

  1. Determine Bug does not belong to a current project. (if you find a bug that is relevant to an active project please feel free to file it under the project on the active sprint)
  2. When Creating a Support bug, use the JIRA component 'MCG'. (Do not put it on the active sprint)

  3. Reporter, Should proactively decide Priorities in the following three buckets

    PriorityBehaviorOutcome
    HighBlocking, Production bug
    • Alert issue on the #mcg-support slack channel
    • JIRA subscription email also gets sent out to alert the support team (Support QA receives through mcg-qa Outlook group)
    NormalBugs found that do not belong to a current project that should be fixed
    • Every morning, Support QA starts a Slack thread (on the #mcg-triage channel) w/ issues filed from the previous day.
    • The Support Team help triage on whether the bug should be pulled in to the active sprint
    MinorMinor bugs 
    • Every morning, Support QA starts a Slack thread (on the #mcg-triage channel) w/ issues filed from the previous day.
    • The Support Team help triage on whether the bug should be pulled in to the active sprint
  4. Bug should show up on go/mcgtriage board.

 

Here are the deciding factors of triageing normal/minor JIRA issues:

State of IssueDescriptionAction
  • Accept
  • Move to Current Sprint
  • Add to Active Support Project Epic
  • Should be fixed by Support Team before next Production deployment.
  • A 15 min fix that could be easily tackled
Will be fixed
  • Accept
  • Move to Backlog
  • Add to Active Support epic
  • Should be fixed but does not need immediate attention and can be reevaluated later
Will be re-prioritized w/ next Support team rotation
Not accepted and left on go/mcgtriage board
  • Still needs more iteration from PM/UX on exact behaviors
Support QA will mention the relevant team member for input. Support QA will be watching the issue to decide when the issue to ready to be reevaluated to any of the state mentioned above.

Details

Execution

The majority of the Project Execution phase will be the usual development process:

  1. Design:  While tasking was done previously, the team should iterate on design decisions and implementation details
  2. Develop:  The regular development process and creation of PRs.
  3. Review:  Code review.  Remember to include app owners on each relevant PR!
  4. Test:  The team's QA will organize the test plan and process for the project.
  5. Iterate:  Fix bugs and other code iterations

This should be a team effort! Please expect to chip in wherever you can to get a project to "complete". This should include working with less familiar code or SE's chipping in to get through testing efforts. Additionally, for features impacting the front-end and adding new interactable elements, the SE should add and record data-e2e tags. The QA should check that the tagged elements can be accessed through a selenium test, and write down any other selenium testing necessary for the new feature to be implemented by the QA on mcg-support.

 

Remember:  Project Execution is more that just writing code.  Other aspects of a complete project include:

  • Thinking through and creating event logging and Splunk dashboards.
  • Adding both internal and external documentation, such as client setup and next steps
  • Adding new entries to go/aidhowto

Wrapup

The goal of most projects is to release a feature to Staging.  When the project reaches this step it's time to wrap up:

  • Review:
    • Look through the "What does it mean to be done" section on the Project Page and confirm that nothing has fallen through the cracks.
  • Release Plan:  
    • Create a production release plan, and make sure this is on the SWaT roadmap.  (SWaT will help get the feature released to production).
    • Ensure that the feature is available on all relevant DBs/demos; update scripts are running successfully, etc. (Sanity check)
    • Link to the Release Plan from the Project Page
  • Toggle Management:
    • Ensure that the team has completed both OFF and ON toggle testing.
    • Create a backlog task for SWaT to deprecate and delete the toggle.
  • Organization:
    • Move all tasks and stories to "complete".
    • Remove the "active" label from the project page.
    • Add the "complete" label to the project page.
  • Feedback:
    • Consider a retrospective / wrapup meeting.
    • Write up any feedback for your teammates and send timely feedback to their advisor or save notes for the next review cycle

What is Power BI?

Power BI is a suite of business analytics tools to analyze data and share insights. It answers the business needs for companies that have a lot of data available through some datasource and need a layer on top of that data to visualize it and generate insights.

History of Power BI

Microsoft has invested in taking a bunch of functionality that is provided via SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS) and combined that with functionality available via Excel plugins like Power Query and Power Pivot/Power view to create the initial version of Power BI that was released in July 2015. 

In its initial form, Power BI was delivered as an online service (Power BI for Offfice 265) which has now become powerbi.com. This primarily targets any businesses that already have their data in Azire and allows them to create a view variety of visualizations based on that data. Around July 2016, they added Power BI Gateway  as an adapter to allow leverage on-premise sources to power the dashboards and reports generated using the Power BI service. This allowed companies that did not currently host data in Azure to allow start levering the platform.

Earlier this year, Microsoft released Power BI Report server which allowed businesses to not only host their data on-premise but also host the Power BI service that houses all the dashboards and reports within their network. This basically meant that anyone using this feature could now get full benefit of Power BI without connecting to the powerbi.com service or the Azure resources. Over the last few months, Microsoft has invested in scaling up the functionality available via Power BI Report server to match that available on the cloud version. E.g. Initial release of Power BI Report server only allowed live connections to SSAS tabular model but as of the October release, they now support a wide variety of data sources with live connections.

Scope of this exploration

Power BI exploration is part of a wider MIC 2.0 project where we are exploring different visualization and BI tools that are available in the market to understand their suite of functionality. Apart from Power BI, we are also exploring Tableau and WebFocus. The objective here is to figure out the strengths and limitations of each of platforms.

During the last few weeks, I have mostly worked on trying out the functioanlity available via the Power BI report server (since that is a subset of the functionality that powerbi.com supports) followed up with a little bit of exploration of the cloud based service.

Strengths

Self service platform

Power BI and other similar product provide really good self-service platform. Through user managemen, admins can permission users to certain data sources (or certain subsets of the data set) and then allow them to create a variety of  cards/reports based on them.

E.g. I was able to plug Demo database to  my power bi instance to recreate one of the dashboards in the platform

 

Once you attach a datasource to Power BI instance, the following operations become extremely easy

  1. Creating computed columns 
    I created a computed bool column/attribute  for "Target Month" so I wouldn't have to enter time period over and over again and that was a simple 2 step process 
  2. Creating new KPIS/metrics (called Measure in Power BI terminology)
  3. Creating a new Chart

    1. Select a visualization
    2. Add any axis (breakout attributes), filters and values (KPIs) 
    3. Adding formatting on the chart
  4. Creating hierarchies  for Drilldowns
    This is a cool functionality where one can create a hierarchy of columns e.g. Country => State => Country =>Zip and then on any chart, drill down/up through the hierarchy
  5. Creating attribute code groups
    This is basically the bucketed coded attribute functionality where I can combine Monday - Friday as "Weekday" group and "Saturday-Sunday" as weekend group on a chart.
  6. Explore data used for a particular card (see data as a table as well as export to csv)

Visualizations

Power BI supports a wide variety of visualizations by default and also has functionality to add custom visuals (cue metric tree )

Default visualizations include

  1. Bar and columns charts
  2. Cards (single and multi row)
  3. Combo charts
  4. Donut charts
  5. Line charts/Trend charts
  6. Basic maps
  7. Matrix (table output)
  8. Tree maps
  9. Waterfall charts

Multiple data sources

Given that Power BI was designed to intergrate with a variety of data sources hosted on Azure platform, it has adapters for large number of data sources used commonly in the industry. It supports live querying and caching on top of some of those datasources (like SQL server and SSAS etc)

Relevant among those are

  1. SQL Server Database
  2. SQL Server Analysis Services
  3. Azure SQL Database
  4. Azure SQL Data Warehouse
  5. IBM DB2 Database
  6. IBM Netezza (Beta)

Integration into other technologies

Given that the tool is designed for addressing a wide variety use-cases, we get default intergration into different technologies like

  1. Ability to access R 
  2. Integration into sharepoint
  3. Ability to integrate into active directory

Also, large part of the platform is designed to be mobile device friendly and there 

Client/Region specific customizations

This tool allows us to  customize the following

  1. Setting locale/language
  2. Adding branding for a client (text/logos)
  3. Setting up date masks, currency masks etc 

Limitations

Platform is under development

While having the platform be under active development could usually one of the strengths, I had to put that under limitations here because the platform is currently in a state where a large fraction of its functionality is not yet fully released. A significant number of data sources are currently supported in Beta mode and core functionality like the ability to use REST APIs as a datasource are not completely ironed out. 

This will mean that if we decide to integrate this tool into out platform, we might run into stability issues as new releases come up and we may not be able to deliver on all the expected functionality if the tool has it in Beta mode or does not support it completely.

Limit customizations on default visualizations

While Power BI does allow basic level of branding and allows us to set date masks etc and create new visuals, there is limited functionality around editing the default visuals. 

Ability to use REST API as a live connection

While in theory Power BI does allow using REST API as a datasource, most of the work seems to be related to importing the data via REST API at the beginning and then use it for in-memory calculation. There seems to be limited explorations of using REST API as a live connections which is what we might want if we want to plug a tool like this into our microservice architecture so that we can retrieve data via REST calls to another microservice.

Next steps

  • Explore performance
  • Explore permissioning model 
    • Role based permissions (restrict functionality  a user can access)
    • Row based permissions (restrict data a user can access)
  • Explore REST API integration
  • Explore custom authencation modules (e.g. using SSO etc)

Bar and donut chart specifics:

  • The first set of columns should be a column for each split applied to the chart where the column name is the attribute name.
  • Once AID Support Time Frequency as a Split feature is implemented, if Time is a selected split, "Start Date" and "End Date" should be first two columns followed by remaining splits
  • The next set of columns should be a column for the AAdvantage portfolio metric value and a column for the Benchmark group benchmark value, with details on the metric name and metric settings / format embedded in the column name (using the same naming logic we use on the top of the drilldown when summarizing the metric information)
6  Numbers match those displayed on cardsTime splits not yet implemented

Trend chart specifics:

  • First two columns show Start Date, End Date for each data point
  • Next set of columns should be a column for each split applied to the chart where the column name is the attribute name
  • The next set of columns should be a column for the AAdvantage portfolio metric value and a column for the Benchmark group benchmark value, with details on the metric name and metric settings / format embedded in the column name (using the same naming logic we use on the top of the drilldown when summarizing the metric information)
  • Hidden partial points still persist data
7  Numbers match those displayed on cards 

Metric tree specifics:

  • No splits supported for metric tree
  • First column lists each KPI in the tree, with details on the metric name and metric settings / format embedded in the column name (using same naming logic we use on the top of drilldown when summarizing the metric information
  • Benchmark data not available for actual values
8  Numbers match those displayed on cards 

Map specifics:

  • Only State split currently supported by Map
  • First column lists States, alphabetically
  • The next set of columns should be a column for the AAdvantage portfolio metric value and a column for the Benchmark group benchmark value, with details on the metric name and metric settings / format embedded in the column name (using the same naming logic we use on the top of the drilldown when summarizing the metric information)
9  Numbers match those displayed on cards

Summary

 Description
Goal
  • Create stories and tasks
  • Determine an accurate estimate of engineering weeks (devs x weeks)
  • Determine an accurate estimate of test weeks
Team members involvedTasking engineer(s) and QA(s). PM lead/UX. Relevant app owner(s).
Tracking
  • Stories and tasks
  • Updated estimates on the Project Page.

 

Details

A SE and QA will be asked to help plan, task, and estimate the project.

The primary goal of this effort is an accurate estimation of effort.  Depending project scope and ambiguity this exercise could vary from a quick estimate (for simple / clear projects) to a deep dive into implementation decisions (for large or complex projects).  In some cases we may assign one or more individuals to spend several days diving in to plan, coordinating with other teams, app owners, etc.  In other cases, we may ask an app owner to make an much quicker estimate based on their experience.

  1. Assign: One or more engineers and QAs will be assigned to plan, task, and estimate.
  2. Learn:
    1. Carefully read requirements for the project.
    2. Review the Project Page.
  3. Plan: The assigned individuals should understand the project and plan:
    1. Come up with the set of stories that will need to be completed
    2. Understand approaches that could be taken
    3. Review plan with all owners of relevant apps, the project's PM, etc.
  4. Task:  For more complex stories, make sure that the desired approach is sufficiently laid out with stories or tasks in Confluence or JIRA.
  5. Estimate:  The assigned individuals should work with relevant app owners to make a reasonable estimate in terms of engineering weeks / QA weeks, and update the Project Page accordingly.
  6. Check:  Take a final pass through requirements and the Project Page's "What does it mean to be done?" section to make sure all aspects of the project were incorporated.

Details 

There are two primary avenues for conceiving and creating projects:

  • Projects created to progress on development based on business goals
    • This path would typically fall under the purview of the PM team
  • Projects created to improve technical aspects of the Mastercard Growth platform / apps
    • These projects will generally originate based on App owner discussions

 

  1. Create requirements:  Create a new requirements page in the space/way you usually do today (e.g. for Business Insights, it's here: Business Insights Product Requirements)
    1. Note that over time we may want to move all of this over, but for now given the ease of linking pages, we'll just leave it as is.
  2. Collect requirements: Collect requirements as usual
  3. Create projects:
    1. Work with Alex Franz to create 1+ projects based on the Project Template and slot into the prioritized "Planning" project list
    2. Create epics associated with each project on go/mcgProjectBoard 
    3. Create placeholder stories associated with each epic and slot them into either "PI Project Backlog" or "MI Project Backlog" as appropriate
    4. For each project we will estimate app distribution (to help identify app owners who should be involved in planning).

2017-12-27: Test Provisioning Users to Specific Portfolios

Project Team Members

John Reagan, Jason Kim, Adam Gallagher, Nicholas Morrow

Start Date

13 Dec 2017 

End Date

02 Feb 2018 

Priority1001
Release Plan 

What does it mean to be done?

We discussed this would involve the following:

  • Supporting a class of attributes that only apply to the client portfolio but you can still filter on when viewing the benchmark
  • Ensuring that a user is unable to request data that is not permissioned to them or part of their benchmark.(related to the above)
  • Special handling for the selection and summary of "permissionable" attributes
    • E.g. potentially summarizing them differently on the top of the output (text instead of pillboxes) or preventing the user from removing the last one
  • This new concept of breaking out the filter tab into multiple sections (e.g. transaction attributes, customer attributes, portfolio attributes, etc.)
    • The thought is that this would be configurable by client 
  • Representing the relationship of codes across attributes and filter specific codes based on selected codes of other attributes (e.g. filtering product lines based on what portfolios are selected). 

It would be nice if we could test this on a realistic example. We may want to separate story for this, but it would be nice if we could create country, card type, and fake portfolio and product line attributes to demonstrate this interaction. Since we need data from the client to create the portfolio and product line attributes, maybe we fake them using "MC child ICA" and "BIN 6" respectively given we can actually compute those from the MC data. 

Who is involved outside of the project team?

This is an estimation for remaining work as of 1/5/17 outside of attribute tabs and attribute code relationships. All this information is now reflected in JIRA, but here is a consolidated view. 

Total time estimate: 10-16 days

# Multiple benchmark integration (3-4 days)

## Handling request (1-2 days)
* If a benchmark has a specific attribute compat type, follow that
* If there are multiple benchmarks and one has a specific compat type
* only situation should be attribute is compatible and some benchmark(s) is client request only, else throw
* Remove attribute filter from whole, add to client portion and any fully compatible benchmarks in benchmark breakout
* example, country filter with country and region benchmarks
* Leverage client benchmark type instead of indexing when finding it in SettingsProvider
* add new js tests

## Disabling attributes (1 day)
* if multiple benchmarks are on and have specific compats, use most restrictive
* add logic to BenchmarkHelpers.js to check specific benchmarks, right now only uses presence (ie do i have a benchmark)


# Pillboxes (4-7 days)

## Create selectors for regular and granularly permissioned attributes (0.5 days)
* consider making new file DrilldownFilterSelectors.js, to do this, and pull other stuff in

## Create new component for Granularly permissioned attribute pillbox (1-2 days)

* isStandalone - used to determine image capture, there's a selector already

* Instead of number consolidation, list all codes as individual elements, like current pillbox
* Probably just use that component, make it show the X's don't show up

## Pull current pillbox into component (0.5 days)

## Extend FilterSummaryPanel for this use case (0.5 days)
* One for granularly permissioned, one for regular, wrapped by a parent
* these are the 2 lines in the mockup
* Filter filters passed to each by permissioning type
* clearAll should be configured to be off

## Make action creator for edit filter functionality (1-3 days)

## Make minor CSS changes

# Splunk logging (2-3 days)
* Log when user clicks edit on new pillbox

# Granular filter validation (1-2 day)

APT-135798 - Getting issue details... STATUS

Development Estimate1 wk
Testing Estimate 
Project Team Members

Allie Ivener

Adam Gallagher

Yufei Qu

Start Date

29 Nov 2017 

End Date

08 Dec 2017 

Priority999999
Release Plan 

 

What does it mean to be done?

We can calculate any precalculated attribute (prior spend, resi zip, point of interest, top of wallet) for any issuer country.

Specifically, each precalculated attribute needs to be linked to a specific run or client or geography so that future runs can reuse the correct existing attribute data and know when to recalculate new data.

Who is involved outside of the project team?

Who that is not on the project team needs to be involved and what is their level of involvement? e.g. app owners, Ops, Data Usage

Details

useAttributeFiltersForPrecalculationAttributes and persistPrecalculationAttributeFilterId and accountOpenDateInternationalization branches exist!

 

Allie Ivener started this work but stopped since it wasn't an analytic bug for the AA/USA datasets. See 2017-11-20: Precalculated Filter Design. Existing branches on git are precalculatedAttributeFilterDataModel (off of master) and processAttributeFilters (off of that). The first branch is basically done (just has sql scripts), and the second branch is in progress of using the new Attribute Filters for precalculated attributes (testing with ToW first).

Also note that ResiZip has hardcoded 'USA'.

Proposed Behavior

The overall proposed behavior across attributes is to calculate a single attribute value for each account, and partition the calculation by issuing country of the account. We should always look at both domestic and international transactions when calculating these attribute values (i.e. do not filter to merchants within a specific country). The consumer would leverage these attributes as follows:

  • For Portfolio Intellgence, we'd pull attribute data for all accounts issued in the countries of relevance (i.e. where the issuers operate). If we do not have attributes calculated for a certain country where the client issues cards, we should of course calculate them.
  • For merchant based use cases (MI, CI), we'd pull attribute attribute data for all accounts issued in countries for which we've already calculated attributes. If we do not have attributes calculated for accounts issued in the country in which the merchant operates, we should obviously calculate them. We should also probably calculate them for neighboring countries as well. Note this means that transactions at the merchant or competitive set from accounts issued in countries for which we have not already computed attribute data will have an "unknown" value for the attribute (e.g. cardholders issued in Germany will have "Unknown" Prior Spend attribute values for Via Varejo). 

The one exception to the above is residential zip code. The proposal is to calculate this attribute by the country of the merchant locations, filtering down to only merchant locations for the country interest. This means a cardholder can have a residential zip value for multiple countries. This allows us to still calculate the account's "real" residential zip code (i.e. the one tied to the country the card was issued), but also allows us to meet more sophisticated use cases like "tell me the zip code international travelers mostly come from when they vacation in the US". The consumer would then leverage this attribute as follows:

  • For Portfolio Intelligence use cases, we'd pull attribute data for accounts issued in the countries of relevance, and for each account assign the attribute value based on transactions at merchant locations in the same country in which the card was issued (e.g. pull the resi-zip calculated based off US merchants for US-issued cards). 
  • For merchant based use cases (MI,CI), we'd pull attribute data for all transactions in countries in for which the client operates (e.g. pull the resi-zips calculated based off Brazil merchants for a Brazil client). For accounts issued outside the merchant's country, we can optionally decide to replace the attribute value with something like "International Traveler" or even something as specific as the issuing country of that card, so we don't mislead the user by tieing a residential zip code to someone who's vacationing in that country. 

 Current behavior (for reference)
AttributeCurrent Calculation
Top of Wallet
  • We look at all transactions (both domestic and international) for a specific issuing country
Residential Zip Code
  • For AA, we filter to US issued cards and also add a manual filter to only transactions at US merchants. Overall, I think this is fine.
  • For other use cases such as CL & WS, we calculate two attributes:
    • "Residential Country": an account's likely country of residence
    • "Residential Zip", which is computed by filtering to transactions at merchants for a specific country and calculating the residential zip. We calculate one of these for each country.
Other customer geographic based attributes (e.g. DMA)
  • We look at all transactions (both domestic and international) for a specific issuing country
Prior Spend Attributes (e.g. Total Prior Card Spend)
  • We look at all transactions (both domestic and international) for a specific issuing country

 

Notes from Meeting with Allie, Nick, Adam on 11/27/2017

  • For AA, we calculate attributes by filtering down to US-issued cards, which is good
  • The problem is that we're using (or want to use) the AA calculated attributes for other use cases, but currently we have no representation on what filters were applied when calculating them (i.e. the fact we filtered to just US-issued cards)
  • The work for this project is to figure out what exactly we want to store on the database
  • Depending on the implementation we choose, we may want to recalculate attributes just to make sure everything is consistent, but we're not changing the methodology so we don't expect attribute values to change

APT-139168 - Getting issue details... STATUS

Staging

n/a

Toggle
  • AidCheckAttributeCodePermissions
  • AidAttributeTabs

Organized by project requirements.

Requirement 1

Supporting a class of attributes that only apply to the client portfolio but you can still filter on when viewing the benchmark.

We need to be able to allow filtering by client only attributes while still requesting the benchmark. Currently we disable this entirely. The only case where we allow this is the filter breakout, where one entry has isClient, and the other isBenchmark. We could expand on this by adding multiple filters on the client side and leaving benchmark alone. To accomplish this, we should rethink how we are handling client vs benchmark in the FE since there is a lot of manually adding and removing filters. Ideally, that filter breakout could be constructed on request, and would intelligently categorize filters based on "isClient". 

Requirement 2

Ensuring that a user is unable to request data that is not permissioned to them or part of their benchmark.

Currently, Rishab added a the idea of a granularly permissioned filter. When a granularly permissioned filter exists, it must always be part of the data request. This is important for security, since if I'm permissioned to portfolio A, I should not be able to request all data, which includes portfolio B. In WebSettingsValidator, this check is made. We will need to add another well tested case for benchmark, since a request for benchmark would not include some of these these granularities on the whole request, but just the client side. So when doing a filter breakout request, we need to check that each piece, along with overall, either includes these attributes or has the benchmark. 

Requirement 3

Special handling for the selection and summary of "permissionable" attributes. E.g. potentially summarizing them differently on the top of the output (text instead of pillboxes) or preventing the user from removing the last one.

This should be pretty straightforward, and can be determined during construction. 

Requirement 4

This new concept of breaking out the filter tab into multiple sections (e.g. transaction attributes, customer attributes, portfolio attributes, etc.) The thought is that this would be configurable by client

APT-136356 - Getting issue details... STATUS

Assumptions

  • "Product Line" and "Portfolio" attributes are client only, and should not apply to benchmark data
    • They can still be used with benchmark but the benchmark will not be filtered in this way
    • This contrasts to other client only attributes, like IMM, which cannot be used at all with benchmark (will be disabled when benchmark is on)
  • "Country" and "Card Type" do apply to benchmark values
    • When using Country or Region benchmark, these two filters essentially define the benchmark group
    • The current implementation of "Peer" benchmark also respects these filters
  • Filters for Country, Card Type, Portfolio, and Product Line must always be present on Client data
  • Filters for Country and Card Type must always be present on Benchmark data
    • This is not in the requirements, but assuming that benchmark respects these filters, it follows that benchmark must always use them

New proposal for data request

This proposal has these filters living in redux state with all our other filters.

We have 3 distinct cases for interaction between benchmarks and attributes. 

  1. Peer benchmark - use applied country and region filters
  2. Region benchmark - use applied region filter, do not use country filter
  3. Country benchmark - use applied country filter, do not use region filter (this actually doesn't matter since country is subset, but probably ignore to be consistent with region.)

Given this disparity between when attributes do or do not apply to benchmark, and the fact that we could not programmically derive which attributes should be included or not based on a benchmark definition as outlined in multiple benchmark Planning and Tasking, we need to be able to define how a benchmark interacts with an attribute on a benchmark by benchmark basis. First, I propose the following new attribute quality, benchmarkCompatibilityType, with the following values.

Enum ValueBehavior
CompatibleIs fully compatible with benchmark and filters apply to it.
AsClientRequestMay be selected with benchmark but should only apply to client request. E.g., country filter with region benchmark.
IncompatibleMay not be selected with benchmark at all.

This enum would be used in two spots.

  1. As a new column on aid.attributes - This would be the default/global rule for benchmarks and this attribute. One example is an IMM attribute having an "Incompatible" value. 
  2. In a new table that overrides values in 1 above that applies to a specific benchmark. That table would have the following structure. 
ColumnValue
benchmarkIdforeign key to aid.benchmarkBreakouts
attributeIdforeign key to aid.attributes
benchmarkCompatibilityTypeEnum value, foreign key to aid.benchmarkCompatibilityTypes

Algorithm

On data request, use the following algorithm (in SettingsProvider.js): 

  1. If a benchmark is present
    1. Look at filters on request
    2. For each attribute
      1. Check for benchmark specific compatibility type, else use default
      2. Split on compatibility type
        1. If compatible, leave filter
        2. If AsClientRequest, remove filter from overal request and add to client portion of filter breakout
        3. If Incompatible, throw
  2. else make request normally

The above algorithm would need some tweaking to work for multiple benchmarks at once, but is achievable. 

Example request json

{
  "settings": {
    "filters": [
      { /* filter for country */ },
      { /* filter for card type */ }
    ],
    "webSettingsDimensions": [{
      "webBreakoutDimension": {
        "type": 1, /*filter breakout*/
        "values":[
          { "label": "Client", "orderId": 1, "filters": [{/* portfolio filter */}, {/* product line filter */}]},
          { "label": "Benchmark", "orderId": 2, "filters": [{/* peer benchmark filter or no filter for country/region benchmark */}]},
        ]
      },
      "limitConfig": {/* omitted */}
    }],
    /* other settings omitted */
  }
}

Web Settings Validation

Whenever receiving a request, we want to ensure that all granularly permissioned attributes are present to ensure users do not see data from an unpermissioned source or portfolio. There are two cases, benchmark and non benchmark. 

  1. If no benchmark
    1. Ensure that all granularly permissioned attributes are present in filters, else throw (ie product line, portfolio, country, card type)
  2. If benchmark
    1. Ensure that all granularly permissioned, non client only attributes are present in overall filters (i.e., country, card type)
    2. Ensure that client portion of filter breakout has granularly permissioned, client only attributes (i.e., portfolio, product line)
    3. Ensure that benchmark portion of filter breakout has no granularly permissioned, client only filters

Previous proposals

 Click to expand...

Proposal for data request

This proposal has these filters living in redux state with all our other filters.

Definitions

Attribute QualityTable Column
Granulary permissionedaid.attributes.permissionType
Client onlyaid.attributeDisplayConfig.isClientOnly

Algorithm

On data request, use the following algorithm (in SettingsProvider.js): 

  1. If a benchmark is present
    1. Look at filters on request
    2. For any attribute that is granularly permissioned AND client only (ie product line and portfolio)
      1. add that filter to client portion of filter breakout
      2. remove that filter from overall request
      3. other granularly permissioned attributes apply to overall request (client and benchmark data)
        1. this includes country and card type
  2. else make request normally

Example request json

{
  "settings": {
    "filters": [
      { /* filter for country */ },
      { /* filter for card type */ }
    ],
    "webSettingsDimensions": [{
      "webBreakoutDimension": {
        "type": 1, /*filter breakout*/
        "values":[
          { "label": "Client", "orderId": 1, "filters": [{/* portfolio filter */}, {/* product line filter */}]},
          { "label": "Benchmark", "orderId": 2, "filters": [{/* peer benchmark filter or no filter for country/region benchmark */}]},
        ]
      },
      "limitConfig": {/* omitted */}
    }],
    /* other settings omitted */
  }
}

This page is meant to list out miscellaneous concerns and tasks that we need to resolve as we work to get the Data Latency Work over the line:

Methodology and documentation

  • We need to come up with and document methodology for:
    • Processing data for a client daily on a server
    • Spinning up a new dataset
    • Restating one (or more) datasets
      • Figuring out if we are OK presenting a partially-restated output table to clients; if not, what our plan is
    • Restating a portion of the data for one (or more) datasets
  • We should talk through what is currently accessible for India data team, and see about documenting or walking them through it.
  • We should finalize a set of checks/alerts we're looking at daily to make sure consolidation is not lagging behind and data population is within reason.

Development work remaining

  • Finish job management code (and merge)
  • Finish cache clearing feedback (and merge)
  • Finish other consolidation code
    • Confirm that 7 day consolidation/restatement window (leave us at 99% + for USA, AUS, BRA) is good enough
    • Weekly chunking
      • Make sure we're fine with how this approach affects some of our account attributes
        • Residential zip - pull forward logic for accounts is now not 100% correct if we go backwards when restating data
        • Prior spend - this problem was around before, but given how we use the future week's values to calculate the current week, restating one could mean inconsistencies with the other
    • Parent job manager
    • Making sure consolidation SP is going to be deployed automatically
  • Need to create view that unions MC_ETL TLOG and consolidated TLOG – (do we need consolidation code to manage this? probably!)
  • Need to settle on how much unconsolidated data we want to keep around/process for freeing up space
    • CUT consolidation transactions we want to keep around going forever. We probably want to clean up the unconsolidated table after 30/60 days?
    • GCO transactions we could keep around forever, but since we don't consolidate/transform the data at all, our version of GCO transactions is the same as the SAN version - it just get's updated more frequently. We could be aggressive here and clean up as soon as the SAN dates available gets updated.
  • Transaction attribute calculation performance enhancements (Perhaps outside the scope of this page but it will reduce final data latency!)
    • Update prior spend calculation to look both forwards and backwards for the optimization branch

Coordinating rollout

  • We'll need to set up Cheddar IMO, MCDI should set up the consolidation / TransactionAttributes dependencies, and should coordinate with others to create/port clients here
    • Need to set up an instance w/ connection string to CHEDDAR so that we can configure scheduled jobs
    • Need to create databases on Cheddar (need to fill in details here)
    • Create/port some datasets to Cheddar (turn off in Gouda!)
    • Need to direct each day's data to both GOUDA and CHEDDAR (for consolidation)
  • For both TransactionAttributes calc servers we need to coordinate jobs:
    • Turn off existing scheduled jobs
    • Setup / turn on new job-manager scheduled jobs
  • For every client we roll out to, we need to configure the instance (plan to work with Kenny to coordinate):
    • Each client instance needs to configure the "lag" database setting (Alex to check; I think I made a default - and we should verify that this is a good default)
    • Each client instance needs toggle flipped to use "lag"
    • These changes need to be synchronized with deployment of the new datasets (where datesavaiable has the new maxDwProcessDate column)

Cheddar setup

    • Cheddar first
  • Get initial consolidation/transaction attributes working end to end for AUS client so we can start testing on Cheddar - Pan Wang
