pageTitle: Design for job runner to manage consolidation and TA calc
content:
Problem statement

As we move towards daily consolidation, an important question becomes how we manage jobs that need to be run with different priorities. Some examples include:

  • Consolidating transactions daily
  • Remapping the affected transactions for each client after consolidation
  • Rerolling all history for clients on a given server
  • Adding an attribute for a client and recalculating a new output

These different units of work all need to play nicely with each other for us to get to daily updates for AID.

With the current infrastructure, we need to solve 3 problems:

  1. We always want consolidation and transaction attributes calc to run serially so that we don't get into an inconsistent state (e.g. the attributes you've calculated use a different version of the transaction from the one you're actually mapping because consolidation ran in the middle).
  2. We also want the ability to prioritize consolidation over other units of work (e.g. if we happen to be running a historical reroll for a client, we don't want that to hold back consolidation)
  3. We need a way to prioritize certain parts of each calculation rather the current model where each run must finish entirely before another run can start (e.g. the weeks that need to be restated for daily refreshes need to take priority over any weeks being mapped for a restatement).

Initial solution

To address these issues, we're going to split up the solution into two parts:

  1. Creating a component that can manage priority between consolidation and transaction attributes calc
  2. Changing the current transaction attributes calc so that we can further prioritize certain parts of that specific calculation

Component to mange priority among job types 

This component's purpose is to establish some priority across job types and then figure out the next highest priority job to run. Here is some psuedocode for the logic that will be called via a scheduled job probably every few minutes:

public class ParentJobManager {
    
    public void Run() {
        var currentJob = // read current job being processed from db
        if (currentJob.IsRunning()) {
            return;
        }
        if (consolidationShouldRun()) {
            var consolidationJob = // make call to consolidation calc project to create and kick off job that corresponds to the highest priority unit of work
            // insert consolidationJobId into db table that keeps track of current job being processed
            return;
        } 
        if (transactionAttributesShouldRun()) {
            var transactionAttributeJob = // make call to transaction attribute calc project to create kick off job that corresponds to the highest priority unit of work
            // insert consolidationJobId into into db table that keeps track of current job being processed
            return;                 
        }
    }
}

This component isn't responsible for enumerating all possible units of work across job types and prioritizing between them nor does it maintain a record of what order to run things. Rather, all it does is figure out whose turn it is to do work and it's up to individual components in the consolidation/transaction attribute projects to figure out what is the most important thing to run if it is your turn and return that single job.

If we consider the current state of our transaction attribute calculation job, pushing only this change leaves us in a world where consolidation and transaction attribute calculation never run at the same time. However, this doesn't guarantee consistent daily updates because the only unit of work we have in transaction attributes is "calculate everything" for a client. If we only have daily updates, that is probably fine and doesn't block the next time consolidation needs to run. But if we're doing a historical reroll for a client, this could end up blocking more important processes like consolidation and daily rerolls for other clients, which is not a desirable state.

Changes to transaction attributes calc to allow for smaller units of work

The additional build we need to make to ensure that we don't get into a state where consolidation or daily updates get blocked, is to break up the transaction attribute calculation into smaller jobs (weeks). Rather than the unit of work being returned from transaction attributes being a run in it's entirety, we actually want to return a run + week combination. This is a fully enclosed and small enough calculation that we expect it to finish and never block consolidation, and also allows us to prioritize different dates across runs. Here is an example if our server was supporting 3 runs (A, B, C) and a historical reroll for run A starts to run and a consolidation job comes in a little bit later:

  1. ParentJobManager checks if there is anything runnning on the db. There is not.
  2. ParentJobManager checks if there is any consolidation work to do (e.g. has the max_dw_process_date changed since the last run). There is not.
  3. ParentJobManger checks if there is any transaction attribute work to do (e.g. are any attributes marked as rerun or any dates marked for remap). There are because we're doing a historical reroll of run A.
  4. The component in TransactionAttributes figures out all units of work that need to be done. In this case there is attribute calculation/remapping that go into rerolling each week, W1, W2, W3, for run A. It returns the highest priority unit, which would be run A, W3 because we're going backwards in time.
  5. ParentJobManager registers that TA job for run A, W3 is running.
  6. While run A, W3 is running, more data on dw_process_date gets loaded so we now can consolidate more data.
  7. When run A, W3 finishes, the ParentJobManager see that there is now consolidation work to do.
  8. The component in Consolidation figures out all units of work that need to be done. For this component, it's pretty straight forward, we need to consolidate the last 7 days.
  9. ParentJobManager registers that job for consolidating, CON, is running.
  10. When CON is done, the ParentJobManager will see that there is more transaction attributes work to be done.
  11. The component in TransactionAttributes figures out all units of work that need to be done. Now, not only is there the remaining W1, W2 for run A, we also need to recalc attributes/remap transactions for W4 which was newly consolidated for all runs. The units of work now that need to be done are (run A, W1), (run A, W2), (run A, W4), (run B, W4), (run C, W4). It is up to this component to return the single highest priority unit which would be any of the W4 runs because we want to prioritize daily refreshes over historical rerolls.
  12. ParentJobManager registers that TA job for run C, W4 is running.
  13. When that finishes, it will either continue to pick up the next highest priority job in transaction attributes or run consolidation if it detects there is more data to consolidate.

This allows us to always deliver on the most recent weeks (daily updates) first before any less important weeks (historical rerolls) and as long as each unit of work is small enough, we won't be blocking consolidation This also leave us flexible to further prioritizing in the transaction attributes component, but as long as we're always returning the highest priority unit of work, the ParentJobManager doesn't need to care about those mechanics.

Simon's notes: Business Insights Reduce Data Latency

Dave's whiteboarding skills:

The chart here was by looking at a single date and for the whole world. I recommend querying transactions.transactions by reviewing the dates elapsed between DW_PROCESS_DATE(date loaded to DWH, which is closely correlated to clearing) and transactionDate(date transaction happened at the POS) to look at a broader sample of dates and segment this by different countries.  I think that information would be valuable.

pageTitle: Handling Daily & Historical Loads (AKA Calculating all the things on Gouda)
content:
Overview

APT-130830 - Getting issue details... STATUS

As we move toward a model in which restatements of transactions, account attributes, and transaction attributes becomes more and more common, we need to be proactive about designing in ways that supports all our current and future use cases and is realistic given the load constraints on Gouda. In particular, we now have the following concerns:

  1. Regular calculation of new client outputs as new data becomes available
  2. Daily restatement of recent transactions through the consolidation process
  3. Regular restatement of recent historical data provided to clients on a cadence ranging from daily to weekly (the specific cadence could be client-specific)
  4. Ad-hoc calculation historical data for new clients or for existing clients when new attributes are added
  5. Ad-hoc restatement of the historical transaction log, account attributes, and subsequent transaction attribute output tables

In light of the growing volume of calculation requirements, we're already at the point at which we'll be unable to meet all these goals perfectly under the current assumptions (namely, that gouda is our only calculation server, everything is calculated serially, and we must remain internally consistent - the transaction set used in the output table must be the same as the one used to calculate account attributes).

For example, spinning up a new client or adding a new attribute currently takes about 2-3 days of dedicated calculation time. Once one or more of our clients are expecting a daily load of data, it will impossible to spin up a new client or add a new attribute unless we relax some constraints or make targeted changes in how we break up our calculations.

Adding priority

One way to meet all the requirements listed above is to assign a priority to each concern and make changes to our calculations to support respecting priority. A reasonable initial set of priorities is listed below:

  1. Daily/regular loads (if we fail to provide these to active clients, we won't be in a good place)
  2. New client calculations over all history / new attributes for existing clients (these are important, but can be run in an "offline" manner)
  3. Full restatements due to problems with how Mastercard or the ETL team load the data (these are important to get to eventually, but we wouldn't typically halt everything and start over from scratch)

One nice feature of these priorities is that they're also in increasing order of complexity and time required to achieve.

Overall Design

Before diving in to the full details of what implementing priorities like these would entail, it's worth identifying the different components of the overall transaction attributes project that would be affected:

  • Transaction consolidation
  • Attribute calculations
  • Output table transaction attribute mapping

Ideally, each of the components above would have a separate job, and a parent job could manage relationships between them. In general, the goal is to achieve the highest-priority work first and only move on to lower-priority portions with spare calculation resources.

To achieve prioritization of daily loads, any part of the three components above responsible for regular data load needs to be able to cancel (or run in parallel with) other jobs related to lower-priority items. For example, if the daily consolidation job begins to run but calculations for a new client are still running, we should have the ability to pause the new client setup in order to complete the highest-priority work. Similarly, if all priority #1 tasks are finished, then new client calculations and new attribute additions would take precedence over full restatements which affect all clients (one could argue for a different prioritization here, but the principle remains).

Supporting Full Historical Restatements

There are a few nuances to adhering to this principle. In particular, full historical restatements of transactions are hard to support. For example, let's imagine how we would handle a bug like the recent spend amount local currency issue affecting calculations during September. To fully and correctly address the issue, we'd have to completely restate anything that touched the transaction log during the month of September. For the sake of argument, let's say we have to restate two years' worth of transaction history. What happens next?

To start, we should continue to provide daily data loads based on the new data, but there are a few more complexities now. One major complicating factor here is that it's quite possible that a full restatement of account attributes would not complete before it's time to provide a new week of data to an existing client. In order to meet this use case, we'd need to allow for prioritization within the precalculated attributes, favoring recent history (to support continued delivery of data) over data in 2015. Once all the priority 1 and priority 2 steps are done for the day, then more account attributes and output table restatement can occur.

It's worth noting that in the worst-case scenario in this model, early periods might never get restated (i.e., if gouda can't keep up or if we perform another widespread restatement before the first one is complete). That's not a great world to live in, but the advantage of this approach is that by prioritizing the most important work first, we're providing the most overall value by providing data in the most accurate and consistent form possible.

Specific Design Implementation

The specifics of how to add priority to our components may be tricky, because currently, both the calculators themselves and the mapper assume that they should run until there is nothing else to do. It would seem that we'd need to refactor code to either be more top-down (i.e., a parent component determines what is most important and calls each component with the specific arguments appropriate for the priority), or we need each component to be able to make a call to some other component which provides the appropriate arguments for the current priority. These specific questions are probably worth a larger design discussion, but the overall idea is that how much is accomplished by each component at any given time is dependent on the context of priority.

It's also worth noting that this will become significantly easier and more maintainable with greater separation between the different components. The JobQueue supports cancellation and continuations, so we should leverage these to manage dependencies and priority appropriately. For example, daily consolidation should probably be able to cancel anything else that is running. Likewise, prior spend running for the daily load should be able to cancel remapping a period based on a historical restatement in 2015.

Open Questions

  • Parallelism: With careful application of parallelism, we may be able to get more out of Gouda. That said, thinking about priorities in a distributed way becomes significantly more difficult if we allow for more than one thing to operate at a time.
  • Servers: The introduction of another server in addition to Gouda would be helpful for achieving more of the data availability and restatement goals, but what would be the right division of processes and servers if we added another server to the mix?
  • Consistency: Until now, we've been holding pretty tightly to the property that the transaction set you map in a period must be the same as the transaction set any account attributes in that period were based on. This ensures that results for prior spend are internally consistent with the results you would get if you individually summed the spend across each account in the period. That said, relaxing this constraint would make many things significantly easier, as we wouldn't be as concerned about the order in which things run. To what extent does this constraint make sense in light of some of the wider questions at stake here?
  • Priority Management: There are many specifics involved with adding priority to our code, both in terms of the individual components, the mapper, and the new job/component that must manage everything. This is likely to be complex and will be no small task.

Geospatial attribute config

IN KIRK:

  1. Use mckirkappdb and the database PlatformDb_MI
  2. Confirm the attribute is in one.entities. Keep that entity id somewhere.
  3. Confirm the *MasterTable for the attribute (found as a column on one.entities is populated)
  4. Look at dbo.databaseSettings and look at the rows where settingId LIKE '%defaultMap%'. Confirm that the lat, long, and default zoom make sense

  6. Use marsh and the correct web database (e.g. GenericGroceryStore)
  7. Insert into aid.mapAttributeEntities with the entity id (from step 2) and the attribute id (found in aid.attributes)
  8. Clear web cache and turn on the BingMaps and GranularGeography toggles
  9. Create a card with a map and ensure that your attributes available as splits for the map and that data is correct.

IN PRODUCTION:

  1. Use DARWIN and the relevant client database (be sure to do this on ALL client databases!)
  2. Create an entity for the geospatial attribute using p_aptOne_addGenericEntity
  3. Populate geospatial tables by selecting INTO the table listed in one.entities FROM the associated table in AptGeospatialData database

  6. Use DARWIN and the relevant _AIDWeb database

Assumptions:

The code definition provided by the mapper is always consistent (i.e, code 1 always means code 1, even if its not in use any more).

  • We therefore cannot re-claim / re-purpose an unused code

We will have to implicitly filter all results requests with down to the codes that are granular permissioned codes (i.e., if you only have access to Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday - there needs to be a filter that adds Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday to make sure all transactions on those dates are what are considered)

Tasks:

  1. Add new column to aid.attributes called "permissionType" or similar
    1. The permissionType column will be an int to provide ultimate flexibility
    2. We will only support coded attributes initially, so we should add a check constraint to make sure the attribute is coded
    3. permissionType will be an enum within C# with two options:
      1. Default 
      2. Granular - where we will bake in code permissioning
    4. We will add a default constraint on the permissionType column to set it to 1
    5. Update the attribute creation stored procedure to take permissionType as an option
  2. Create a new itemType on the primary product database called 'AidAttributeCode' or similar
    1. Add a table aid.attributeCodeItems on either the web database or primary product database - which will have itemId, attributeId, codeId
    2. Populate the defaultItemPermission table to have an entry for 'AidAttributeCode'
  3. Update the ItemSetupHelper to create itemIds for new codes
  4. Update Attribute Service GetCodes function to filter out codes for attributes that have granular permissionType that are not permissioned to a user
  5. Make the front-end enforce some sort of required filtering for granular permissioned attributes
    1. Change to the filter panel to a selector / drop down that requires one box be checked, etc.
    2. Make sure you can't remove all the pills for a given filter?
  6. Throw on createResults in web if the any required filters are missing (or we could add them? - not sure what that would do to front-end state)
  7. On save card, update the itemDependencyMapping population to include the granular codes
    1. This ensures that anyone who tries to view the card (i.e, received the link) has the bare-minimum access required. 

 

Advantages of above:

  1. All changes are contained in Web
  2. No need to rework any sort of cache invalidation in results

Other design considerations:

If we wanted to take this a step further and have results check permissions (which is the plan I initially came up with), there are several technical hurdles:

  1. We would have to rework the cache to make sure that aidSettingsCacheKeys are ammended to include something around permissions (because you could get into the case where a the same aidsettings are passed, but the coded permissions are different for two different users) and therefore our filterSetTimeSlice cache would be incorrect / unusable
  2. We have to defend against different permission calculations between web / results; permission to an item is cached by session; when you don't have permission to an object, the permission is always checked, and thus due to order of operations - results could always have a super set of web (since permissions can be granted on-the-fly)
  3. We would also have to change out the breakout definition provider to filter out codes as well (if anything was filtered out - this would be bad - since DU would have run on the wrong thing).

pageTitle: 2017-11-30: Calculate new data sets and projects recap
content:
Summary

This project took many more days than initially estimated. This page summarizes key factors causing the delay and outlines ways to avoid such delays in the future.

Factors leading to more dev days

Creating derived join mapping clause

What was the problem / why was this needed? The residential DMA attribute required for PI was based off of the residential zip attribute. The required JOIN clause to obtain the residential DMA value needed the residential zip table, which is also a precalculated attribute. The infrastructure to do such a mapping did not exist. While this was not the first attribute that was based on a precalculated attribute, previous situations were handled on one-off cases that were utilizing the existing APIs in the TACalc codebase. 

Estimated time in this project: 5+ days

Resulting bugs or tech debt: 

  • Associated dates available type was not created
  • Blocking error if multiple residential zip tables to join to for a given time period
  • Alias conflict with multiple joins to the same table
  • Deleting the previous residential DMA attribute in TACalc that prompted this new mapping clause
  • Many existing attributes can utilize the derived join mapping clause. Refactoring some of these attributes to this clause can clean up much of the code in TACalc  APT-134962 - Getting issue details... STATUS

How to avoid in the future:

  • I don't think there was any QA involvement in testing this new mapper, so that would have added a little more time but probably would have caught some of the bugs we saw
  • More robust unit tests. The unit test had one test case and did not cover the case that blocked calculations
  • Not all app owners were aware of how the original residential DMA attribute (or any of the others) were being created. Going over how some of these attributes were going to be created may have avoided some lag time between kicking off the buggy run and brainstorming/implementing the new JOIN clause

Brazil cleansed postal code definition

What was the problem / why was this needed? A custom definition of postal code was requested by the Brazil team, involving string manipulation to create a derived attribute. 

Estimated time in this project: 3 days

Resulting bugs or tech debt:

  • The attribute was not initially created to be coded, meaning it could not be consumed in AID.
  • When it was coded, a custom codes table had to be created since we do not have a list of brazil postal codes (not a bug, but also not ideal)

How to avoid in the future:

  • The development of this was not very well thought out, I think because it seemed like mostly a proof of concept type of attribute that we ultimately don't want to replicate/use for long. It also ended up needing multiple attributes to get to the final one that AID will use (string to int, then derived).
  • Add a check to ensure correct attributes are coded and have associated codes

Missing parenthesis causing inaccurate (and super slow) USA data set calculation

What was the problem / why was this needed? Parenthesis were missing around the transaction log WHERE clause specifying to keep transactions where the issuer is USA or the merchant country is USA, leading to super slow calculation time. Investigating the slow calculation time led to the realization (thanks Pan Wang) that parenthesis around the conditions of that WHERE clause were necessary for correct order of operations.

Estimated time in this project: 1 day + recalculating USA data

Resulting bugs or tech debt: None

USA run was using AA precalculated attribute results

What was the problem / why was this needed? All persisted precalculated attribute results are AA specific, but do not have any indication/connection to the AA client runs in the database. Thus, when USA was calculating prior spend, top of wallet, etc. it was using the AA results. When USA got to a week that AA hadn't gotten to yet, the USA run calculated it itself. This luckily is not an analytic bug here since we do want USA to use the precalculated results for the "all transactions by a USA issued card" dataset, but we realized that when Citibanamex ran a few months ago, it may have calculated these attributes before AA, leading to inaccurate results for AA.

Estimated time in this project: about 2 days in this project (will be finished in subsequent project)

Resulting bugs or tech debt:

  • Had to recalculate time-varying attributes that may have been calculated during the Citibanamex calculation window
  • Resulted in new "internationalize precalculated attribute" project

Missing attribute codes for new attributes

What was the problem / why was this needed? In multiple cases the codes were not added to the intAttributeCodes or varcharAttributeCodes table for a new attribute. 

Estimated time in this project: 0.5 days of dev work, but more hours of lost calculation time

Resulting bugs or tech debt: 

  • A way to validate that all requested codes attributes have codes during the database provisioning step would catch this much more quickly
  • The Improve handling of updated and deleted codes project will help with this too

Including null in intAttributeCodes table

What was the problem / why was this needed? Adding a new attribute to intAttributeCodes based on a table included  a row where the code was `null`. This needed to be removed for the calculator to continue.

Estimated time in this project: 0.5 days of dev work

Resulting bugs or tech debt: None

Considering CRS to adding new attributes

What was the problem / why was this needed? There was miscommunication on adding new attributes to the CRS instance and the current state of the CRS instance that needed to be addressed before moving forward with adding these attributes.

Estimated time in this project:  a few hours of consideration and going over requirements

How to avoid in the future: Having/going over project requirements more clearly in the beginning the project. 

Future considerations

Multiple workstreams: This project involved a lot of similar work but still multiple different work streams. Creating attributes and/or data sets for new geographies or clients involves the same kind of work, but balancing AA, USA, Canada, Brazil, and Australia datasets and the associated new attributes for each proved to be more context switching than initially expected and it became challenging to keep track of what state everything was in at any given time. 

Resources: While communication between project-mates was done well, certain considerations were overlooked by all members of the project (especially when adding the derived join attribute clause) that led to more bugs and delayed kickoffs, making planned runs get pushed back even more.

The Strategy agreed upon was to, categorize tasks that will require manual testing execution in the beginning and then take a fail-safe approach by setting up automatic checks across the data pipeline. 

*I am mentioning those who I think will be a good point person to start with, but foresee changes as we actually try to execute these tasks. 

  1. List of Initial Implementation tasks that would need Manual testing execution required. Kenny Chin , Nicholas Morrow
    • Version control from McMaster to Gouda
    • Regression test for consolidation scripts
    • Regression test and validation checks for data pipeline.   - Nicholas Morrow
    • Cache invalidation - publishing this in TA, logging clears, and clearing correctly
    • Rerunning account attributes based on updates, publishing maxDwProcessDate column
    • Pan Wang Can you list out additional areas we talked about in the meeting here?
    •  
  2. Setup Tasks that needs to be done before actual implementation:  APT-128985 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Task out story to get the necessary columns we should be reading dwProcessDate, dwSequenceNumber - Pushkar Rege / Allie Ivener - Added to Sprint K
    • Identify areas where Data Import failure detection would be useful - Pan Wang & Kenny Chin 
      • Timeline: Next sprint +1 from 10/3 (sprint next bag)
      • ex. McMaster → Gouda

      • APT-131337 - Getting issue details... STATUS
      • APT-131335 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Identify splunk logs that will help setup alerts when trx difference is more than a certain % threshold  Nicholas Morrow & Kenny Chin   
      • Timeline: Next sprint +1 from 10/3 (sprint next bag)
      • Hard stop process at ex. 2% 
      • Log date when difference is more than 0.5% but does not stop the process. 

      • APT-131338 - Getting issue details... STATUS
      • APT-131336 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Draw out requirements on what are the trigger points, implications, actionables in monitoring Data trends - Hai-Ri Park & Kenny Chin 
      • Timeline: Next sprint +1 from 10/3 (sprint next bag). potential to overflow. Sprint +2
      • ex. the amazon state should not have the highest actual spend vs. Rio) 

      • APT-131339 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Identify splunk logs that will help monitor/track delays/load/performance, status of how different events trigger downstream events etc. - Kenny Chin
    • Identify and add another/move TransactionValidator function up the pipline from where it is currently. - Pan Wang & Kenny Chin
      • Identify if there is additional validation that should be added to the TransactionValidator
  3. Actual Implementation 
    • TODO after step 2 is done.

 

The tasks above are things that has to be tackled to implement an eventual automated fail-safe process. Following are areas we are trying to handle:

  • Data Import Failure detection 
  • Data Quality and consistency regards to data movements across systems
  • Monitor and track Delay, loads & Performance

pageTitle: Data latency design for separate ETL process
content:
We want to construct our own pipeline to get to daily data refreshes for the AID platform. Currently, we have places in the ETL process where we're either mandating an artificial lag (wait a week before publishing the last week to give transactions at least 7 days to be processed) or rely on processes that present other points of lag (SAN sync). To get to daily refreshes, we want to hook into the ETL process where it makes sense and then do our own processing (with only the columns we need, with a smaller look back window than the data team uses) that allow for most up to date data.

 

 

Where do we diverge from the ETL process?

Currently the ETL team pushes both CUT (after the transactionDate match with AUTH and appending installment data) and GCO data partitioned on dw_process_date to MC MASTER, pretty much as soon as the files arrive and processing is done. Much of this processing and other business logic (assign accounts, filter opt out customers) happens on MC MULE and we're grabbing this data as soon as it lands on MC MASTER to pipe to GOUDA.

That means the data set that moves to GOUDA is piped daily by dw_process_date (DW_ALL_TXNS in diagram above).

What steps do we reimplement ourselves on GOUDA?

For CUT data, the final transaction log being published is partitioned on transaction date, so we need to consolidate (depivot from dw_process_date to transactionDate) into another table. This currently happens on MC MASTER and the ETL team consolidates the past 90 transactionDates every time a new dw_process_date comes in, guaranteeing that every transactionDate has a 90 day window for transactions to be reported before we "freeze" it in. There are historical rerolls/one time updates that can change data older than 90 days, but this is the model the data team operates with for the weekly SAN publish.

We're hooking into the process before this consolidation process to (1) speed up this process by consolidating fewer days and (2) bypassing the SAN sync. For our process we will assume we only need to consolidate the last 7 days. This is subject to change and some further investigation, but for CUT it takes about 7 days to get to 99% of transactions which is a threshold we're comfortable with. So each time we get a new dw_process_date partitioned dropped onto GOUDA, we need to reconsolidate the last 7 days of CUT and update the finalized transaction log (CONSOLIDATED_TXNS in picture above).

For GCO, there's no additional process because data is loaded and consumed on the the final transaction log partitioned on dw_process_date.

What downstream effects does this have for TA calculations?

For CUT, we will be consolidating and restating the last 7 days every day. Therefore, we need to recalculate all attributes that were calculated using those dates as well as remap the TA augmented tlog for those 7 days every day. 

This is further complicated by GCO, because there's no consolidation process and therefore no "freeze in" step. Data on transactionDate will continue to come in and change the set of rows we need to look at for clients that need GCO data. Given that GCO is reported differently, it's possible that we want to restate a longer period than just the consolidation window to get to a sufficient level of data population (> 99%).

This definitely varies by country/geography, but after doing some investigation, CUT and GCO both seem to get to around 99% population after 7 days, for the geographies we're currently supporting (USA, AUS, BRA). 

Therefore, the initial build is to use the same window for CUT/GCO, but remain flexible to making that different or vary by client in the future.

How much of this own TLOG do we plan on storing? 

This model requires us to store our own versions of CUT and GCO as we pipe data from GOUDA starting at some point. Rather than rerunning this data movement/consolidation process for all history, we can pick a date to seed data using transactions.transactions, transactions.gcoTransactions (probably maxDatesAvailable currently) and then use our own version going forward after that. The view for transactions.transactions on GOUDA would look something like this if we started moving CUT data using our own pipeline on 2017-01-01.

SELECT accountId, locationId, transactionDate, spendAmountUSD
FROM MasterCardData.transactions.transactions -- ETL tlog
WHERE transactionDate < '2017-01-01'
UNION ALL
SELECT accountId, locationId, transactionDate, spendAmountUSD
FROM TransactionLogConsolidation.consolidation.consolidatedTransactions -- our own tlog
WHERE transactionDate >= '2017-01-01'

Everything after 2017-01-01 will be data we've moved/conslidated ourselves using this separate data pipeline.

What decisions have we made regarding how our TLOG will be diverging from the ETL TLOG?

This does mean that as time passes, we will be diverging gradually from transactions.transactions published on the SAN by the ETL team. Transactions that come in between the 7 days later and 90 days later will be lost from our tlog and the downstream augmented TA tlog we publish, but that should only be ~1% of transactions. There are also more dramatic shifts that the data team could make (if they need to reload an old month of data, or change some logic in their pipeline) that we will not get automatically since we're presisting our own tlog. The stance we're taking in both these situations is that a full historical restatement is required if we want to resolve these differences. These should be rare and actually given our current model, pretty easy to resolve (aside from the recalculation time itself). We would just adjust the date in the view (2017-01-01) to be a later date and start our process over from that date forward. We would then instantly get the ETL team's updates via the SAN and can continue our process going forward.

How does this affect dates available for the augmented TA TLOG that is currently published?

Currently, maxDateAvailable signifies what date we have data through for analysis with the assumption that this data is pretty static (because the ETL team has baked in some lag already). This concept has to change since we're restating many days of transactions daily. It will now be up to each client to set their maxDateAvailable to be some certain lag from the absolute last day we have data through. For example, if you're a merchant and don't want data to change, you could set your datesAvailable to be on a 7 day lag. But if you're open to seeing data change in order to get data more recently, then you can set your lag to be 3 days.

How do we plan on incorporating this into the current TA process. Is consolidation another job, does it run async?

The current plan is to make the consolidation process a separate component from the TA calc process, but have them called sequentially in a parent job throttled at 1. Though these processes could run async, it can lead to race conditions that cause data inconsistencies. An example below:

  1. We calculate account attributes with the tlog consolidated with max dw_process_date = 1/1
  2. A new dw_process_date comes for 1/2 and we reconsolidate. So 7 days worth of transactions before 1/2 will have more rows than went into the calculation of account attributes.
  3. We try to map the transaction log in step (2) with the new tlog but using account attributes from step (1).

We now have an inconsistency (which I would categorize as a bug) because you could have an account with prior spend in AA = $100 in last 7 days, but have more than $100 in spend if you just summed up from rows in the tlog. Our goal is to keep each publish of the TA augmented table to be consistent with itself and the current solution is to throttle things at 1 so we don't open ourselves up to this race condition.

Objectives

The data pipeline work we are doing has a couple objectives

  1.  Reduce data latency.
    1. Get to a daily, automated process
    2. Improve performance of the ETL pipeline
  2. Create a robust ETL process to serve the MDP.
    1. Improve existing steps.
    2. Decrease number of steps, data hops, number of machines, processes, tasks, etc. involved in the process.
    3. Decrease dependency and/or conflict with non-MDP consumers (shared component code is good, but shared pipeline use leads to conflicting priorities)

 

Phase 0: (Ongoing) Build knowledge around the existing process and identify possible improvements.

 

Phase 1: (Late Aug - September) Urgency around the first object is driven by the business opportunity to deliver Merchant Intelligence in the Brazil market as soon as early October. 

  • To succeed in Brazil this October we should have our eyes set on the following by end of September (at least for the Brazil data-set):
    • The pipeline through to TransactionAttributes needs to be processed daily.
    • TransactionAttributes should be published to production daily.
    • Daily publishing should be automated
      • With possible exception being the final SAN-sync to production, which may depend on the HSM.
    • Where feasible, the pipeline should otherwise be improved to reduce latency.
  • The following goals should also be top-of-mind, though they could come shortly after the goals listed above if necessary:
    • Cache management should be automated (when new data is automatically published which impacts prior results, those results should be purged)
    • DatesAvailable / additional lag should be adjustable (so that consumers can tradeoff between latency and data completeness)


Phase 2:  (TBD; depends on prioritization) Continuing to improve pipeline performance and robustness will continue to be valuable.  Ultimately, we expect the ETL process to need to handle a higher volume of data, more data sets (including on-us, other client data, fraud, etc).  We also expect this to ultimately feed into an MPP system (e.g. DashDB) in addition to TransactionAttributes tables.  We should be considering:

  • Understanding these other data sets, and how they need to be ingested.
  • Possibly developing an independent pipeline (with shared components).
  • Rethinking hardware and architectural needs of ingest.
  • (more detail listed below)

Callouts of some operational and data challenges

  • Piping data from MCMULE → GOUDA (if we choose this approach):
    • We will need to add to / add an additional DI process to execute the transfer.
    • We will need the bandwidth / capacity for the transfer
      • Based on the current pipeline, estimate that transfer of 1 day may be <1hr
      • Looks like writing to disk is limiting, not bandwidth – but we'll need to consider impact on the network
      • Unsure if we could get fiber for this?
    • Initial load, disaster recovery, and/or restatement process
      • Getting 3 years of the entire table oriented by DW_PROCESS_DATE over to GOUDA may be a challenge
        • Maybe there's an option to use the SAN for this one time?  I'm not sure whether MCMULE is attached?
      • Think Saptagiri said there's enough space; need to confirm that (We'll need the consolidated data; should be ~the same # of rows as CUT + GCO)
      • Won't need all columns

Phase 2: Independent pipeline with shared components

The medium and long-term timeline and needs of the MDP ETL / ingress operation are less clear than the goals above.  Achieving these needs will probably need to be part of one or more future epics.

We could think about a medium-term phase "Phase 2a".  If we assume that the current data-sets and outputs (TransactionAttributes) are largely unchanged, this phase could involve:

  • Thinking about hardware architecture:
    • We'll want to think about the set of servers (and their characteristics) and not assume that the MCMULE/MCMASTER/GOUDA pipeline is correct.
    • It's compelling to use a single server for ETL and TrxAttribute creation, rather than two
      • Remove cost of moving a large table (e.g. MCMULE→GOUDA).
      • The machine could be more powerful than MCMULE, which would reduce time cost for the initial ETL steps.
    • Alternatively, the HSM could enable automated SAN syncs reducing effective transfer time.
      • SAN space concerns would make this difficult right now
  • Shared components:
    • Rather than fully sharing the DI processes and output tables from MCMULE's ETL, it likely makes sense to share components, but allow each pipeline to optimize (e.g. the MDP inputs, currently, could probably avoid streaming a number of columns throughout the process).
    • We'd want components (possibly SSIS components, as well as some shared SQL scripts) to be shared between the pipelines for consistency
    • However, having separate pipelines using shared components would allow the two to individually balance priorities
  • Reliability:
    • In addition to latency, we expect that in the long run a separate pipeline could help achieve goals of reliability:
      • The MDP pipeline would not change / be impacted by needs of other efforts.
      • The MDP may be able to have fewer data dependencies (though, on the flip side, it will eventually likely have more)
  • Other challenges
    • MCMULE has a number of supporting tables (currency conversion, installment, locations, ...).  Making all of these available in a consistent way would need to happen.
    • SSIS component development
      • Developing these is a bit cumbersome and debugging isn't as straightforward as writing unit tests
      • Unclear whether complex dataflow processes (like opt out logic) can be easily written as custom components
        • If they can, how will performance be in comparison?
      • Creating these comes with the implication that we will be owning parts of the data team's process. If they require changes to the components, we will need to be responsive to those.
        • Alternatively, we could see if members of their team want to partner on this effort so they can be empowered to make changes (or new components) in the future.

 

A longer term phase "Phase 2b" could be to envision future MDP evolution and needs.  Some areas we can start to mull over include:

  • How do ETL/ingest needs start to change as we load into an MPP (e.g. DashDB)?
  • How and when do we incorporate different date sets (fraud, on-us, other client provided data, IMM)
    • Today when we do have this sort of data it is not part of the same ETL pipeline.  Should it be?
  • Do we end up with multiple pipelines? (e.g. different columns and data needed for Market Intelligence vs. Portfolio Intelligence vs. banks, etc)

SSIS: Generate TransactionId and get distinct customers

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/Packages/ExtractAccountTransactions_Cut.dtsk ? (filename was cut off in screenshot)
  • Read through flat files (does not need all columns)
  • Identify opt-outs (DE2_CARD_NBR == "OPTED_OUT" or DW_ISS_COUNTRY_CD == "SWE", or in ETL_OPTOUT_MC_CUSTOMERS
  • Generates TransactionIDs
    • Uses procedure MC_MASTER_ETL.DBO.generateTransactionID
      • Unclear if/where this is version controlled
    • This procedure assigns a unique set of trx IDs to transactions within the same processing date.
      • This procedure uses a table that is generated during the CutC data load (referenced as "temp_transactionID table" in the SSIS data flow
      • it checks the master trx ID table to see if there are already entries for the dw process date that was just loaded.
        • if so, then it finds the max transaction ID for that day, identifies new transactions for the dw process date in question, and assigns IDs to those new transactions
        • If not, it assigns transaction IDs to the transactions starting with tthe `min_trx_id` value for the date in "Mc_master_etl.dbo.etl_transactionID_range".
    • Note: transaction IDs assigned are unique across the entire CUT data set.
    • Note 2: This SP is also used for GCO.

  • Applies salt

  • I quickly sp_helptext'd generateTransactionID.

It may very well be more efficient, but a number of the subsequent steps are focused on customerIds and they could happen separately if we did find that more efficient for some reason.

  • Creates "TypedTable"
  • Cleanup of DE_CARD_NBR (end spaces)

  • Why is the 'Union All 1' operator necessary? (Maybe it is, or it doesn't affect performance, but it seems pretty much the same as the union operator above it.) Edit - I see this in a bunch of places, so there's probably a good reason for it, just not sure I understand why yet.
~1 hour

Validate typed table

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/control_validation_cut.sql
  • Gather statistics for the "typedtable", such as distinct count of several columns, total sales, etc.
  • Compares with the control table. Most checks are exact, except for card number count (because of opt-outs).
  • Insert new rows into the master control table (MC_MASTER_ETL.dbo.etl_CUT_ctl_master)
  • There are several DISTINCT counts (DW_ISSUER_ID, DW_MERCH_LOCATION_ID, DW_ACCT_PREFIX6, DW_ACQUIRER_ID). It may be worth reviewing this the stats query to make sure the query plan is sensible and that this doesn't regularly spill as a result.
  • The transform needed for DE4_TXN_AMT is surprisingly complex; is that cleanup that can/should happen earlier?
~2 minutes

Partition swap into "production" table

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/swap_typed_to_production_cut.sql
  • Check for duplicate (DW_PROCESS_DATE, DW_SEQUENCE_NBR) rows in the new data
  • Partition swap new data into production table
  • Create clustered columnstore index on new table (WITH (DROP_EXISTING = OFF, DATA_COMPRESSION = COLUMNSTORE))
  • Check that "typedtable" is empty
  • I'm no colstore expert, but someone w/ experience should do a sanity check to make sure the creation of the colstore index makes sense as written. My assumption is that it does.
~15 minutes

Delete temp files and tables

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/Cleanup_temptables_cut.sql
  • Simple table cleanup
 < 1 minute

Update stats

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/update_stats_cut.sql
  • p_updatestats on ETL_ath_PRODUCTION for this dw process date

 

5-10 minutes

Update customerId in OPT OUT master table

/TransactionOptOut/Update_New_Accounts_in_Optout.sql
  • Updates MC_CUSTOMERS.dbo.ETL_OUTPUT_MC_CUSTOMERS to have the latest HASH_PAN → aptId mapping.
  • This is fairly straight foward; could check indexes on the relevant tables to make sure the HASH_PAN join is efficient.
  • Possibly unhepful, but it would be feasible to have an OPTOUT bit on ETL_MC_CUSTOMERS_PRODUCTION rather than requring a join again later on to ETL_OPTOUT_MC_CUSTOMERS in order to identify OPTOUTS. If everything is indexed properly this is probably a minor observation.
~15 minutes
1 (AUTH) - DI job moves AUTH data Mastercard files to McMule









Check customer duplicate status

/IngestAuthandCutFiles/check_customer_duplicate_status.sql		Runs the same SQL file as the CUT job above <1 minute
Copy files to temp directory; unzip (7zip)  ~10 minutes (almost all to unzip files)

SSIS: Extract daily AUTH accounts

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/Packages/ExtractAccount_Auth.dtsx

 15 minutes

SSIS: Load control file

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/Packages/Load_Control_File.dtsx

 < 1 minute

Create missing accountIds

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/create_missing_account_auth.sql
  • Similar to the comparable CUT step
 45 minutes

SSIS: Read AUTH data into SQL table

/CUT/Packages/LoadTypedTable_Auth.dtsx

 25 minutes

Validate typed table

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/control_validation_auth.sql
  • Similar to the comparable CUT step
 < 1 minute

Partition swap into "production" table

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/swap_typed_to_production_auth.sql
  • Similar to the comparable CUT step

 

 5-10 minutes

Cleanup temp tables

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/cleanup_temptables_auth.sql
  • Similar to the comparable CUT step
 < 1 minute

Update stats

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/update_stats_auth.sql
  • p_updatestats on ETL_ath_PRODUCTION for this dw process date

 

5 minutes

Update looping table

/IngestAuthAndCutFiles/update_loopingtable_auth.sql
  • Signifies that this day has been processed
 < 1 minute
2 - Process raw data






Validations

/CUT/AR/01_Preprocessing_Validations.sql
  • Some sanity checks around rowcount, installment data, making sure location data is up-to-date, making sure currency data rates are up-to-date.
  • The first row validation is commented out, but the aggregation over vw_ETL_CUT_Production_CCI is still run. Seems like we should either do the validation or remove the aggregation.
 

Grab the AUTH, CUT, and Installment data

/CUT/AR/02_Collect_Input_Data_Elements.sql
  • (left) join CUT data from step 1, and installment data (MC_ETL_TRXPROCESSING.dbo.vw_ETL_INSTALLMENT_PRODUCTION) (on dw_process_date and dw_sequence_nbr).
  • Index this table
  • There used to be a step here for AUTH, but it is commented out.
  • May be worth considering the tradeoff between writing the CUT/Installment join table vs. using a view or subquery (or the possibility of doing this in an earlier step).
 
Process GC (2.1) and non-GC (2.2) in parallel
  • In parallel, run:
    • DI Job 2.1: All SQL CUT - GC - Titanic 1
    • DI Job 2.2: All SQL CUT - non-GC - Titanic 1

(details below)

  

Currency manipulation

/CUT/AR/03_Calculate_SpendAmount.sql
  • Installment adjustment (write into new table and index) (for Brazil)
  • Compute USD and local spend exchange rates
  • Execute currency conversions, writing transactions into a new table, and indexing
  • There are multiple scan-and-write operations operating on the same raw records. It seems likely that we can consolidate. Assuming the write operation is expensive and the joins are inexpensive this may save time.
 

Create final table

/CUT/AR/07_Consolidate.sql
  • Waits for other DI jobs (Polls every minute)
  • Inserts GC data with join to currency adjustments and transaction datetime adjustments (all joins on DW_SEQUENCE_NBR)
  • Inserts non-GC data with join to currency adjustments and transaction datetime adjustments (all joins on DW_SEQUENCE_NBR)
  • Creates clustered colstore index on new table.
  • Does the lack of DROP_EXISTING = false raise any concerns?
  • Is it just me, or are there two inserts to the staging table with an identical rowset? I see a SELECT INTO and an INSERT INTO.
  • More generally, if we were in C#, I could imagine combining this step with the step above - that way we only write the data once instead of 2-3 times. Maybe we don't want to do that level of optimization, or maybe we want to keep it in two steps so we can validate.
 

SSIS: Move transactions to McMaster

/CUT/AR/MoveRawTxns_fromMcMule_toMcMaster.dtsx

  

"Update looping table"

/CUT/AR/08_UpdateLoopingTable -Titanic.sql
  • Updates process date (presumably to inform a DI loop that it can start processing the next day)
  

Process Orphans

/CUT/JD/09_ProcessGCOrphans
  • Identify orphans (where transactionDate is > 14 days older than DW_PROCESS_DATE
  • Does some duplication checks
  • Insert records into MC_GC_OrphantedData.dbo.etl_GC_Orphans{year} tables
  
2.1

Auth match

/CUT/AR/04_AuthMatch.sql
  • For GC transactions (may have both CUT and AUTH) identify matches btwn CUT and AUTH
  • Multi-step process to match CUTC and AUTH (first direct matches using AUTHOP_PROCESS_DATE, then BANKNET_REF_NBR
  • creates ETL_CUTCAUTH_MATCH)_FINAL table as output
  • There are a few upfront queries (get max/min DW_AUTHOP_PROCESS_DATE) that could be combined to avoid scaning the CUT_intermediate_table more times than necessary.
  • The match queries could be worth diving into; there are multiple scans and indexing steps; strategically consolidating some of these steps could be benefitial.
 

TZ Transform

/CUT/AR/05_TZTransformation_GC.sql

Timezone transformation for some transaction types (0,9,20)

  • There's quite a bit of logic; could be worth diving into
 
2.2

TZ Transform

/CUT/AR/06_TZTransformation_MS.sql

Timezone transformation for some transation types (0,9,20)

  • There's quite a bit of logic; could be worth diving into
 
3 DI Job moves GCO data to McMule and McMasterSimilar to (1)   
4

Manual(?) execution of consolidation script

/CUT/JD/Consolidation_Thread1.sql
  • Paritition-swap into MC_ETL_transactions_New.dbo.etl_transactions_production, partitioned now by transactionDate, by looking back up to 14 days (in terms of DW_PROCESS_DATE for each partition)
  • Caught up with Jaideep Sethi and got more detail on when/what cadence this is run.
  • This consolidation script is run every week (Sunday) on the last 28 dates (though this is going up to 90 days with the new transaction log).
  • We distinguish between transactions that were processed > 14 days after the local transactionDate (those that fall in the window get stored in the main table while those falling outside the window get stored in a special "orphaned" table) but when consolidating each transactionDate, we take all transactions that we have processed to date.
  • We then artifically deflate dates available to be max transactionDate - 3 so that we get ~95% of transactions for the most recent date.
 

There are a number of other scripts (creat stats, for example) in /CUT/JD/.

 

Open questions:

  • What about Auth?
  • What happens on McMaster to pivot to local transaction date; are there other operations?
  • Would it be faster to keep most of the columns separate in intermediate calculations and only join to get all the columns at the end?

pageTitle: 2017-02-02 Handling Parent Access Id / Account Issuer Id
content:
Problem

The 5/25 check for the benchmark check should be at the "parent issuer" level - i.e., at single legal entities for a given country. However, the data feed from Mastercard has some duplication of these parent issuers (e.g., multiple parent issuer ids with the same name).

Proposal

We want to create an apt version of this attribute that correctly groups parent issuers, and then use that for the 5/25 benchmark check.

Ideally, this solution would be automated (i.e., find matches automatically) and robust to refreshes of data.

Potential automated solution - Levenshtein distance

Finds "edit distance" (e.g., minimum number of character changes necessary to make one string into the other)

Findings:

OK for 0, but even 1 would require manual validation:

Not very good for distances > 3:

Full automation is probably not realistic. But this could serve as the basis for making the initial manual effort more efficient.

Open questions:

  • What does responding to updates look like?
    • Maybe flag changes / new rows that have edit distance > 0/1? (similar to how attribute codes updates are flagged)
    • In practice, this hopefully won't change that much
  • Cadence
    • Every time we load data? 
  • How much data should be considered?
    • 3,540 of 11,322  parent access ids are actually used
    • 555 of these are actually in the transaction attributes output table.

Decisions

  • US only for now (with transactions)
  • manual for first pass
  • In future, flag updates (if names don't match)
  • add column for aptAccountIssuerId
  • Timeline: not super urgent, but affects 5/25, so the sooner the better
  • US Bank is the worst offender
  • Follow up with Simon to add this to his list

WIP

APT-108655 - Investigate improvements to how we apply 5/25 checks DC SUBMITTED

Background

We currently apply 5/25 for each individual data point (e.g. each day/week). However, we are only required to apply the 5/25 check over the most recent 12 months of data available in aggregate. With this new implementation, all 5/25 checks would be based on the last 12 months according to our dates available table. If a graph is filtered to results for sales in the grocery industry, the benchmark checks would be applied to sales in the grocery industry for the most recent 12 months of data. If that passes, any time slice of sales in the grocery industry passes 5/25 check, whether it's in that 12 month period or not. 

Doing this is more complex than the current implementation and has potential negative performance implications, but it will also mean data will likely pass the data usage benchmark checks at a higher rate. 

Open Questions

  • How will the 12 months aggregated data be stored? 

  • What are the performance implications? How can results be cached? 
  • When, if at all, is the cache invalidated with new data?
  • Can any of the 12 months aggregation be calculated up front when new data is loaded?
  • What are the changes needed in code?

Calculations / Making this Work

Old Implementation

  • Input - rawMetricResults
    • filterSetId | startDate | endDate | spendAmountUsd | transactionCount | numberOfActiveAccounts | indexedSpendAmountUsd | indexedTransactionCount | indexedNumberOfAccounts
    • All of these values are for the given analysis period (i.e. number of active accounts between start and end date)
  • Output - dataUsageSummary
    • endDate | startDate | filterSetId | dataUsageRule | CheckPassed

Options for New Implementation

Option 1:

  • Input - add lastYearSpendAmountUsd and indexedLastYearSpendAmountUsd  columns to RawMetricResultsByIssuer and RawMetricResultsByAggregateMerchant ITables 
  • Output - dataUsageSummary: no changes

Option 2:

  • Create an additional table that stores the results for the 12 month aggregation for each filterSetId
    • filterSetId | startDateOfDatesAvailable | endDateOfDatesAvailable | spendAmountUsd | indexedSpendAmountUsd  where these values are for the last year of data in dates available
  • Input and output would not change
  • The Benchmark Rule Checkers would check that additional table to determine if the rule passes

Option 3:

  • Create a LastYearDataUsageInfoProvider that gives the needed information for given filterSetIds - then that can be used in the CompetitiveSetUsageChecker instead of what is currently the "input" parameter to that function

  • The ITables passed to the DataUsageValidationRunner for the merchant and issuer checks would be for the last 12 months of dates available instead of the analysis period
  • Passing in these new ITables would cause nothing in the Rule Checkers to change

Caching

Goal: If calc needs to be kicked off but the filter set has already been used for a different time frame, only run the cell size data usage check and use the previously determined results of the benchmark checks.

  • Calc doesn't have filter set id. What will we use as the key - the json request passed to calc? 
  • Should Data Usage trust that it may not need to run 5/25 checks since it passed before? 

Performance Implications

  • Added calculations on one years worth of data for each filter set
  • Cache hit for every future use of a filterSetId since the 12 months used in the aggregation will not change day to day
  • Consider recalculating the 12 month aggregations for commonly used filter sets when dates available is updated to avoid this recalculation on the fly
  • Benefit of not needing to do the 5/25 check for every time frame (especially good with custom time frames) because the check would instead be based on filterSetId and the same 12 months aggregation of data

Sample Runtime Differences

Data Usage Specific Queries (rolling up metrics by issuer and merchant to create the rawMetricResultsByIssuer/Merchant tables)

Chart Info12 months1 day
Spend YoY, 3 filters306 ms4 ms
205 ms4 ms
Donut3 ms1 ms
Usage Dashboard Spend YoY, 6 filters40 ms1 ms
  • Most of the time in the 12 month aggregation is from merging the individual rawMetricResults tables for each month into one table

Overall runtimes, specifically the population of the Intermediate Data Usage Aggregation Result table which reads from TransactionAttributes

Chart Info12 months1 day
Metric Tree, no filters81 sec20 sec
Metric Tree, 2 filters (product group, trx channel)174 sec1.7 sec
Metric Tree, 3 filters (product group, trx channel)120 sec14 sec
Metric Tree, 6 states3 sec0.2 sec
  • Of note, there were multiple cases where the 1 day time ranges failed data usage for benchmark checks and the 12 month one passed

Improved Pass Rate

Old Implementation DU Failures: Citi

I ran a sample calculation where the pass rate was improved from 10 rows failing the Issuer Benchmark Check to 9 rows. This was on Spend YoY, split by Industry, filtered to eCommerce.

Recalculating each failing dashboard card didn't seem like the best use of time, but my assumption is that the cards would be more likely to pass with this new implementation.


What attributes and filter sets are failing?

The following attributes failed at least one of the two benchmark checks in production (note this has been updated):

  • Residential State
    • 59.9% of filter sets that fail 5/25 have a filter this attribute
  • Top of Wallet
  • Transaction Channel
  • Product Type
  • Merchant Industry
    • 88.3% of filter sets that fial 5/25 have a filter with this attribute
  • Product Group Id
  • Is Benchmark
    • All filter sets are benchmark since it's the benchmark check
  • Total Transaction Count - 90 day lookback
  • Total Prior Spend - 30, 180 day lookback
  • Cross-Border Indicator
  • Is Citi?

6277 distinct filter sets failed a benchmark check on Citi. 1457 on Barclays.

401 filter sets did not fail a benchmark check for every time range requested on Citi, 109 on Barclays. 

What might start passing?

  • One filter set (21211) on Citi's database on Hardwell failed data usage rule #3 - Issuer Benchmark Check. Found same filter set on Titan (75575) and it does pass the Issuer Benchmark Check (7/35) if the new 5/25 rule is applied
  • Another filter set (14164) on Citi's database on Hardwell failed Issuer and Merchant Benchmark Checks. The queries with this filter set had been on one week of data at a time. The same filter on Titan (71376) does pass Issuer Check (5/25) and Merchant Check (6.30) with the new rule.
  • Both of those have a filter to a very specific Merchant (ex: Miscellaneous Technical Services) that presumably would have few transactions in a small date range and thus fail data usage. These cases would benefit from the increased date range of the new rule and have a higher likelihood of passing data usage. This relates to a problem with data in the "other" category of a chart being what fails data usage, causing the alert icon.

What might start failing?

  • Applying 5/25 on one year's data might cause different DU failures. Are we allowed to determine which 5/25 check would cause fewer failures and apply that one? 
     versus 

Code Changes

Depends on which option is chosen, but a basic outline:

  1. Get transaction extract for the most recent year in datesAvailable with the given filterSets
    1. MetricResultGeneratorJobRunner.cs
  2. Calculate number of active accounts for that transaction extract for both issuer and merchant
  3. Use that data for the Merchant and Issuer ITables passed to the DataUsageValidationRunner and used in the benchmark rule checks

Action Items

  • Create story/tasks to add better Splunk logging for data usage
  • Work on "other bar" story and investigate what DU failures are resolved by that change
  • Investigate home improvement example above 
  • Investigate Top of Wallet filter example from Chris
  • Reevaluate improved pass rates of new 5/25 check 
  • Discuss technical implications (i.e. caching)

Background

We currently use the PARENT_ACCESS_ID for grouping by issuer. This has a few problems, such as certain issuers having multiple parentIssuerId. 

Important to note: ICACode = IssuerId = AccessId 

Investigation and Findings

Getting Data

 

  • Aggregated financials to "parent-issuer" level and to "market grand-parent issuer" levels using [MasterCardData].[Merchants].[ICACodes] joined to [MasterCardData].[Transactions].[ColumnStoreSkinnyTransactions] on ica.parent_access_id = st.accountIssuerId

  • To make the query shorter, I filtered to USA and the ICACode's begin_date > 2016-01-01. Using ICACode for the date filter cause problems, such as Barclays and Chase returning no results. 

  • Waiting for a query by transactionDate on the skinny transactions table to finish running

Issues 

  • US Bank is under the MISC grandparent-issuer level and we don't want to look at everyone in the misc bucket when applying 5/25 → there are duplicates at the grand parent level
  • Chase, Bank of America, and Barclays did not appear anywhere in the aggregations which is problematic because they are in our benchmark group
    • Reason: Chase only had Canadian rows during the queried time period
    • Reason: Bank of America has two rows in the ICACodes table but did not match any in the skinny transactions table
    • Reason: Barclays does not have any rows in the queried time period

Motivation

Frequency splitter class is resposible for taking a start date, end date pair and a frequency and splitting the time period into time slices which are then used by calc as time unit for calculating metric results. Unfortunately, when you split and analysis time period into time slices based on fiscal calendar, some of them end up being partial (e.g. 30 day period could get split into 4 7-day weeks and one 2 day time slice). Hence, after getting back the results from the AIDResults app, the AIDWeb app has to use the Frequency splitter again to figure out which time slice is partial. Since we are currently working on getting rid of the AID.Core library,  I wanted to start a discussion on best possible option moving forward

Option 1: Move FrequencySplitter to AIDWeb

Rationale

As we expand the scope of the AID platform, we would expect the logic for getting time slices from analysis time period to become more complex where we can snap to start of the period or end of the period etc. It should not really be the responsibility of the Results API to maintain this logic and support all the edge cases. Rather the Results API should just take in whatever time slices the consumer wants and return results for those. That way, each consumer of the AIDResults app could split up the analysis time period based on their custom needs.

Pros

  1. Logic for splitting up Frequency is owned by single app
  2. AIDResults app is not concerned with fiscal calendar and the logic for getting time slices moves to consumers
  3. AIDResults api moves closer to being something like a public api where any app that is not AIDWeb could potentially still consume it

Cons

  1. This will be breaking change to the Results API
  2. This creates an inconcistency between frequency breakouts and attribute breakouts, forcing one to be evaluated in web and the other in results.  
  3. This may impact the results app's ability to optimize calculations since it will have less information about the requested data.

Option 2: Move FrequencySplitter to AIDResults

Rationale

Currently, AIDResults is in-charge of splitting up analysis time period into time slices, it should continue to do so. Web should take the time slices provided by AIDResults and present them without any additional validation. Since the Web app will need to know if a time slice is partial for display reasons, AIDResults api will need to pass that along.

Pros

  1. Logic for splitting up Frequency is owned by single app
  2. Web does not need to query FiscalCalendar again and do another join to get the flag

Cons

  1. IsPartial flag on TimeSlices is only used for display and should not be a responsibility of AIDResults API 
  2. This will be breaking change to the Results API
  3. Results will need to provide more context in its response (which means more to serialize and send between apps.
  4. Web will likely need to do timeSplitting logic in the future (ie showing how many weeks are in a custom time frame). That makes this option less optimal from for future code.

Option 3: Continue using Frequency splitter in two places

Rationale

No extra work required and it might be worth waiting a little bit more to see what other use cases come up.

Pros

  1. No extra work required

Cons

  1. AIDWeb and AIDResults need to query fiscal Calendar so that logic gets run twice for each request

Option 4: Create WebServer.Core and add FrequencySplitter there

Rationale

This will allow both apps to use the frequency splitter as they do today.

Pros

  1. Not invasive, code works just as is
  2. Prevents leakage of services currently existing in Core from also potentially be used / discoverable in the Calc Server applications

Cons

  1. Extra project in the solution
  2. AIDWeb and AIDResults need to query fiscal Calendar so that logic gets run twice for each request

Vote

What option do you think is best?

Simon's notes on these metrics are here: Productionalize and Automate Creation of Transaction Attributes. This page assumes understanding of what attributes we're trying to calculate.

Input

In order to calculate these attributes, we will need a table containing the following (keyed on hubId)

HubIdDescriptionLatLongOpenDateCloseDate
1LAX30.11-25.212013-01-01NULL
2DFW22.2117.312014-01-01NULL

 

Note: we probably shouldn't name the column hubId, it's generalizable to anything that has an associated lat/long (I would suggest locationId, but that's a very overloaded term)

Data Model

This type of attribute can be generalized as "attributes that can be calculated from comparing zip codes to the lat/longs of certain locations". I'd propose the following data model to store these attributes

attributeIdlocationTableNamelocationColumnNamedistanceToLocationAttributeTypethreshold
     

DistanceToLocationAttributeType is an enum describing how we actually want to calculate the value for a certain zip code (which of the attribute types on Productionalize and Automate Creation of Transaction Attributes is it)

distanceToLocationAttributeType
DistanceToNearest
Nearest
IsWithinBounds
NumberOfLocationsWithinBounds

Note: some of the distanceToLocationAttributeTypes are redundant (nearest with "none" as an option, is within the bounds). We can talk to Simon to verify which ones we actually want to calculate, but this doesn't really affect any design decisions

 

locationTableName/locationColumnName are used to get the table that we need to join to the zip codes table. The threshold is used to restrict certain distanceToLo

threshold is used to determine how many locations are within the bounds and whether or not the nearest is within the bounds. It should be null for attributes where it doesn't make sense.

Calculation - (zip, time frame) attributes

This is a new component that will need to be scheduled via the job queue just like the prior spend calculation or top of wallet calculation. It should be run at the same cadence as the residential zip calculation.

The component itself is pretty straightforward. It needs to take in a set of attributes that we want to calculate values for, determine which tables the "hubs" for those attributes are stored in, and then calculate the attribute values by joining the zip table to the tables storing the hubs. The only real open question is whether we want to store different hub attributes on the same table or different tables (say United airlines wants attributes for their hubs). However, that's an easy question to push off because we only have one type of hub attribute that we're calculating as of now, and it is very easy to generalize later.

Mapping - Option 1

  • Treat this exactly the same as we treat the state attribute. These attribute values are calculated and persisted at the (Zip, time frame) level before the ResidentialZipCalculator is called. 
  • Inside the ResidentialZipCalculator, we join to the various tables storing these attribute values on residential zip. 
  • ResidentialZipCalculator will then persist those attributes along with residential zip and state as account date attributes

Pros

  • The mapping code does not need to be generalized to handle dependencies where we are joining to a new table based on the value of a derived attribute
  • There will be no performance implications for the mapping code

Cons

  • Space - these are persisted at the (account, time frame) level when that's not necessary
  • Residential Zip Calculator will need to be generalized slightly to find the row with the correct date

Mapping - Option 2

  • These attributes are calculated and persisted at the Residential Zip, Month level, before the Mapper is called.
  • The mapper will join the table(s) storing these attributes to the residential zip table (or to the transaction log that's already being augmented by residential zip)

Pros

  • These attributes won't need to be persisted twice
  • There will be no changes to the Residential Zip Calculator
  • We will likely need to generalize the mapper to handle dependency orders later in the code anyways

Cons

  • We will need to generalize the mapper, leading to more complex code before are tangible benefits for doing so

pageTitle: 2016-12-22 Dashboard Custom Time Frame Calc Concerns
content:
High level idea

Allow a user to update all cards on a dashboard with a custom time frame

Concerns

  • Many jobs will be kicked off at once by one user
    • The dashboard may be slower to refresh than we'd like
  • One custom time frame dashboard run may easily use up all resources (blocking other users from using smaller and faster drilldown functionality)

Solutions

  • Code
    • Implement per user job queue throttling 
      • not sure on timing, on the architecture team's backlog:  APT-93081 - Getting issue details... STATUS
      • We could talk to them about moving it up or implementing it ourselves
    • Wrap the calc job kicked off by drilldowns with a different job than the calc jobs kicked off by the dashboard
      • Give dashboard calc jobs a smaller throttling policy than the underlying calc job, so the dashboard run can never eat up all calc resources by itself. It will still slow down drilldowns set off by other users, but not be as much of a  show stopper.
      • cons 
        • if only a dashboard run is ongoing, we've artificially slowed it down (including our own pre-caching results for the dashboards with new data)
        • doesn't give drilldowns or other users complete priority, just some resources will always be left untouched for drilldowns to use
        • the web request will need to give us more information on the request (coming from the dashboard card or a drilldown card)
        • seems like a hack to avoid doing "per user job queue throttling"
    • solution c?
  • Do the feature, and allow for users to be blocked by other users' clicks
  • Don't do the feature

Problem

Each client database requires particular data setup via table inserts and view definitions. Some of this setup is one time (i.e. when a new client is acquired), some of it recurs (infrequently) over time. Below details the data that must be configured:

NameServerTables/Views

One

time

Client specificSet byInfo
attributesWebaid.attributes, aid.excludedAttributeCodes, aid.attributeDisplayConfig, aid.transactionAttributeMappingsFALSETRUEAIDSet by AID based on MCDI TransactionAttribute tables
bucketsWebaid.buckets, aid.bucketSets, aid.bucketSetMembersTRUETRUEClient team?Calculated by client team once
merchantsWebaid.clientAggregateMerchantsFALSETRUEAIDSet by AID based on MCDI TransactionAttribute tables
miscellaneousWebaid.fiscalCalendarTRUETRUEClient team?Set by client team once
transaction viewsWebattributeValues.intProductCodes, attributeValues.varcharCodes, attributeValues.datesAvailable, attributeValues.attributeMetadataFALSEFALSEAIDSet by AID based on MCDI TransactionAttribute tables. Defintion varies by environment.
benchmark weightsCalcaidCalc.benchmarkWeightsTRUETRUEClient team?Calculated by client team once
index factorsCalcaidCalc.indexFactorTRUETRUEClient team?Calculated by client team once
transaction viewsCalcattributeValues.attributeMetadata, attributeValues.transactionAttributes, attributeValues.spendAmountUsdByCountryByDayFALSEFALSEAIDSet by AID based on MCDI TransactionAttribute tables. Defintion varies by environment.

Some general issues include:

  • Recurring vs non
    • some of these will change over time while other won't
    • it is not totally clear at this point what that situation will be like over time with new clients
  • Client-specific vs non
    • the transaction views are not client-specific BUT can't simply be set up via DbUp because the database that the view points to differs between testing and production
    • one solution could include treating these differently from the standard data setup by doing these view creations in DbUp by environment somehow
  • AID generated values vs client team generated values
    • Some setup (e.g. attributes) will be what our team decides on and maintains
    • Some setup (e.g. buckets, benchmark weights) will be generated by client teams based on client data)

Options
