  1. Using unit tests as tools for generating scripts to be run against specific clients (current process - see here for details)

    1. Benefits
      1. No work right now
    2. Concerns
      1. Not scalable
      2. Complicated
      3. Easy to mess up

  2. Client specific DbUp and/or improved unit test tools

    1. Benefits
      1. Only some work now but not a ton
      2. Should make it easier to understand and not mess up for a next client
    2. Concerns
      1. Not scalable
      2. Still kind of complicated but less so than 1

  3. Data Import

    1. Benefits
      1. Client team / data team control
      2. Clean system
    2. Concerns
      1. Not clear if DI can connect to non-client databases (and this set up completely requires this)
      2. DI not intended for one-time setup - but rather recurring setup (e.g. weekly importing new data for a client)
      3. Not in platform yet - and will remain out of platform in KIRK even if that problem is solved out of KIRK, until SSO in in KIRK as well, since the platform integration depends on SSO support

  4. AID UI that supports uploading of CSV files

    1. Benefits
      1. Client team / data team / AID team control
      2. Clean and simple system 
    2. Concerns
      1. Most work for AID team
      2. This would not help with TransactionAttribute views - so that'd still need a separate solution

pageTitle: 2016-12-22 Persistent, Custom Dashboard and Drilldown Proposal
content:
Motivation

Modern web users expect stateful URLs that are shareable and permanent. Currently on production we do not have this functionality. In addition to stateful URLs we want the AID to have configurable dashboards for which we can pre-calculate results on an arbitrary cadence. Both of these feature involve storing which settings represent either a dashboard card or a drilldown state. Consequently, when implementing the stateful URLs we should follow a design that supports further development of custom dashboards and result pre-calculation.

Requirements

  • URLS must be representative of the state of the web app
    • When refreshed shared they must open to the same results as the initial page hit
      • now and in the future
  • The dashboard must be represented in the database of a client rather than in the javascript of the app
    • this will more easily allow per-client dashboards
  • We must be able to pre-calculate the results of the cards on the dashboard for the default timeFrame options
    • We must do this with a scheduled .NET job (not phantom JS)
  • This must lend its self to future user-customizable dashboards
  • Default dashboards can be configured on a client-by-client basis

Phases (what does each consist of)

Here we will outline what each phase of these features look like. We plan on immediately implementing Version 1. Version 2 is the end sate that we believe AID will reach over time. We are making design decisions now to make the transition from V1 to V2 as smooth as possible.

Current State - Production

The app does not track state in the URL

  • Refreshing puts the user on the homescreen regardless of where you are in the app
  • Clicking back goes to the splash page (smh).
  • The dashboard is (more or less) hardcoded into the app js

Version .5 - Master

The app tracks via the url what page of the dashboard you are on and which drill down you are in.

  • Clicking back (in the browser) will return you to the previous AID page you were on
  • Refreshing within the drilldown will return you to a drill-down with the settings of the card you originally drilled into.
  • Selected startDate and endDate are also tracked in the dashboard view
  • There is no tracking of changes you make with in a drill down
  • The dashboard is (more or less) hard-coded into the app js

Version 1

The app tracks your page and it's current state.

  • Any refresh or share on the dashboard will return you to the same dashboard with the same startDate and endDate
  • Any refresh or share on the drilldown will return you to the state with the last applied settings
    • Your current settings changes will not be saved until you click apply
    • Your chart settings will be saved (stacking, splitting)
    • Highcharts settings will not be saved (confirmed okay for V1 with Chris and Daniel)
  • All links are permanent and usable ad infinitum
  • The dashboard's configuration is represented in the database and independent per client 

Version 2

Everything in version 1 plus:

  • All dashboard cards are precalculated by a nightly scheduled .NET job
    • This job only needs to touch .NET code and the DBs  and does not to interact with the FE
  • Each user can customize his or her own dashboard in the product
  • PMs can add default dashboards, add cards to the dashboards, alter the cards in drilldown, save the cards to the default dashboard, position and resize the cards, all via an AID dashboard creator app
    (These features can be implemented in any order independently)

Design

React Router / URL management

Our single-page app uses front-end routing through the use of the HTML5 browser history API. All of our routes for home, dashboard, and drilldown go through the same controller method to the same HTML and JS bundle. It is then the responsibility of React Router to parse the URL and adjust the app appropriately so that it enters into the correct state on page load. As the user clicks on the different dashboards of the menu navigation, time frame selector on the dashboard, clicks into a card on the dashboard, and eventually applies settings in the drilldown, React Router alters the URL in the browser via the HTML5 history API accordingly, but does not issue a new request to the controller as it is not necessary. This leads to an extremely fast experience for the user and shareable/readable URLs.

Drilldown settings

The nice thing about using Redux on the front-end for state management is that, at all times, we have a snapshot of exactly what settings are applied and the current state the user is in. There is actually a specific property in our drilldown state, appliedSettings, which is an object that stores all the information (filters, breakouts, metric, series/group/stack indices, etc.) necessary to recreate the drilldown view exactly as it was before. This lends itself naturally to serializing this JSON object and storing that in the database as the way to repopulate an arbitrary selection of drilldown settings. Highchart's hiding and showing of series is not saved in our appliedSettings state.

Database Structure

Table NameColumnsComments
aid.dashboardConfig
  • CurrentDashboardSetId
kept current with new versions of the dashboardSets
aid.dashboardSets
  • DashboardSetId
  • DashboardId
  • OrderId (tracking left to right)

immutable, represents the dashboardSet's current dashboard setup across tabs of dashboards.

For Version 1 this will be consistent for all users.

aid.Dashboards
  • DashboardId
  • DashboardName

 
aid.DashboardCards
  • DashboardId
  • CardId
  • LayoutJson

Immutable - Once a dashboard is created it cannot be modified for backwards compatibility

LayoutJson is a serialized json string containing card layout information (x, y, width, height, etc.)

aid.Cards
  • CardId
  • JsonSettings (serialized)
  • AidWebSettings (serialized)
  • Version

Immutable

The JsonSettings are the pertinent sections of the app's redux state

The aidWebSettings are the results needed for this card

The version allows us to convert the aidWebSettings and JsonSettings to their current format on the fly

 

Settings Compatibility

Given that we are statifying settings and continuing to develop on the AID platform, backwards compatibility is a very valid concern. Instead of trying to write code that gracefully handles both old and new settings (a very difficult task) we can just write code that updates old settings to the current settings. The technique we will use to do this involves writing a set of updating functions that takes in one version of a type of settings and maps it to the next ( ie a function that maps from verison_x of the settings to version_x+1). We can continually write these simply update functions and successively apply them to old settings to always end up with settings in the most updated form. 

Every time we change the form of the settings object we write a function, f_x, that updates the current form to the new form to the new form ( of the xth form to the x+1th form).

 
\[ f_{x}(settings_{x}) = settings_{x+1} \]

Thus given the version of settings we have saved in the DB is version z and we the current version is version z+2 we can get the current settings by running

\[ f_{z+1}(f_{z}(settings_{z})) = settings_{z+2} \]

We can generalize this and apply it as need to always recover the current settings from an old version.

A very nice property of these conversion functions is that since they are incremental, they should be simple, susinct and easily testable.

Results Pre-running

To Pre-Calcuate results we leverage our existing .NET code (with a little refactoring). We will get the set of aidWebSettings for all cards that are in any of the userDashboards. (Join userDashboards → dashboards → dashboardCards → cards). We will get the current latest timeFrames using the LastPeriodProvider. We will run each of those websettings through web to generate AidSettings, run the aidSettings through results and to calc. 

How we support each use case

Version 1

  • Modifying/Creating dashboards
    • Go to the drilldown and create the output you would like on the dashboard
    • Use the drilldownId from the URL to look up the cardId in the db
    •  Add an entry to dashboardCards with that cardId and your desired X,Y, Height and Width properties

Version 2

  • Modifying/Creating cards and dashboards
    • There is a standalone single page app for creating dashboards and cards for those dashboards
    • PM can add new dashboards, name the dashboard, add cards to the dashboard, configure the cards via the drilldown
    • These changes are persisted into the data model defined above

Outstanding Questions /Decisions

Which path should we take?

Generalized: for potential Future Clients support

Data: Sanitized

Available Environment: Qwest (link from ApparelStagingAccess DB)  & Kirk

New data update cadence: Once every Month or two months 

 

ProCon

Looking forward to potential clients other than AA

might take a while to setup the DB. (Data sanitizaition etc.)
Testing in Qwest 
New data update cadence should be less frequent. So that we will have consistent baselines and will have to look into the new data change once every two months. 
One step closer to Dev. outside of Kirk 

AA Specific Plan

Data: Citi or Barclays?

Available Environment: Kirk

New data update cadence: Once every Month or two months 

 

ProCon
will be quick and easy to setupGeared towards AA
Easy to follow actual business trendWe already have AID_Citi & AID_Barclays setup
Baseline will actually make business sense

This is subject to change. It's just a rough sketch of data sizes that I think might be reasonable to work with. I think the runtime here would be kind of reasonable, but I'll verify that

Create Transaction Log to Use

  • Preliminary test transaction log size = 1 GB
    • Total transaction attribute size on gouda is 3 TB, which means we need ~ 1 out of every 3000 rows
      • In April, we have 36 million accounts
      • We also calculated 34 months of data
    • If we want 6 months of data, then we need at most 70,000 distinct accounts to stay under 1 GB (we'll do 60,000 to be safe)
  • Only prior spend attributes with 1 month lookback periods or smaller used 
  • Runtime analysis:
    • Say prior spend took 1 hour to calculate per week (overestimate), and we want to calculate prior spend for 6 months (36 weeks)
    • That would take 36 hours to run (not taking into account optimization that only the first week actually takes that long)
    • Each week will be looking through 1/600th of the data since that is the percentage of accounts we are looking at
    • This gives an estimated runtime of 36*60/600 = 3.6 minutes
    • This is a rough estimate, but it tries to be on the conservative side and gets a reasonable result.
  • Filtering the transaction log down to 6 months and 60,000 random accounts as the input to the test case seems reasonable.

Get TransactionAttributes_Testing up to date

  • Created bamboo job to deploy to TransactionAttributes_Testing on merge (gouda)
  • Ran DbUp successfully (after dropping / truncating all tables )
  • Ran database initializer
  • All tests still pass on master

Create Regression Test itself

  • TODO: DJT

pageTitle: 2016-12-13 Calculating a new week of data
content:
APT-106554 - Getting issue details... STATUS

Proposed steps for running a new week:

  • Update StringToIntCode Mappings
    • StringToIntCodeMapper.UpdateCodeMappings()
    • Should be called before running a new week of data so that transaction mapping for those attributes happens correctly without joins failing
  • Update metadata
    • TransactionAttributeOutput: Either drop tables and recreate using provisioner or do a diff and only add new codes/rows
    • Could make provisioner handle diff logic for metatdata tables
    • Ideally, the diff would update changed columns for existing rows, not just add new rows
    • Update codes tables on AID instances
      • Might need a new component for this
      • Or could run the provisioner on each of these databases
  • Update RunDates
    • Could be based off the TLOG dates available and the dates available of our calculated attributes.
    • Date snapping would be simpler with only weekly attributes, but should still be possible
  • Execute Run
    • AttributeMappingAutoRunner filters to incomplete runDates of the specified runId.
    • Implication: we need to make sure previous executions are complete before making another execution
  • Update statistics for on TransactionAttributeOutput
    • may not persist when transferring, but still may be useful for our own exploration
  • update GDV
    • just call update method
    • Statistics for GDV?
  • Copy Updates
    • SAN
    • BCP
    • Differential backup

Code changes:

  • Update provisioner to handle updating the metadata tables or make a new component to handle this.
  • Need some sort of data model to keep track of client databases so we can programmatically update metadata on those instances
  • Design a component (name suggestion: RunDateUpdater) to find which dates should be run and programatically update runDates tables for a specified run
  • Add a call to RunDateUpdater in TransactionAttributeMapperRunner
  • Update statistics updater to operate on specific partition
  • Call TransactionAttributeMapperRunner with the specified runId

Date

19 Dec 2016

Attendees

  • Nick Sidawy
  • Dustin Tiedemann
  • Adam Gallagher
  • Simon Krauss

Objective

We're currently working to automate the calculation of AID transaction attributes and want to discuss the two main options. This involves the process of augmenting the transaction log with attributes as well as running attributes we expect to be already calculated (e.g. prior spend, top of wallet, residential zip).

Option 1: Separate jobs for each of our calculations

This proposal would involve having completely separate jobs for each of our calculation processes. There would be a job for each of the attributes that require prior calculation (those would look at transactions.datesAvailable for missing dates to run) and a period mapper job (that would look at dbo.attributeResultsMetadata for available dates to map). The jobs would all run at a cadence and only do work if there was new data to process.

Example:

Dates available is updated from 12/25 → 1/7 (2 weeks) at 10AM

10AM:

  1. Top of wallet starts running month of Dec (12/01 → 12/31)
  2. Residential zips starts running month of Dec
  3. Prior spend starts running the last week in Dec (12/25 → 1/7)
  4. Period attribute mapper does nothing

11 AM:

  1. Top of wallet finishes, does not try to run Jan (data till 1/31 not available yet)
  2. Residential zips finishes, does not try to run Jan
  3. Prior spend still running first week
  4. Period attribute mapper still does nothing, waiting on all calculated attributes to be updated for a new week

12 PM:

  1. Prior spend finishes first week, starts second week
  2. Period attribute mapper sees it has new week of data for all attributes, kicks off mapping attributes for first week (12/25 → 1/31)

1 PM:

  1. Prior spend finishes second week
  2. Period attribute mapper does nothing because it needs residential zip/top of wallet attributes to be calculated for month of Jan before it can kick off next week

Option 2: One mapper job that kicks off dependencies on other calculations

This proposal would be the opposite and have on job depend on the completion of other jobs. The entry point would be the period attribute mapper job and that would be responsible for kicking off jobs to run the attributes that require prior calculation.

Example:

Dates available is updated from 12/25 → 1/7 (2 weeks)

  1. Period attribute mapper wants to run week of 12/25 → 12/31
    1. Kick off prior spend for this week
    2. Kick off top of wallet/residential zips for the month of Dec
    3. Once those finish, run period attribute mapping for this week
  2. Period attribute mapper wants to run week of 1/1 → 1/7
    1. Kick off period spend for this week
    2. Kick off top of wallet/residential zips for the month of January
    3. The top of wallet/residential zips jobs will fail because we don't have all the data needed to calculate the full month
    4. Period attribute mapping for this week will not run

Logging/Rerun Infrastructure

Whichever approach we take, we'll want an infrastructure in place that allows us to log what has run so that we can (1) see what has run in the past to fill in missing data, (2) see what is currently running so that we don't kick off duplicate work, (3) potentially give us a way to rerun things if we find a bug or need to restate data.

Running attributes that require prior calculation

I envision a table very similar to the one that the SiteMetricAutoRunner uses for logging prior spend/top of wallet/residential zip:

attributeIdattributeValueDaterunStartTimerunEndTimemarkForRerun

 

   

 

When each of these components runs, it will look at all the attributes/dates it should be calculating (we'll need to add a CalculationType column to attributeMetadata, and maybe even a CadenceType that designates if the attribute is run weekly or first of the month) and populate what is missing. Then it will run everything that has either never run before or was marked for rerun. This gives us flexibility for when data gets added for new dates or a new prior spend attribute is configured.

Running period attribute mapper

I think there are definitely some open questions around how this works for the period attribute mapper component itself, but currently our code assumes that we always run all attributes together (e.g. we don't have different attributes with different dates available, the mapped transaction log is the most conservative of all the prior spend/top of wallet/residential zip dates available).

If we hold to that, then this logging table is pretty simple, we only need a date dimension. This still presents some issues if we ever want to do something like add a prior spend attribute... The prior spend calculation would run fine, but then the mapper would need to remap everything, even though the we really only need to remap the new attribute - because the old output table would have a different schema. Currently, our code just fails, since the partition swap will fail - is it worth building functionality that would deal with this more robustly or is that such a low use case that we're find punting or manually fixing that if it comes up?

Thoughts/Open Questions

  • These were the two main options I could think of, not sure if there's other implementation paths that others can think of?
  • I personally like option 1 better, but that's only because I think it's simpler to manage when there's no dependencies.
  • If we follow through with getting the JobQueue like we've discussed, it will make implementation of option 2 much nicer with continuations.
  • Should we think about the use case of mapping a subset of attributes or adding a new attribute more? Our current infrastructure is very brittle in that we must always run all attributes and you can't really add a new one after mapping has occurred since the output table will have a specific schema.

Final Queries / Query Plans

TODO Dustin Tiedemann

Removing cast from varchar to int in the AID code

The biggest improvement made to the calculation query was to use int attributes rather than casting varchar attributes to strings. This process is very CPU intensive and dwarfed the amount of time it actually took to read in attributes from the transaction attributes table. Before this cast was removed, queries using one of these attributes took up to an hour to calculate a month of data. Afterwords, the time for a month of data went down to around 10 minutes for a month.

 

Moving the filter set case statement to a join

The next step was to remove an expensive case statement to calculate the filter sets and turn it to a hash join. Even after making the change above, the query was heavily CPU bottlenecked. Removing this case statement got the query down to around 20 seconds for a month of data

After making this change, the query plan looks like this which is much more reasonable (filterSetIdAttributeMappings is the table we're joining to). Here we can see that I/O is expected to be the most expensive part of the query

Removing the concept of nullability in a filter set

One thing that we discovered that's worth discussing is that it's very important to make sure the join from the transaction log table is on equality. For instance, in one implementation, we introduced the concept of a null attribute filter which meant that the attribute was ignored for the filter, resulting in a query that looks something along the lines of

SELECT a.*, f.*
FROM TransactionAttributes.attributeValues.TransactionAttributes a
JOIN dbo.filterSetsTable f
	ON (a.attribute_1 = f.attribute_1 OR f.attribute_1 IS NULL)
	AND (a.attribute_2 = f.attribute_2 OR f.attribute_2 IS NULL)

This lead to a nested loop joins (because you can't do a hash join when there is an OR clause) which resulted in a bad plan.

Breaking up the benchmark query into 2 separate queries

Problem

For benchmark results (cards that are non-American Airlines Citi/Barclays cards) we need to calculate a couple of things that aren't necessary in the American Airlines case.

1) Results split out by aggregateMerchantId - for data usage

2) Results split out by issuer - for data usage

3) weighted account count - at the total level (not broken out by issuer or aggregateMerchantId)

 

All of these were calculated in the same query using ROLLUP and GROUPING SETS. This lead to a rather complex query where we would roll up the transaction log to each of the 3 levels above. Ideally, this would save us from needing to read from the transaction log multiple times. However, it lead to query plans that could have a very expensive table spool (on the transaction log) and it lead to actually reading through the transaction log multiple times when there wasn't a table spool.

Improvements

We split this query into 2 queries. The first query calculates data usage results and groups by (aggregateMerchantId, issuerId). It doesn't need to calculate weighted account count, so it can just sum sales from that intermediate result.

The second query can avoid the intermediate group by and aggregate the results straight to the total level and calculate weighted account count correctly

Splitting out query for multiple time slices into multiple queries

The initial structure was to calculate values for all time slices in 1 query. We would calculate data for a full range (say one year of data) and then join to a time slices table to get those results broken out by month. The data was never being aggregated over a full year.

Time slices are non-overlapping. Because of this and the fact that results are calculated per time slice, each time slice accesses a separate section of the transaction log. So these queries can be easily split up into 1 query per time slice and the same amount of work will be done. There's no duplication when reading the data or calculating partial results.

The advantages of splitting these up is to

  • Avoid an unnecessary join to the time slice table (requiring minimal CPU but row estimates could be affected)
  • Splitting the query into smaller queries will reduce the amount of spilling that could occur in the case of a poor row estimate and may eliminate spilling in certain cases

Running these queries in SSMS gave us the results we expected: the separate time slices queries are better, but it doesn't reduce the query time by orders of magnitude or anything.

 Query for 1 year12 queries for 1 month
Data Usage10 s6 s
Benchmark1 min 22 s1 min 2 s
Non-benchmark1 min 39 s1 min 13 s

Benchmarking/Competitor Set Restriction

This query is a subquery (actually it appears twice, once for investors and once for brands) in larger data usage query. That query's performance was actually OK. With high contention on the database it took about 40 seconds but runs of the query with no contention ranged between 1 and 1.5 seconds. Still, the query itself had an over-complicated query plan which increased the likelihood that contention could impact run time significantly.

*I am not sure I've seen all three JOIN types used consecutively like this!

Two changes were made to address this:

  1. The table that contains the data that is being benchmarked in this query is actually being referenced from a view with some fitlers and aggregations on it. This leads to the somewhat complicated and memory intensive middle two branches we see in the query (note the third branch is cut off in the image but it looks the same as the second).
    To improve this, rather than reference the view directly, we cache the data in the view into a table and give it a clustered index that will make determining the share of spend per row as fast as possible. This simplifies the above query plan section (see branch 2 & 3):
  2. Originally, all the competitor restriction definitions were stored on tables in the database. The query would run a CROSS JOIN against these tables to check if each row passed ANY of the data restrictions and then run a GROUP BY to find if at least one of them had passed. SQL did a fairly good job coming up with as reasonable as a plan as possible for this but again the concern was how complicated the query can be. In particular you can note the need for two additional JOINs and all the operators after the 3 JOINs are complete.
    To improve this, the query was restructured to no longer pull the definitions from tables and instead hard code the different checks in the query itself. This significantly simplified the query:

    That's the whole thing now!

Overall the run-times before and after the changes are actually fairly similar (about 1-1.5 seconds) but its worth noting that the new version is running as a single threaded serial plan mean while the original ran in parallel with 22 threads.

pageTitle: 2016-12-05 Steps for transitioning to latest MCDI TransactionAttributes database
content:
General steps

ALTER underlying views for TransactionAttributes

  1. Web (Marsh)

    1. attributeValues.attributeMetadata

      ALTER VIEW attributeValues.attributeMetadata
AS
SELECT * FROM attributeValues.attributeMetadata
    2. attributeValues.intAttributeCodes
    3. attributeValues.varcharAttributeCodes
    4. attributeValues.datesAvailable
  2. Calc (Titan)
    1. attributeValues.attributeMetadata
    2. attributeValues.attributeValues
  3. Use SetUpTransactionAttributeViews.linq (in C:\dev\platform\aid\scripts) to generate these view definitions and then run on the specified servers

Verify proper transaction attribute mappings

    1. Mapping from AID data model to Mastercard TransactionAttribute data model (MCDI)

      • On Web database (MARSH)
      • aid.transactionAttributeMappings
-- view the AID attributes (from aid.attributes) and their mappings to the actual transaction attributes
SELECT
	att.attributeId AS aidAttributeId,
	md.attributeId AS transactionAttributeId,
	att.name AS aidName,
	md.name, AS name
FROM aid.attributes att
	LEFT JOIN aid.transactionAttributeMappings m
	ON att.attributeId = m.aidAttributeId
	LEFT JOIN attributeValues.attributeMetadata md
	ON m.mastercardTransactionAttributeId = md.attributeId
 
-- change the VARCHAR coded attributes we consume to instead use the INT coded versions now
-- IF the IDs change, then run the updates below, OTHERWISE, we just want to confirm that the types are INT codes now
-- product code (AID attributeId = 2; MCDI attributeId = 508 for ProductGroupId)
UPDATE aid.transactionAttributeMappings
SET transactionAttributeId = X
WHERE aidAttributeId = 2
   
-- industry (AID attributeId = 17; MCDI attributeId = 701)
UPDATE aid.transactionAttributeMappings
SET transactionAttributeId = Y
WHERE aidAttributeId = 17

Update log

  • 12/6/2016 - Nick Sidawy and Ryan Allen
    • All scripts referenced by the following bullets are in aid\TransactionAttributesSetup_2016_12_06\
    • Created new database on Marsh named TransactionAttributes_20161206
      • Ran the "generate scripts" task on Titan.TransactionAttributes_20161206 
        • Select all table objects other than the GDV table and attribute values table
        • Generate both Schmea and Data
        • The script is located here in the AID repo: ProvisionAttributeMetaDataOnMarsh.sql
      • Run the generated script on Marsh.TransactionAttributes_20161206
    • Updated the VIEWs on AID_Dev databases (TITAN and MARSH) based on the steps above to point to TransactionAttributes_20161206
      • Script stored for future use in AID repo: TransactionAttributes_20161206_UpdateScript.sql (in C:\dev\platform\aid\scripts)
      • Script for generating VIEW update scripts added datesAvailable (in C:\dev\platform\aid\scripts)
    • Changed ProductGroup attribute to point to new INT-coded attributes which previously were unavailable
      • AidAttributeId - 2
      • MastercardTransactionAttributeId - 703
    • Added new AID attribute: "Arline Industry Parent Aggregate Merchant Id" (804)
        • Citi - has isDrilldownOption set to FALSE
        • Barclay - has isDrilldownOption set to TRUE

pageTitle: 2016-11-18 Converting Coded String Attributes To Int Design Discussion
content:
Problem

The AID team would like each coded string attribute to be mapped to an int so that filter sets can always work with coded int attributes. Currently, an attribute like industry shows up as a string which presents complications in filtering because there needs to be branching logic when applying/rendering different filter types.

Proposed Changes 

We need to create a new type of attribute that renders this transform when mapping attributes. This data model will only support the conversion of strings → int and not any other potentially coded attributes (bit, date) and will need to be able to store 2 things:

  1. How to map each string value for that attribute to an int.
  2. Where to look when checking if we need to create new mappings since this is the first time we're seeing that string value.

dbo.convertedStringToIntAttributes

attributeIdbaseAttributeIdstringToIntMappingTablestringSourceSchemastringSourceTablestringSourceColumn
800 (coded industry, INT)500 (industry, VARCHAR)dbo.industryCodeMappingmerchantsaggregateMerchants industry


The first part of the data model (attributeId, baseAttributeId, stringToIntMappingTable, attributeColumn, baseAttributeColumn) allows us to associate the base string attribute to the new int attribute via a mapping table and the industryCodeMapping table in this example would allow us to dynamically generate a CASE statement to map this new attribute when augmenting the transaction log. It would look something like this and would need to be updated every time we map attributes.

industryCodeindustry
1ABC
2DEF
3GHI

The second part of the data model (stringSourceTable, stringSourceColumn) allows us to detect when we get a new string that has not been mapped to an int. In this case, before any mapping occurs, we would select the distinct values of industry on merchants.aggregateMerchants and if any are missing from industryCodeMapping, we would need to insert a new row.

The challenging piece here is how we create this transform for entries we currently have and new industries in the future, so that we always maintain a unique and historically accurate mapping.

I see two options here:

  • We hash the industry string so that every code gets a unique int. Each time we see a new industry string, we insert into this table with the hashed value.
  • We create this table with industryCode as an identity. Each time we see a new industry string, we simply insert to get a new industryCode.

We would never update any existing mappings, so that attributes mapped in the past remain accurate, and before running the transaction attribute mapper, we would need to update each of these mapping tables for any new strings we're missing.

Result

For the industry example above, the modified transaction attribute flow would look as follows:

  1. Since we're calculating attribute 800, we need to make sure the mapping from industry → industryCode is populated for all industries.
  2. If not, we insert new rows into this mapping table.
  3. We would calculate all attributes, and the mapper would know how to render the CASE statement so we get attribute 800 along with 500.

The AID team would then get a finalized transaction log that would contain both attribute 800 and 500, the int and string versions of the INDUSTRY attribute. This extends to any other string attributes they would want translated to ints, but also offers the flexibility to not provide this translation for other consumers if it's not needed (they would just request attribute 500, but not 800).

Index Factor / Normalization

Decision: use total AAdvantage portfolio spend in Jan 2015, scaled to be a decimal between 1 and 10. Multiply the attributes by index factor.

---

Right now there is a table (aidCalc.indexFactor) that contains the index factor (what all indexed metrics are divided by). What this value should be and how we go about normalizing the indexed values are TBD.

Some thoughts thrown around so far:

  • use "total AAdvantage portfolio spend in 2015" as the index factor (this needs to be calculated and stored)
  • consider multiplying by the constant instead of dividing to avoid losing precision, while requiring that indexFactor is an INT
  • be careful of overflow (we're using MONEY type). 0-1000 was recommended by Alex Franz in a pull request
  • does this value need to be different for different clients?

Coding Details

  • Indexed metrics for AA only and benchmark. Non indexed metrics only for AA.
  • Adding 3 more columns to the results that are always returned: IndexedSpend, IndexedTransactionCount, IndexedNumberOfAccounts
  • Details for the main updates are below. More stuff will break, tests and db scripts will need to be updated as well.

Results

Assuming Calc sends along the appropriate metrics, Results has to calculate absolute derived metrics (i.e. spend per account, basket size, etc). These calculations should now be done using indexed metrics. Most updates here involve including the 3 new indexed columns wherever the three existing metric columns are used.

FileDetails
Metric.csadd the three indexed metrics to MetricEnum
MetricResultService.csuse indexed metrics when calculating derived metric results
MetricResultCacheUpdatorinclude indexed metrics when updating metric results

Data Usage

The non-indexed metrics should continue to be used for non-benchmark case. In this case, all 6 columns are passed through, but the data usage checks are performed on the non-indexed metrics since the index factor could skew the values and cause a false passage of data usage. In the benchmark case, only the indexed metric columns should be passed through, but the data usage checks should still be on non-indexed metrics.

FileDetails
DataUsageValidationRunner.csupdate the GetSupportedMetricColumns function to take a boolean containsOnlyClientAccounts - if true, pass through all 6 columns, otherwise pass only the additional indexed supported columns
DataUsageOutput.csadd the three indexed columns
TBDupdate cell size check that is used for indexed metrics

Note: we're going to get indexed metrics working fully before considering how to handle the new cell size chekc.

Calc

Calc has to be sure that the indexed metrics are calculated and the proper index factor is applied to the numerators/denominators used in the calculations. 

FileDetails
MetricResultAggregator.cs
  • in GetAggregatedResultsGroupingSets, include an indexFactor to use in updated subqueries which will figure out the 3 indexed metrics
  • the index factor will be either be from memory or database where it is heavily cached since it will rarely be changing
  • open question: what will this index factor be? Total AAdvantage portfolio spend in 2015 was proposed by Chris in the confluence page from our last meeting. The same factor will be used for all metrics.

Overview

This component is responsible for taking the individual attributes that we calculated values for, joining them to the transaction log and combining them into one or more tables storing transaction attributes.  The different attributes that we want to store could come from attributes that the MCDI team calculated (prior spend, residential zip, top of wallet), attributes on the transaction log (accountId, transactionChannel) or by joining to other tables (state, product line, issuer).

Create attributes metadata table to retrieve results

On DbUp, we will create a table to store this metadata and then populate the table from the existing definitions on the calculation database. We will also create the partition schemes and partition functions needed.

Results - v1

We will store a single columnstore table that contains all transaction attributes for AID. The table will be partitioned by date. As the number of transaction attributes increase, we will need to revisit this and split transaction attributes into multiple tables.

Calculation Overview - Data Model

Attribute Retrieval Data Model

AttributeIdTransactionAttributeDatabaseNameTransactionAttributeDatabaseSchemaTransactionAttributeDatabaseTableTransactionAttributeDatabaseColumnIsDeprecated

 

Note: examples here may be stale. Look at AID Derived Data Elements for the actual transaction attributes (everything that's high priority should be included in version 1)

These tables need to exist on the TransactionAttributes calculation database and will be used to populate the results table and metadata table

Attribute Types:

  • Account/Date Attribute: 
    • Examples:
      • Top of Wallet 
      • Prior Spend / Transaction Count / Basket Size
        • Also restricted to within a particular industry / aggregate merchant
      • Residential Zip

    • Metadata needed:

      AttributeId

      		AttributeValueDateMinDateMaxDateAccountIdColumnAccountDatabaseNameAccountSchemaNameAccountTableName
  • Values that can be calculated from direct joins to the transaction log / Transaction Log Column

    • We will create a view that joins the transaction log to the appropriate tables that will be referenced in the calculation code

     

Calculation 

1) Create a new result table that will store all the transaction attributes. It will be columnstore and will be partitioned by date.

2) Loop over each date, determine which attributes need to be calculated and which have attributes in the old table

  • Deprecated attributes and new attributes need to be recalculated

3) If no data exists

  • Get transaction log (select appropriate columns) filtered to a single week
  • Join to tables specified by attribute type 2 (attributes that are provided and can be calculated by simply joining to the T-log)
  • Join to the appropriate tables for account/date attributes

4) If data exists

  • Get existing transaction attribute data for a single week
  • Join to tables specified by attribute type 2 (attributes that are provided and can be calculated by simply joining to the T-log)
  • Join to the appropriate tables for account/date attributes

5) Partition swap the new data into the existing table

6) After all dates are finished calculating, update the metadata so that the attributes point to the correct table

7) Drop the old table

Creating Statistics

We will want to run statistics on every column of every partition. This is likely going to be the most expensive part of the calculation, so we'll want to parallelize that when we can and run incremental statistics

Getting the data to AID

  • When calculating a new set of metrics (or deprecating old ones), we will provision and populate a new database with the new metrics and then move that database to AID's instance
  • When calculating a new week of data, we will insert new rows into the existing table and then run statistics on that new partition

Parallelizing calculation

We will want to run this calculation across multiple threads to make it complete faster. In order to do that we'll create the concept of a run which encapsulates the process of calculating attribute values. In some instances, that run simply

Operations to be supported

Calculating historical values for all time

The easiest way to approach this is to calculate these values one day at a time and partition swap that single table into the larger table. This allows us to easily track the progress of the query, and more importantly, ensure that if the calculation fails at some point, we don't lose all data.

So this problem is essentially the same as adding new attribute values for a date range.

Adding new attributes

In this case, we will calculate historical data for the new attributes. We then create a new table to store all of the attribute values (new and old). We then join the table(s) containing the new data with the table containing the old data and then update the old values

Adding new attribute values for a new date range (as data is loaded)

Explained in the calculation step above.

Adding new attribute values for a new date range for a subset of attributes (Suggestion: don't support)

This would be a minor optimization that would allow consumers to use values for attributes that have been calculated while other values are being calculated. This does not seem like a major concern given how fast calculating a new week of data is for all of these attributes. I don't think we should worry about this case until we have a real need.

Deprecating data

Fortunately with the columnstore table, deprecating data can simply be a metadata operation on the transaction attribute definitions table. We can keep the transaction attributes table as is and only read attributes for attributes that are not deprecated. When we recalculate those values, we will simply calculate new values for the attributes that are deprecated, and combine them with the old values for non-deprecated values.

Calculation Options:

  • Stored Procedures (not going to pursue)
    • Pros
      • Very easy to deploy to the database we want to run and we can kick off calculations in SSMS
    • Cons
      • Writing any tests for this is going to be somewhat annoying
      • Developing is going to be very annoying
      • Significant effort to convert it to C#
  • CLR via Data Import
    • Pros
      • Development isn't substantially different from using standard APT libraries
      • Given Adam's changes, setting up the project and deploying should be pretty straightforward
      • Data Import gives us an easy way to kick off runs
    • Cons
      • Will need to do some work to set up Data Import
      • Will need to do some work to convert it to use APT standard libraries in an app right, but should be easy
  • Call C# from unit tests
    • Pros
      • Almost no overhead setting up processes to deploy and run calculations
      • Will be coding in C#, so will result in the least amount of throwaway code
    • Cons
      • It's easy to accidentally kick off calculations that you don't want to run
      • It's easy to kick off calculations from the wrong branch
      • It's difficult to know when we kicked these off
      • Going to be annoying to deploy code for unit tests for 6 months if 
  • Call C# from web API (not going to pursue)
    • Pros:
      • Will have the same infrastructure and code as the real solution
    • Cons:
      • Will be the most work to set up deployment / calculations
      • We don't have a good upper bound on how long it'll take to set up deployment / calculations

Takeaways: I don't think options 1 or 4 are feasible. 4 is simply too much overhead. There isn't much incremental work from 1 to 2,3 and stored procedure development is so painful that we'll lose a lot of efficiency developing them anyways. I can see moving forward with 2 or 3 and would be very interested in getting your opinions.

Calculating different types of attributes

A lot of this depends on what attributes we are calculating and what approach we go with.

Assuming that we are going with the unit test approach and no transaction attributes are dependent on other transaction attributes, one simple outline would be 

  • Create a simplified data model for the AID attributes. It'll be a subset of what's necessary here: 2016-10-05 Transaction Attribute Calculation Engine Discussion
    • I imagine that we'll need the derivedDataCalc.dataElements table and the specific configuration tables for each attribute
    • We will likely also need information about what dates were calculated and the various debugging information needed (commit, date calculation kicked off)
  • In the unit tests themselves, we define the attributes that we actually want to calculate using the data model and also what dates we want to run
  • There will be a TransactionAttributeCalculationProcessor class that will break that date range up into discrete calculation units and kicks off those calculations
  • Each transaction attribute type can determine how to calculate and store attribute values for a set of attributes (batching them if necessary)
  • We can try and parallelize the transaction attribute calculation within the TransactionAttributeCalculationProcessor where we kick off jobs for however many calculation units we want
    • This might make it tricky to debug and maybe isn't something we need for v1
    • We could also accomplish this by opening up separate instances of VS and kick off multiple attributes in different unit tests (not a great solution)

Getting transaction attribute data to daisy

Options:

  • Snapshot replication
  • BCP files over

The BCP solution likely works pretty well for the calculating all of history for the December deadline. It becomes more tedious once we need to do this on a recurring basis. Given that snapshot replication is easy to set up, I don't see a downside with going with snapshot replication from the beginning.

Getting AA accounts into marsh

Snapshot replication seems appropriate for this as well.

pageTitle: 2016-10-19 Calculating prior spend as an account-week attribute
content:
Date

19 Oct 2016

Attendees

  • Pan Wang

  • Nick Sidawy

  • Dustin Tiedemann
  • Adam Gallagher
  • Simon Krauss

Data model

These current attributes need to be calculated for the initial delivery:

  • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size
  • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size at AA
  • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size in T+ E Airline industry
  • Count of industries transacted in

With different look back periods, by priority, of:

  • 90
  • 365
  • 30
  • 180
  • 7

Thinking about this generally, I think we need a data model that can define for each attribute:

  1. What set of locations we need to be considering - prior spend unrestricted cares about all locations, prior spend in AA only cares about locations where aggregate merchant = AA. 
  2. What the look back period is.
  3. How we should be aggregating to get the attribute - prior spend would be SUM(sales), prior transactionCount would be SUM(transactionCount), count of industries transacted in would be COUNT(DISTINCT industryCode).

A basic data model proposal:

dbo.priorSpendAttributes

attributeIdlocationFilterSetIdlookbackPeriodDaysaggregationString
Prior spend in last 30 daysnull30SUM(sales)
Prior transaction count in AA in last 60 days160SUM(transactionCount)
Prior spend in T + E Airline Industry in last 30 days230SUM(sales)
Count of industries transacted in the last 60 daysnull60COUNT(DISTINCT industryCode)

I'm not a big fan of the raw sql aggregation string here and I think we can come up with a better way to represent that, but I think this table captures all 3 points above. There will be additional parts of the data model (shown below) that capture how we're filtering to different set of locations, but this table presents all the information we need to calculate a given attribute.

 

dbo.priorSpendLocationFilterSets

locationFilterSetIdlocationFilterIdlocationFilterType
111
222

dbo.locationFilterTypes

locationFilterTypelocationFilterName
1Filter by aggregate merchant
2Filter by industry

dbo.aggregateMerchantLocationFilters

locationFilterIdaggregateMerchantId
13001 (AA)

dbo.industryLocationFilters

locationFilterIdindustryCode
23 (T + E Airlines)

Initial implementation ideas

Calculating multiple prior spend metrics together

We want to be calculating prior spend attributes together to minimize hitting the transaction log (e.g. prior spend in a particular industry code uses a subset of transactions needed for prior spend overall). To that effect, we should be able to take a similar approach to our site level metric calculations where we annotate each row of financials with which prior spend metric it applies and then aggregate over specific columns.

Ex.

Let's calculate prior spend overall (id = 1), prior transaction count in industry = "Airline" (id = 3), prior spend in transaction channel = "Online" (id = 9) together.

If we were working with daily account financials we could annotate the financials like follows:

accountIddatelocationIdindustrytransactionChannelsalestransactionCountinPriorSpend1inPriorSpend3inPriorSpend9
12016-01-011AirlineSwiped3501110
22016-01-012RestaurantSwiped501100
32016-01-013ApparelOnline402101
12016-01-022AirlineOnline4501111
22016-01-024RestaurantSwiped601100
32016-01-025EntertainmentOnline202101

In this situation, we can easily aggregate across all 3 of these different prior spend attributes using the same set of financials. Whether or not we actually want to write these columns or rely on a case statement to do this logic when rolling up remains to be seen, but I think this approach scales out pretty well. 

Calculating dates by looking at prior dates calculated

We don't want to always be pulling the look back period of financials for a prior spend attribute when we can be smarter about how we use attributes in the past.

Ex.

Let's say we want to calculate prior spend in the last 30 days for date A , but have a prior spend attribute value for date B already.

In this situation, we could calculate prior spend in last 30 days at A by extracting the last 30 days and summing that. Or, we could see that we already have a prior spend at B which was 3 days ago and back out prior spend at A by removing the purple chunk and adding in the green chunk. I think this approach makes a ton of sense for attributes with long look backs if we're calculating these account attributes weekly.

The flow in our calculation code could look something like this:

  1. If this is the earliest date we have an attribute value for, we just extract the entire look back period and sum up.
  2. If we want to calculate date A, but have a previous attribute at date B:
    1. We sum up the green section for all accounts
    2. We add the attribute value calculated at date B
    3. We subtract the purple section for these accounts that had an attribute at date B.

This allows us to extract a much smaller time range and also limit the set of accounts when calculating date A (green section will be all accounts, but purple section will only be accounts that had attribute at date B).

This page is deprecated. Please see AID Transaction Attributes API & Data Model for the official documentation. 

Motivation

Once we have transaction attributes, a key component of the design of the overall system is how to access them. Since this work involves coordination between MCDI and AID to ensure that requirements are feasible and deadlines are met, it is imperative that a consensus is reached early in the design process.

Design Proposal

Data Model

The data model should be expressive enough to service basic data exploration as well as provide information which can be used to construct queries against the actual transaction attributes. For example, given that the underlying attributes will likely be distributed in multiple tables (see 2016-09-14 Transaction Attributes Brainstorming for more details), there will need to be one or more lookup tables which map attributes to their location. In addition, these lookup tables can store information about each attribute's data type (e.g., int, bit, etc.) as well as classification (e.g., prior spend, distance to store, account status, etc.).

As AID already has ownership of frontend-related attribute metadata for masks, symbols, etc., MCDI's primary role is to provide calc-related metadata and actual values of attributes.

As such, the main attribute metadata table will be maintained by MCDI and will be defined as follows:

attributeIdnamedataTypeIdattributeTypeIdisCodedisOrdinaldataSchemadataTabledataColumnjoinColumn
1Prior Spend (365 days)3101attributesattr_spendpriorSpend365accountId
2Account Active Date2201attributesattr_accountaccountActiveDateaccountId
3Account Close Date2201attributesattr_accountaccountCloseDateaccountId
4IsAmerican1310attributesattr_accountisAmericanaccountId
5Restaurant Segments4310attributesattr_accountrestaurantSegmentaccountId
6Latitude3401attributesattr_locationslatitudelocationId
7Longitude3401attributesattr_locationslongitudelocationId

In addition, there will be tables for code definitions (if applicable). For example,

attributeIdcodeSchemacodeTablecodeNameColumncodeIdColumn
4attributeCodesisAmericannamecode
5attributeCodesrestaurantSegmentsnamecode

The columns in these tables are described below:

columnIddataTypedescription
attributeIdintPK for attributes
namevarchartext description of attributes
dataTypeIdintmaps each attribute to its storage type in SQL (e.g., bit, int, float, money, etc.)
attributeTypeIdintmaps each attribute to its classification (e.g., prior spend, account info, etc.)
isCodedinttrue if the attribute is segmented, false if continuous
codeSchemavarcharschema containing code definition
codeTablevarchartable containing code definition
codeNameColumnvarcharname of column in code table for the name of the code
codeIdColumnvarcharname of column in code table for the id of the code
dataSchemavarcharschema containing underlying attribute data
dataTablevarchartable containing underlying attribute data
dataColumnvarcharname of column in table containing underlying attribute data

Note: The columns relating to codes will be relevant to only a subset of the attributes. To avoid having a large number of NULL values in this table, it may be desirable to store these columns in separate tables mapped by attributeId.

This model will also require tables for describing data types, attribute types, and code/splitType definitions.

For example, attributes.restaurantSegments might contain:

codename
1QSR
2Fast Casual
3Casual
4Polished Casual
5Fine Dining
6Unknown

Note: As codes are used by both the calc code and the web frontend, they will have to be consistent between the MCDI calc database and the AID web database. To accommodate this, we can create a view on the AID database to point to the MCDI code table and make sure that codes don't change over time. This way, MCDI can deploy to a single database while AID can automatically benefit from updates.

Example API

Using the tables above, the provider engine should be able to build and structure queries on the fly given a set of specified inputs (e.g., a list of attributes). It will return ITables or raw SQL subqueries which can be used within larger queries defined by AID. In an effort to maintain flexibility and generality, the engine will not be responsible for filtering or aggregating the data (which will be under the domain of AID), but the data model should provide all the information necessary to perform such operations.

Below is a brief proposal of the core class and method signature:

// Returns the handle / query for the specified transaction attributes
// Since we don't know the exact schema of the subquery, we return an ITableWithDescriptor
// The table will always provide accountId, locationId, transactionDate, spendAmount, and the value of the specified attribute,
// which can be named according to an agreed-upon convention, e.g., attributeValue_XXX
public AttributeValueResult GetAttributeValues(ICollection<int> attributeIds)
 
// high-level attribute class containing columns in attributes table above
public class Attribute {
	public int AttributeId { get; set; }
	public string Name { get; set; }
	...
}

// class containing raw values and metadata about attribute data type, etc.
public class AttributeValueResult {
	public AttributeMetadata Metadata { get; set; }
	public ITableWithDescriptor TableDescriptor { get; set; }
}

Access Provider Approaches

Since AID is likely to be the main consumer of this data for the foreseeable near future, it makes sense to choose an approach that will provide the least friction to the development process at this early stage. Unless there are major objections, this initial recommendation is to code directly in a new project in the AID solution. Once the API has solidified and there are more consumers in the picture, it will make sense to extract the library into a form more conducive to being used by multiple consumers.

Below is a longer discussion of the pros and cons of various methods of providing access to the transaction attributes.

1. Coded directly in AID solution

In this appoach, the MCDI team could work directly with the AID team by writing the access code directly in the AID solution. This would allow for rapid development without worrying about versioning or deployment, which would be a productivity boost initially while the API may still be shifting significantly.

If the end goal is to provide this accessing logic to consumers besides AID, eventually the logic would likely need to be extracted out into one of the solutions described below.

2. C# Library

An isolated C# library would include a set of data types for the attribute metadata as well as a set of methods for constructing and executing queries involving different types of attributes. The library would need to provide some way of handling configuration for the access layer, such as the database connection string, etc.

This approach would be simple and lightweight, but it does suffer complications involved with handling updates and multiple versions (as the AID team would need to update their dependency on this library in order to take advantage of each new published version). While this versioned structure may also be considered an asset, in the early stages of development while the API may be shifting, the updating process may involve extra unnecessary friction.

3. Web API

In this approach, the underlying subqueries would be returned via a web call rather than through a C# method call.

Using a web API would simplify the deployment process somewhat, because non-breaking backwards-compatible API changes could be made without explicitly notifying all consumers of the API. However, any major breaking changes would need to cause a version bump, and to handle this gracefully, multiple versions of the API would need to be served. At this early stage in development, while AID is the only consumer of this API, this concern likely wouldn't be much of an issue, but in the long run, it would be necessary to consider the infrastructure necessary to support multiple served versions.

An additional factor affecting the feasibility of this solution is the extra work required to serve and consume the content over HTTP. Both the provider (MCDI) and the consumer (AID) would need to maintain forms of this code, which seems unnecessary as long as there are no restrictions on the access of the underlying databases. On the other hand, if in the future a compelling need to restrict consumers from having read access to the database containing attribute and attribute calc metadata, a web API would be a way of providing the query building service while protecting the underlying data model.

4. Web API + C# Library

This approach is the same as (3), but it includes a C# library for calling the web API so that API clients using C# don't need to directly make web calls. This shifts the burden of writing the HTTP-consuming code to MCDI, and versions of the API and the consuming code would need to be kept in sync.

Closed Questions

*These are no longer relevant, as AID has ownership of all the aggregation and web-related display.

  1. Input on alternative provider solutions
  2. Will AID need any other attribute metadata to make queries?
  3. How does AID plan on doing bucketing for continuous attributes? Is it on the fly? Do they need that information in the data model from us?
  4. Will we need to support multiple types of aggregations per attribute, or will each have at most one? Is this something that needs to be expressed in the data model?
  5. Which attributes will be coded, and how will the codes be defined?
  6. Is more attribute metadata (besides those already included) required for frontend display?

Open Questions / Next steps

  1. Solidify codes table between AID and MCDI
  2. Will we need to update the codes table with some ETL process?
  3. Also want to include aggregate merchant, location, isBenchmark, industry

Goals

We want to design a calculation engine that will be able to support calculating many types of derived data elements off the Mastercard data in an scalable and automated fashion.

Initial thoughts

In thinking about this calculation engine, our design needs to be robust to a few things:

  • Data elements can be calculated at different times and for different dates.

    Ex 1. We get Mastercard transaction data for 2 more weeks, so we need to calculate prior client spend attributes for the new time frame but may not want to calculate residential zips because we're fine falling back on the one from last month.
    Ex 2. We have calculated all transaction attributes for history, but then decide to add a new prior client spend attribute that needs to be calculated.

  • Calculations will have different sets of dependencies and we need a data model that can enumerate those.

    Ex 1. The calculation of a prior client spend attribute doesn't depend on anything but the transaction log.
    Ex 2. The calculation of a distance to store attribute depends on both the transaction log as well as the residential zips derived data set.
  • Data elements may be calculated using inputs from different snapshots in time and we need to know when calculation of one data element necessitates the recalculation of another.

    Ex. We calculate distance to store attributes for February using the residential zips from January, since we didn't have the most up to date residential zips at that time and we're fine using ones from a month ago. We get around to calculating residential zips for February eventually and once those finish, we most likely want to rerun these distance to store attributes with updated residential zips. 
  • Results for different dates should be easy to mark as out of date and rerun.

    The site level metrics auto runner is an example of a design we'd want to avoid because we find dates to run by looking at the last date we have metrics calculated for and check if there is new data to run. This makes it incredibly difficult to mark a subset of dates for recalculation, in cases when we find a bug in our code or the distance to store example above where some data is persisted but we want to update that data to rerun with a more recent snapshot of one of its dependencies. We need our design to be flexible to us designating different time frames to be calculated.
  • Results will be continually being updated, so we need some versioning concept.

    This is something that probably warrants a more detailed discussion, but we want to know when different data elements were calculated and what state their dependencies were in when used for calculations. 

SQL data model proposal

With the above points in mind, I think an initial data model has to involve a few tables:

  • derivedDataCalc.dataElements

    This table will store each derived data set to be run as well as metadata around how these data elements will be calculated.

    dataElementIddataElementTypename
    12Prior Client Sales Transaction Attribute (4 n-tiles, last 30 days)
    22Prior Client Sales Transaction Attribute (4 n-tiles, last 365 days)
    35Distance To Store Transaction Attribute (5 n-tiles)
    45Distance To Store Transaction Attribute (4 n-tiles)
    56Residential Zip
    67Restaurant Buyer Segments
    71Industry Segment Transaction Attribute

    For things like residential zips or restaurant buyer segments, there isn't any additional metadata we need. But for attributes that represent our current split types, we'd have metadata similar to what is currently stored in our split type definitions tables.

  • derivedDataCalc.dataElementCalculatedDates

    This table will store the dates we have calculated for each data element. At some cadence, the calculation engine will go through each data element and check what dates should we have run, what dates we have results for, and run the time frame that is missing. This should give us the flexibility to calculate data elements at different cadences and for different time frames.

    dataElementIddatedateRun
    22016-02-012016-10-01
    22016-02-022016-10-01
    ...  
    42016-02-012016-10-01
    42016-02-022016-10-01
    ...  
    62016-01-012016-09-01

    Ex 1. We have calculated results for prior client spend up until January. When dates available gets updated through February, the calculation engine will see we should have data until then but only have data until January. We'll then kick off a job to calculate attribute values for each date from January on.

    Ex 2. We have data elements calculated for all history but realize there was an issue in our transaction log process for dates between 2016-01-01 and 2016-02-01. This means we need to restate the transaction log which causes us to have to recalculate all attribute values in this time. We can just delete from this table where date is between these two dates, and the next time the calculation engine runs, it will know it needs to calculate this time period because it should have data for every date in dates available.

    Ex 3. We calculated results for distance to store for February using the residential zips from January, since that was the most recent snapshot we had at the time of calculation. We get around to calculating residential zips for February eventually and once those finish, we want to recalculate attribute values for February with the updated residential zip snapshot. We can delete dates in this table for that data element from the start of February on so that the next time our calculation engine runs, we rerun distance to store for these dates

     

  • derivedDataCalc.dataElementDependencies

    This table will store specific dependencies between calculation of other data elements, so that a calculation depends on another derived data element, we know to rerun that calculation when that data gets updated.

    dataElementIddependentDataElementId
    35 (distance to store attributes depend on monthly residential zips)
    76 (industry segment attributes depend on monthly customer segments)

    For the last example in the above bullet, this table would allow us to programatically determine that when we update residential zips, we also need to rerun distance to store. That way we know which data element to delete rows for in the table that stores calculated dates.

This model does adopt more of a passive approach to calculating data elements. As in, if we need to calculate A that depends on B for a certain time frame, we don't run B and then run A. We run A by taking the most recent version of B that has been calculated and using that. Then, when we calculate more updated data for B, we recalculate A. For all the data elements we're enumerating so far, that model does fine (e.g. we're fine providing attribute values without the most recent residential zips or restaurant buyer segments), but definitely open to more discussion on that assumption. The alternative approach here would be a more active system that allows for a top down then bottom up dependency (e.g. running distance to store actually kicks off a job that runs residential zips for the time frame with a continuation job that calculates distance to store, if we already have the most up to date residential zips that job will do nothing and just kick off the continuation for the actual logic). I think we can accomplish this with the job queue infrastructure, but having our calculation engine check if we need to run new data at a cadence achieves much of that capability with less overhead.

API design

I'm not assuming we have the job queue at our disposal here but either way, I could see us using a job-like instrastructure where each "job" knows how to calculate a specific class of derived data elements (e.g. client prior spend, distance to store) . Each "job", whether that's an actual job in the job queue or a clr stored procedure that runs some sql, would implement a common interface or an abstract class that would help us determine what dates to run, the logic to actually calculate the data elements, and dependencies we need to kick off.

Here's some psuedocode for our residential zip/distance to store calculations:

public class DistanceToStoreAttributeCalculator {
 
    public Dictionary<int, List<StartEndDates>> GetDatesToCalculate() {
		var datesToRun = new Dictionary<int, List<StartEndDates>>(); // maps each distance to store data element to list of dates we need to run
		
		var distanceToStoreDataElements = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<int>(@"SELECT dataElementId FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElements WHERE dataElementType = 2").ToList();
        var datesAvailable = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<StartEndDates>(@"SELECT minDate, maxDate FROM transactions.datesAvailable");
		var datesExpected = // enumerate dates between min/max date in dates available
		foreach(int dataElementId in distanceToStoreDataElements ) {
            var datesCalculated = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<int>(@"SELECT date FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElementCalculatedDates WHERE dataElementId = @dataElementId").ToList();
			var datesMissing = // difference between datesExpected and datesCalculated , chunked up into time periods
            datesToRun[dataElementId] = datesMissing;
        }		
		return datesToRun;
	}
 
    public void CalculateAttributes() {
		// calculate distance to store data elements with some batching by dates/look back period
    }
 
	public void UpdateDatesForDependencies(int dataElementId, DateTime refreshStartDate, DateTime refreshEndDate) {
    	// do nothing because no other calculations depend on distance to store
    }
}
 
public class ResidentialZipCalculator {

    public Dictionary<int, List<StartEndDates>> GetDatesToCalculate() {
		var datesToRun = new Dictionary<int, List<StartEndDates>>(); // maps each distance to store data element to list of dates we need to run
 
		var residentialZipDataElement = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<int>(@"SELECT dataElementId FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElements WHERE dataElementType = 6").Single();
		var datesAvailable = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<StartEndDates>(@"SELECT minDate, maxDate FROM transactions.datesAvailable");
		var datesExpected = // enumerate dates between min/max date in dates available, only pulling first of the month dates because we run residential zips monthly
        var datesCalculated = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<int>(@"SELECT date FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElementCalculatedDates WHERE dataElementId = @residentialZipDataElement").ToList();
		var datesMissing = // difference between datesExpected and datesCalculated as end dates, start dates would be 3 months back from each end date because we run residential zips in 3 month chunks
        datesToRun[dataElementId] = datesMissing;

        return datesToRun;
	}

    public void CalculateAttributes() {
    	// calculate residential zips data element
    }

	public void UpdateDatesForDependencies(int dataElementId, DateTime refreshStartDate, DateTime refreshEndDate) {
        // need to update distance to store dependency so it will rerun next time - the generic way to do this below
        var dependencies = this.aptQuery.ReadLite<int>(@"SELECT dataElementId FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElementDependencies WHERE dependentDataElementId = @dataElementId").ToList();
        this.aptQuery.WriteLite("
        	DELETE FROM derivedDataCalc.dataElementCalculatedDates
			WHERE dataElementId IN (@dependenciesDelimitedString) 
      			AND date >= @refreshStartDate
        ");
    }
}

Open questions

This is a first pass and I know we're going build and refine this design, but just wanted to call out some things that I don't have good answers to and would like to think about more:

  • We still haven't discussed how batching of calculations will work. I've kind of hinted in my code above that we could batch calculation of all distance to store attributes together according to some heuristic, but why not batch prior client spend and distance to store? They would both involve the same set of transactions if we were updating attributes with the same look back period.
  • We still don't have a good plan for making sure the exact same "job" isn't kick off multiple times:
    • We taken the passive approach here, so we'll never get into a situation where two data elements depend on residential zip so traversing the tree means we kick off residential zips twice.
    • We still run into issues with our passive approach if we check for new data to calculate once a day - if the calculation of a data element takes longer than day, we would kick off that job again even though it is already running the next day.
  • How do we keep track of ongoing calculations? 
    • I think the job queue would go a long way into addressing this, but even with that functionality we probably want some logging table that tell us what data element is running and for what dates.
    • That could help us sort out the issue above with kicking off duplicated work.
  • Where do these results go after they're calculated?
    • I was focused mostly on the data model for calculating results, but I could see us doing a couple of things here.
    • My initial thought is to just write all newly calculated attributes to a user table and then swap them in at the earliest convenience. That way, current processes won't be blocked if we're recalculating an attribute but then versioning becomes more important for us to know if downstream consumers want to rerun calculations.

Notes from 10/12 meeting

  • The dependency for a calculation will be a particular data element as well as a date range or heuristic for getting a set of dates that need to be populated for this dependency.
    • Ex 1. Distance to store in the last 364 days would depend on the transaction log being populated for the last 364 days as well as residential zips for the last month.
    • Ex 2. Client prior spend in the last 364 days would depend on the transaction log being populated for the last 364 days while client prior spend in the last 30 days would require a much smaller history to be populated.
    • This would mean that a certain data element would not be calculated unless all dependencies have had data populated for their necessary dates.
    • This has flexibility in terms of data quality and available.
    • This probably means that a data element is defined by its dependencies, so you could have a distance to store metric that uses any residential zip calculated in the last 3 months and another distance to store metric with the same look back/tiling that has to be calculated with a residential zip in the last month.
  • There needs to be some versioning in place so that we can (1) know how different data elements and their dependencies were calculated, and (2) reproduce the data elements a consumer is seeing at any point, even if they've been refreshed. 
    • Every time a data element is calculated, we will record to a table with what was calculated, when, which sessionId to refer to in our logs,  and the specific commit hash that was used to run the calculation.
    • Every time a data element is calculated, we will also store those fields for each data element it has a dependency on.
  • We can signal when a data element is being run by a nullable dateStarted field. If this is null, then it's not running and we can kick off new data.
  • Things left to discuss:
    • Batching different calculations together
      • Ex 1. Run all distance to store attributes together.
      • Ex 2. Run distance to store and prior client spend together if the look back period is same.
    • Web app for job queue and exception handling much preferable to stored procedures
    • Accessing these attributes will probably go through some library.

Goal

Replicate as closely as possible the AID use case for transaction attributes and determine the performance, and storage implications of our transaction attribute structure.

AID use case

  • Server: daisy, will be one of our most powerful servers with 6 TB of RAM, we'll likely want to run this on a server without much load to get a baseline comparison

  • Query: 

    AID query
    SELECT MIN(ta.date) AS date, 'M' AS frequency, ta.attribute_X_code AS filterSet, SUM(ta.sales) AS spend, SUM(ta.transactionCount) AS transactionCount, SUM(ta.accountCount) AS accountCount
FROM ( 
	-- turn numeric attribute values into coded attribute values
	SELECT 
		ta.date,
		CASE WHEN ta.attribute_X_value < 10.0 THEN 1 
		ELSE WHEN ta.attribute_X_value < 20.0 THEN 2
		ELSE WHEN ta.attribute_X_value < 30.0 THEN 3
		ELSE WHEN ta.attribute_X_value < 40.0 THEN 4
		ELSE 5 END as attribute_X_code,
		ta.sales
	FROM transactionAttributes ta
	JOIN fiscalCalendar fc
		ON ta.date = fc.date
	WHERE ta.date >= '2014-01-01' AND ta.date < '2015-01-01'
) ta
GROUP BY fc.fiscalYear, fc.fiscalMonth, ta.attribute_X_code
  • Number of attributes: In the fullness of time,  AID will want hundreds of attributes

Test Cases
