We'll use 1/10th of the transaction log for a full year's worth of data.  We will have the following test cases:

Generating attribute data

Current Suggestion:

  • Calculate real transaction attributes for:
    • Prior spend, transaction count, basket size in past 30 days
    • Prior spend, transaction count, basket size in client, past 30 days
  • Create new sales/basket size transaction attributes in the following way
    • Find some value X where 5<= X <= 50
    • For each row, change attribute value by Y% where  -X<=Y<=X (each row will be perturbed differently)
  • Create new transaction count attributes by taking existing transaction attributes
    • changing the value to be something between minTransactionCount and maxTransactionCount (randomly chosen for each row, possibly weighted by frequency)

Because space is a concern, we want the compression of the transaction attribute table to be representative of the compression that we're actually going to get when running this on production.  This means that the data needs to be similar to the data that we're using on production.  Calculating a few real transaction attributes and then randomly perturbing the data for the other attributes will accomplish this while still being fast enough that we're not calculating 50 transaction attributes.

Open questions

  • Is it possible to use SQL Server 2016? 
    • Probably not necessary.  batch mode execution is available for some operations in 2014, we can move the database to 2016 and test it if necessary
  • How fast is "fast enough"?
    • Less than a minute?
  • Should we use SAN replication?
    • It shouldn't have a drastic impact, but yes, we are using it
  • Are we storing numeric or coded values?
    • From a space concern, numeric seems much better but AID will likely bucket those attributes into code.  It seems like the best approach here is to store numeric values and bucket them in the test query

Results

In order to test how the amount of space scales based on the number of transaction attributes, we ran two test cases which generated a full month of fake transaction attribute values. The first test case generated 2 transaction attributes and the second test case generated 10 transaction attributes

  • Test Case 1 (2 transaction attributes):
    • Size of a particular row: 61 bytes
    • Size of transaction attribute table: 70 GB
  • Test Case 2 (10 transaction attributes):
    • Size of a particular row: 117 bytes
    • Size of transaction attribute table: 128GB

Based on the size of a particular row on the table we would expect the first data set to be roughly (61/117) = 52.1% of the size.

The actual table is (70/128) = 54.7% of the size.

This shows that while we get a slightly smaller table than we would expect when we increase the number of attributes, using the size of the schema is a reasonable bound for the amount of space we'll need.

Motivation

One important component to the transaction attribute infrastructure will be the system of scheduling when to run calculations for a particular attribute. Calculations for some attributes may need to be re-run as often as new Mastercard data is received, while calculations for other attributes, due to their length or the slow-changing nature of the underlying metric, may be less frequent.

Given the large number of transaction attributes needing to be calculated, it will be helpful to have a coherent, unified system of determining the cadence at which each attribute should be calculated based on new data or deprecations of old metrics. Below we discuss some of the high-level goals of this system and begin fleshing out what the system could look like and what implications the scheduling system will have on the data model and calculation design.

Goals

What properties would an ideal scheduling system have? It's difficult to answer this question without making assumptions about the underlying infrastructure, but there are a number of specific properties that would be helpful. Note that not all of these may be required or present in the final system, but these are a starting point for thinking through some of the decisions surrounding the design of such a system:

  • Idempotence: Regardless of the details of the scheduling mechanism, the underlying data model and calculation structure should ideally be able to support multiple runs with the same data inputs without breaking or creating duplicate output rows. If we don't have this property, then we may waste calculation time and key collisions in data tables could become a concern (if we use intermediate storage prior to mapping attributes to a transaction).
  • History-agnosticism: Calculations should not need to rely on having successful previous runs. There are two main situations in which successful previous runs will not be present: 1) on the initial run of a given derived data attribute and 2) after the failure of a previous calculation. Fundamentally, these two situations aren't that different, and they may be handled in essentially the same way by the calculation.
  • Cadence-preserving*: If the fundamental cadence of a calculation is set to a given frequency, this should not be disrupted by failures. For example, if we want to calculate resiZips on the last day of every month, but a given run fails and it has to be rerun on the following day, the data should ideally still be calculated from the end of the previous month rather than the date the calculation is run. In other words, it may be worth decoupling the date the calculation is run from the dates the derived data elements are based on.
  • Cadence-flexible*: If we make a decision to change the cadence of a given calculation, this should ideally be feasible without requiring major changes in data model or calc code.

*These properties are only important if we persist some intermediate output prior to mapping attributes to transactions. It's something of an open question whether this will be the case or not, but for resiZips and customer segments, which don't change frequently and have utility apart from transactions, it may make sense to persist the customer-date attributes in addition to the transaction attributes.

With these properties in view, a number of more specific questions come to mind about the scheduling system:

  • Should each calculation know when to run, or should it be told to run by a higher-level component?
  • Should the logic for determining if a given calculation needs to be run be centralized or distributed?
  • How do we keep track of when each calculation has been run and what its status is?

Proposal

Fully delving into the details of the calculation code engine is outside of the scope of this page, but below we focus on the questions specific to the scheduling and status persistence and outline a proposed system of structuring calculations to preserve as many of the ideal properties as possible. The solution below is something of a hybrid between a top-down and a bottom-up approach in that it allows for independence in the definition and initialization of each type of calculation while pushing logic for determining what needs to be run outside of each calculation's code. A similar approach is already in use in the Restaurant Buyer Segments feature, and it would be relatively simple to expand this approach to handle other attributes requiring to be calculated.

Most recent data

Mastercard.Transactions.DatesAvailable contains dates of available Mastercard data, so this table can be one input to calculations in terms of determining bounds on which to run.

Run tables

Run tables are a simple but effective way of tracking when each calculation is run and logging its status. This information can be used subsequently in determining when to next run the calculation and what calculations need to be filled in because of missing or deprecated data. One important call-out is that when using this approach, we need to maintain one-to-one correspondence between the run table and the calculation output; i.e., ensure that a new row gets inserted after a successful run and also have logic in place for missing rows. If this gets out of sync, it could be very problematic.

Frequency Configuration

A run table alone would be sufficient for calculations run on a daily basis, but for other frequencies, logic must be put in place for how often to run the calculation. If the range of frequencies and timetables is few, one can imagine simply defining different types of frequencies (e.g., monthly, bimonthly, weekly, etc.) and defining logic for each frequency. A more sophisticated solution would be to generate a calendar of expected run dates for each calculation. Regardless, the general logic is to determine which dates are expected to be run, compute the difference between the expected dates and the existing dates, and then run the calculation for the given set of dates, or skip the calculation entirely if it is initialized but there is nothing to do.

Summary

The main benefit of this approach is that it is configuration-oriented, so adjusting the behavior of a type of calculation is simply a matter of updating a few database fields. One can imagine alternative approaches which hard-code this logic into each individual calculation, but this would quickly become unwieldy. Another advantage of this approach is that it should be straightforward to add and schedule new metrics and back-populate results of new calculations as they are integrated. In addition, this solution preserves the idempotency and history-agnosticism properties, and makes cadence easy to reason about and configure. By extracting the logic of "when should this calculation be run?" out of each metric's calc code and centralizing this logic as much as possible, it will be easier to manage the scheduling and configuration of each calculation.

Initial Ideas

Things to note

  • Based on the current list of attributes here , we can reasonably expect there to be 100+ attributes that we will need to store
    • If all we stored were these values + unique identifiers for rows, then we would easily have several times more uncompressed data than the full version of the TLog
  • Retrieving attribute values should be relatively fast
    • However, ultimately AID is not the only use case for these attribute values so that speed in their context is not our only measuring stick
  • We will be calculating new values on a regular cadence (e.g. once a week) as new TLog data becomes available
    • We will need to be able to quickly insert these new values into our data set
  • The list of attributes will grow over time. Our calculations will need to be able to calculate individual attributes for all history

Attribute Value Storage

Product transaction attribute storage and what we can learn

As long as we are dealing in the realm of SQL Server we don't have a lot of options here. In fact we might be tempted to follow the model of the product which has the following characteristics:

  • One table with three columns:
    • Attribute ID
    • Transaction ID
    • Value
  • Partitioned on Attribute ID

However there are a few problems with this structure that we want to specifically avoid:

  • A lot of storage is wasted on repeated use of the same value
    • We have the same transaction ID value stored for each attribute we have; needless to say the same is true for the attribute ID
    • One could easily imagine pivoting this table so that we had a column per attribute value rather than a row per attribute value and we would save a tremendous amount space
  • Since the table is partitioned only on attribute ID, we get no benefits of partition swapping when a new set of transactions and their values are loaded into the DB
    • The only real benefit to the partitioning scheme is loading or restating entire sets of an attribute's values
  • There is no date column on this table meaning there is not a easy way to restrict the row set that we want to query outside of partition elimination on attribute ID

Idea #1

Trx IDDate (Partitioned)Attribute1...AttributeN
12015/1/14 4
22015/1/23 5
  • Store attributes values in a pivoted table with a column per attribute
  • In addition to a transaction identifier column, we will include a date column for both query and data load performance
  • The table will use a clustered column store index. Since consumers of the table will only need to query a small subset of attributes at a time, we want to avoid reading in the entire (very wide) row. By using clustered column store index we should be able to only read in columns we are interested in for a given query.

To support this table we will need a data model that will tell a user where they can find the values for a particular attribute e.g. what column holds the value; think financial data sources. 

Additionally, we may need several of these tables. As we add new attributes to the set, adding columns to existing tables will likely be a prohibitively expensive operation. 

Include columns from the TLog?

For AID a very common use-case will be asking for the amount sales broken out by a transaction attribute value e.g. what are the total sales in January 2015 broken out by prior spend at grocery stores in the last year. With the current structure we will be required to pull the relevent transactions from the TLog and join this set to the attribute value table.

We could consider just copying columns of interest from the TLOG to the attribute table as well:

Trx IDDate (Partitioned)LocationId...SpendAmountUsdAttribute1...AttributeN
12015/1/11 $45.234 4
22015/1/21 $9.253 5

Open question: What would be the columns we'd want to include on the tables in this fashion?

Open question: Would things like "transaction channel" become attribute values in this view? If we had multiple attribute tables would we want it represented on each or is one table enough? Would we define a core set of attributes that would be on each table?

What about customer-date attributes?

Most attributes we would want to calculate are actually customer-date attributes, not transaction attributes. For example, Prior Spend in the last 365 days for an account is totally independent of any transaction committed on a particular day. In fact, if that customer has multiple transactions on that day, then we will be storing this value repeatedly with the table proposed above.

In practice, this actually isn't too bad. Accounts use commit transactions less than 2 times per day1 on average so the additional data volume is not significantly more.

However, there are definitely some attributes that we don't even need daily values for like residential zip and buyer segment. We could easily get away with having monthly values for these. 

Open question: Should attributes that we only need to calculate periodically for customers be stored in a separate place as transaction attributes? Should we store them as both transaction and customer-date attributes?

1 I queried the TLog for the month of March, 2016 and September, 2015 and calcualted the number of distinct acount dates pairs over number of transactions and got 0.621 and 0.615, respectively.

WIP

 

The purpose of stand-up is to keep the team up-to-date with the status of different issues and to identify and potentially resolve roadblocks impeding progress.

This is accomplished by each team member answering the following 3 key questions

  • What progress has been made since the last stand-up?
  • What will you be working on until the next stand-up?
  • What obstacles are preventing you from doing your job?

We will be testing out having two different kinds of stand-up one moving person-by-person and the other issue-by-issue. The goal of having these two types is to eventually take the person-by-person stand-up async (via email/confluence) and to have a less frequent issue-by-issue stand up to ensure our progress is aligned with our sprint goals. The format of these meetings and do's and dont's are described below.

Agenda

This will be run by Jackson Hamburger and he will delegate to a willing team member if he is planning to be absent. Realistically, anyone can run this meeting and we will quickly reach a point where it does not matter.

  • Person-by-Person days
    • Iterate through team members 
      • Each individual answers the 3 key questions
      • If roadblocks are identified, briefly discuss steps to resolve
      • These next steps will likely be either catching up with other team members offline or reaching out to another APTer
    • Check the status of the Story of Bugs
      • Assign/discuss priority of new bugs
  • Story-by-Story days
    • Iterate through the stories on the board
      • Team members answer the 3 questions on a story-by-story basis
      • If roadblocks are identified, briefly discuss steps to resolve
      • These next steps will likely be either catching up with other team members offline or reaching out to another APTer
    • We iterate individuals to possibly add misc updates like upcoming WFH, review writing, vacation etc

Do's

  • Answer the key 3 questions
    • Think about if you were emailing an update what you would say
  • Have a time goal of 10 minutes with a maximum time of 15 minutes
      • Pace accordingly
    • Yes, this implies that each person should speak for less than 2 minutes
  • Have one person from each office call in early by ~2 minutes
    • Jackson Hamburger in NYC
    • John Reagan in DC 
    • These people are responsible for finding someone else in their absence
    • There's no need to waste ~5 minutes of 10 team members' time waiting around to get connected
  • Before stand-up review your tasks for 1-2 minutes
    • know what you are going to say
  • Book Gauss and Use Life-size
    • This is substantially easier and requires a single call for NYC 
    • The back up plan is Alex's or Chris's webex

Don't's

  • Introduce new ideas
    • This is not a planning meeting or a design/best practice discussion
    • If you want to introduce a new idea (probably related to an identified roadblock), let the team know that you will be reaching out to explain it to them
      • follow up by doing via email, confluence or scheduling a meeting with the the key stakeholders 
  • Show up late
    • Stand-up should take about 10 minutes, showing up 2 minutes late is the equivalent to showing up 12 minutes late to an hour meeting
  • Use your computer or phone
    • Other than to check your calendar or notes
    • Pay attention

To tackle the technical debt that the AID team accrues, we employ a Kanban board to monitor the state of all of our technical debt.

Issue Priority

Issues are assigned priorities on a scale of low, medium high. These priorities are not intended to compare with feature stories but are intended to compare technical debt tasks.

Please tackle the highest priority technical debt available first.

Managing Tasks

We monitor the technical debt board on a consistent basis at each sprint planning to ensure that our technical debt has appropriate priority and to pull tasks into our next sprint.

When working on a technical debt task, be sure to scan the Tech Debt board to find other related or duplicate stories whose statuses should be updated. 

 

Continuous Tech Debt Awareness

There are some types of technical debt that build up continously over time (and already exist in the codebase).These are things like not employing best practices, weak commenting and poor testing duplication of logic.

To help keep this to a minimum we need to be vigilant on PRs but also we need to constantly be removing technical debt that we find (or know exists) in the code.

Please acquaint yourself with the status of our Tech Debt board so that when you are working on a particular part of the code that we know we want to refactor/update you are able to make that change while in context. If for instance, we know the HomeModelProvider has limited testing coverage and you are making changes to that file, it is your responsibility to add unit tests. Additionally on PRs reviewers should also be commenting if they believe we can tackle a tech debt task in conjunction with a PR.

Kanban Board

Link : go/aidTechDebt

This board will be essential to tracking AID's outstanding, in progress and completed technical debt.

We view this board at tasking and sprint planning meetings.

Key Info

  • To be visible each task needs the AID component or a label of 'aidweb', 'aidcalc', 'aidresults' or 'aidDU'
  • The labels associated with each swimlane are as follows
    • Design = 'design'
    • Testing = 'testing'
    • Documentation = 'documentation'
    • Tooling = 'tooling'
  • Please set the priority of the issue
  • Please add the appropriate aidweb, aidresults, aiddu and aidcalc labels
    • if it spans apps add both

This document establishes best practices to allow JIRA to best represent the state of development, code review, and testing of features.  It also specifies our process of handling bugs and support issues to most accurately reflect the work we plan to address within a sprint.

Tracking story development on a feature branch

Feature Development Progress

The state of stories and sub-tasks should represent their place in the development process.  The meaning of these statuses should apply to both the overall story as well as individual subtasks:

StateMeaningNotes
Not Ready / OpenThe story or task is not yet in development. 
In ProgressThe story or task is being actively developed. 
Awaiting ReviewThe developer is iterating on review feedback but is not yet ready to be tested. 
Awaiting TestIt is appropriate for the QA team to begin branch testing."Awaiting Review" is not synonymous with the existence of a Pull Request; Tasks and stories should be moved to "Awaiting Test" to indicate that we anticipate minimal further review comments or necessary changes, even if the review may be awaiting approval from some individuals.
DoneBranch testing is complete and can be merged into master at any point. 

We've been discussing whether it is appropriate to move all sub-tasks through "Awaiting Review" and "Awaiting Test".  While some discretion should probably be taken by the developer (e.g. it may not be necessary to move specific sub-tasks like "Add a new enum type" to "Awaiting Test"), when in doubt we'd like to provide the QA team with more information rather than less.  The QA team will frequently review tasks in "Awaiting Test", moving those which are not as relevant to the testing process to "Done".

Testing Story

The QA team will utilize a "Testing" story to ensure there are tasks for each feature/story that requires testing.  The tasks in this story will enable the QA team to track progress of stories beyond the development of a branch (including integration testing in master and release).

The mappings below aren't completely intuitive, but work pretty well if you think of the task as the testing and release of a story:

StateMeaningNotes
Not ReadyThe story or feature is in development but not ready to be tested 
OpenReady to be tested / Prioritized to be Tested first 
In ProgressThe story or feature is being actively tested.

As soon as a task moves to this state, the QA should schedule a testing discussion with the respective engineer.

For branch development this means that the feature is being functionally tested on the branch. 

This is also where the QA team estimates the release branch with which the feature will deploy to Qwest. (See screenshot explanation on how to read a test task below)

Awaiting ReviewThe main story or feature test execution is complete but could still have bug fixes (blocked) & integration testing on master leftBug fixes should be feature branch tested prior to merging to master.
Awaiting TestThe story or feature has been tested on master (Kirk or !Kirk) and is ready to be part of the next AID release to Qwest Staging.

Quick check on staging will be done with the next deployment.

DoneThe story or feature is ready to be deployed to production. 

 

How to read Testing Task naming format:

Knowing how to read testing tasks in the testing story helps better estimate when the feature is expected to release as well as knowing what testing method was used to test the feature. (eg. Toggle, QA branch, Local branch)  

 

 

Enhancement Triage

UX and PM team members should look at the BI/PI Enhancement section of AID triage (go/aidtriage) regularly to triage enhancement requests as they come in

The current process and prioritization logic is as follows:

  1. "Accept" the issue to remove from the issue from the triage board
  2. Look at priority of enhancement request to baseline priority based on filer's assessment (feel free to adjust as necessary)

  3. Assign labels and epic fields to each enhancement:

    1. Common Labels:
      • Newhire – tasks that are relatively smaller in magnitude, easy to pick up w/out a ton of context
      • Dashboards – anything related to dashboard functionality
      • Wording – labels, attribute naming, metric names
      • Visualdesign – e.g. changing colors on a data visualization
      • Visualization – anything related to the display of the output on dashboard or drilldown
    2. Epic fields will commonly remain UI/UX as that is a common theme for enhancements, but if it relates to a more specific epic, replace with that epic instead

  4. Triage based on original priority and any additional context you may have:

    1. If high priority, add to the placeholder future sprint of the appropriate team (PI or BI) on the backlog
    2. Otherwise, delineate roughly between things we want to do soon vs things we want to keep documented on the backlog
      • “top of backlog” – requirements ready, should pull in to an upcoming sprint
      • “rest of backlog” – we want documented, but not sure we want to start requirements

Other changes

Story of bugs

The "Story of Bugs" will be deprecated as this makes issues difficult to track.  Instead, bugs and support issues are treated as follows:

Feature bugs

If bugs come up during feature development and branch testing they will be filed under the corresponding story.

Production, support, and master integration bugs

Other bugs and support issues that are part of existing features (anything that has moved beyond "active development") that the team intends to take on during a sprint will be added ad-hoc to the sprint as tasks and will appear on the bottom of the JIRA rapid board.  To facilitate this process:

  • We will create a triage board to identify bugs which have not been triaged (go/aidtriage).
  • Each day we will triage new bugs and support issues.
    • We need to decide or experiment on timing; for example, this could be prior to standup each day.
  • Issues which we do not intend on handling in the current sprint should be moved to the backlog.
  • Issues which we do intend on handling in the current sprint should be added to the sprint.
    • Issues should be assigned a single story point to represent the change in sprint-scope and "chaos" introduced.  If an issue is likely to require more effort we should assign an appropriate value and consider impact on the sprint, possibly moving other work out of the scope of the current sprint as a result.

Labels

After feature branch testing and any bug fixes are done, the branch can be merged to master. Whoever merges this branch is also expected to add the 'merged' label to the respective story. This will help to automate the release notes for each deployment.

Anytime a Pull Request is "merged" the person merging that work should expect to label at least one story or task.

My open issues

@Everyone should go to http://jira/issues/?filter=-1 and make sure that the issues assigned to them are actually things they are working on. Close/unassign others as necessary

The purpose of this page is to discuss a high level design for how we implement the logic for the AID transaction attributes.

Runner

Goals

  • We want to have one pace of logic handle calling calculation code
    • It will determine what dates need to be run and what an appropriate batch is for an attribute type
    • It will NOT be responsible for updating any run or results table
      • If it did then it would be difficult to call calculation code directly as it would not update the appropriate tables
  • Dependencies will be ignored for now except for the dependency on the Transaction log
  • Each calculation class should implement interfaces which will:
    • Provide a way to determine what calculations have been run
    • Provide an entry point for the calculations

Example

public class TransactionAttributeCalcuationRunner
{
	// The assertion here is that attributes wihtin a type can calculated in batch.
	// That is true at the moment but could change so maybe we want to have an additional
	// layer of abstraction for attributeCalculationGroups that for now will be equivalent
	// to grouping by attribute type. 
	public void Calculate(AttributeType attributeType /*e.g. Prior spend, Top of Wallet*/) 
	{
		// get all attributes associated with the type
		var attributes = this.GetAttributesFromType(attributeType);
		// we will want a handle on something that will tell the runner what has been calculated for an attribute type
		var calculationResultProvider = this.GetCalculationResultProviderForAttributeType(attributeType);
		var datesAvailable = this.GetTransactionLogDatesAvailable();
		// get the list of attribute-dates that we have calculated for the type
		var calculatedAttributeDates = calculationResultProvider.GetCalculatedAttributeDates();
		// get the frequency for the attribute calculation, is it per transaction, per account-day, per-account month?
		// how expressive should this be? Can we get away which just an enum for now?
		var attributeTypeCalcualtionFrequency = calculationResultProvider.GetCalculationFrequency();
		
		// figure out what dates need to be calculated
		// we pass in the attributes to because we basically want to LEFT JOIN to the 
		// calculatedAttributeDates to make sure we catch attributes that have not been calcualted at all
		var datesToCalculate = this.GetDatesToCalculate(
			attributes,
			attributeTypeCalcualtionFrequency,
			calculatedAttributeDates,
			datesAvailable);
		
		var calculator = this.GetCalculatorForAttributeType(attributeType);
		foreach(var date in datesToCalculate) {
			// the calculator will handle everything from determining which attributes 
			// of the type need to be calculated for the date, handling run log info,
			// and persisting results appropriately
			calculator.Calculate(date);
            // alternatively we could pass in the attributes in the following way
            calculator.Calculate(date, attributes.Except(calculatedAttributeDates.Where(cad => cad.Date == date).Select(cad => attributeId));
		}
	}
}

Results Data Model

In Site Level Metric calculations we relied on a model where outputs from our calculations would have to go in particular tables that were created ahead of time. The benefits of this approach was that it was quite easy to find results we were interested in and look at our data as a whole. The downside was that the model was a bit brittle because new output tables would have to be created proactively or else our calculation would hit errors.

For transaction attributes I think we should move towards a model where we have a table that describes where results for a particular attribute-date exist:

AttributeId (PK)
AttributeValueDate (PK)
startDateendDateDatabaseSchemaTableColumnDate Calculated (PK)
12016-1-12016-1-12016-1-31Outputsdboresult_Aattr_12016-10-20
12016-2-12016-2-12016-2-28Outputsdboresult_Battr_12016-10-21
22016-1-12016-1-12016-1-31Outputsdboresult_Battr_22016-10-21
22016-2-12016-2-12016-2-28Outputsdboresult_Battr_22016-10-21

The benefits of a model like this is that:

  • Output tables can be created on the fly when calculations are finished
  • If we need to recalculate the values for an attribute and it currently shares a table with a different attribute, we do not  need to recalculate both. Instead we can just recalculate the one, put it in its own output table and "deprecate" the old version of it.
  • This eliminates any need for managing a set of partiitoned tables (production, staging, deleted)

We should create a class that handles inserting into this data model.

	public class AttributeResultInfo 
	{
        // the attribute id
		public int AttributeId {get; set;}
        // the column on the result table that holds the attribute value
		public string ValueColumnName {get; set;}
        // the date value of the result
		public Date AttributeValueDate {get; set;}
        // what transaction date the result applies to
	}
	
	// This method will handle inserting into the result table. The resultTable parameter can be used
	// to determine what database, schema, table the results are stored. The attributeResultInfos tell the method
	// what data was calculated and what column it holds it in the result table
	public void PersistResult(ITable resultTable, ICollection<AttributeResultInfo> attributeResultInfos)
	{
		// inserts into the results table
		// deprecates any row that holds duplicate data
	}

Open questions

  • It would be good if we somehow had a mapping of results rows to the transaction dates which they apply to. For example, for an account-month attribute we want to state somewhere that the attribute value date 2016-1-1 applies to transactions across all of January of 2016. I think ti would be beneficial to have this represented in the data model so that we can quickly figure out what JOINs we need to do for the transaction attribute result mapping withuot having to invoke specific logic in that module
    • We could add another key column to the table above that specifies transactionDate; this would require duplciating result rows for each transactionDate they apply to
    • Alternatively we could just have a result-to-transaction-date mapping table that we insert into as part of this component 
  • Does not log anything about what is running to prevent duplicate results from being calculated simultaneously. Should that be part of this or should the Runner be responsible for this?

Cleaning up deprecated tables

Since this model does support table deprecation, we should make sure to make some sort of maintenance script that will look at this table periodically and delete any table that has only deprecated attribute-date pairs associated with it.

Transaction Attribute Result Mapper

 

Attributes to Calculate

While we ultimately want to annotate each transaction with an attribute, there are two paths forward for how the calculation run for attributes that have a frequency less than daily:

  1. We can calculate them at a monthly (for example) cadence and then in the combining step join these monthly values to the TLog
    1. The main benefit here is that space used by the output tables should be significantly less
    2. The combining step should be faster too because we have less rows to deal with
  2. During the calculation step, we can output these values at the transaction level (dw_sequency_number, dw_sequency_date)
    1. The only benefit here is that it makes the combining step consistent across each attribute because the outputs are stored at the same level

Option 1 is preferable. Handling logic for the combining step to which includes details on how to join output tables from different attribute types to the t-log for our final results should be simple enough.

Account-Month attributes

Residential Zips

The attributes persisted for residential zips is the account's zip code and state.

We have decided to rewrite residential zip logic for this effort. While the logic to weight transactions by industry and day of week to assign a score to each account-zip combination remains the same there are a couple key differences

  1. An account must have at least 3 transactions in the three month lookback period for us to assign that account a residential zip code. It is not required that these 3 transactions happen in the same zip code.
  2. When calculating residential zip code information for a given month, all accounts' residential zip values brought forward from the previous month unless an account has a new value assigned to it
  3. For a given account-month, we keep track of when the values in that row were originally calculated. This is meta-data we persist in case we think old results are being causing weird results
    1. Chris Piccoli, should we look at this column when pulling last month's values and filter out rows where the original calculation value is from 6-12 months prior?

Buyer Segments

We are not currenlty comfortable with the state of the logic so this attribute has been deprioritized.

Top of Wallet

We have followed the logic outline on this page for this implementation: Calculating Top of Wallet#Proposal1:MasterCardTopofWalletCalculation

Account-Week Attributes

These attributes will be calculated once a week. For simplicity, this will be done on each Sunday. Doing this for account-week is sufficient granularity for our needs and siginficantly reduces the number of data points we need to calculate.

Prior Spend Overall/At Client/In Industry

Notes on the calculation and needs. Much of this information can be found on this page: AID Derived Data Elements#DataElementstoPre-Calculate/Pre-Aggregate: 

  • When calculating the prior spend for an account-date we DO NOT include that date in the look back period
    • For example, if we are calculating the a week of prior spend for 2016-1-8, the lookback period is 2016-1-1 to 2016-1-7
  • When assigning these attributes to the transaction log, we use the account-date that is before or including the transaction date
    • For example if an account transact on 2016-1-8, and we have an attribute value calculated for 2016-1-8, we should use it, as it represents the spend of that customer from 2016-1-1 to 2016-1-7
  • What look back periods we want (by priority)
    • 90
    • 365
    • 30
    • 180
    • 7
  • High priority prior spend types
    • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size
    • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size at American Airlines
    • Prior spend / transaction count / basket size in T+ E Airline industry
  • Medium Priority spend types
    • TODO: add

Account

Date of First/Last Transaction

Is American / Is Benchmark

The assumption here is that we will be provided mapping of these accounts and that we will simply need to persist them on the final transaction attribute table. Therefore there will be no calculation step, but they will need to be accounted for in the combining resutls step.

Transaction Attributes

These consist of attributes which are already on the TLog (like transactionTime) or attributes that can get be obtained through JOINs to small tables (like industry code). We have two options for calculating these attributes:

  1. We can just run these JOINs in the final combining step of all our attribute values to create our final output table
  2. We can a calculation step that handles creating this data set and then treat it like any other attribute

Reason for proposal:

  • Different prioritization list between PM-SE-QA. development, release and expected release for features differ. 
  • Recently features have been flowing through to production w/o QAE knowledge pretty frequently. Hitting direct staging/production bugs. 
  • Help set realistic deadlines that considers 'dev-testing-bugfix-retest-release'

Duration: 30mins

Cadence: biweekly

Meeting owner: Hai-Ri Park

Meeting Content: 

First 10 mins: Everyone gets on the same page regarding priorities and end goals

  • Demos 
  • Deliverable s and Timelines
    • Promised Date (Demo, Client meetings, Client trainings)
    • release deadline (Min 1.5 days before recommended before promised date)
    • testing deadline (1-7 days depending complexity)
    • dev deadline (avg 1-2 sprints)

Next 15-20 mins: Collaborate on what tasks the team needs to prioritize to achieve the priorites/end goals mentioned

  • Deliverable s: Go through JIRA Backlog
    • Dev tasks that need to be included in upcoming sprints. 
      • Estimate when dev tasks/stories need to be started w/ the consideration of all the timelines above in mind. 
    • Testing task that need to be included in upcoming sprints.
      • Consider and prioritize by release deadline. 

  • Consider New stories / tasks that can be added after the prioritized tasks has been estimated.

Team goals

  • Develop a tool on top of AID platform that will generate insights for merchants while comparing their KPIs to those of competitors and industry
  • Scale the AID platform to be multi tenant so as to reduce the resource cost of setting up a new instance of AID for a merchant/client
  • Create new KPIs that more closely light with the merchants use case

Stories for phase 1

  1. Create a new instance of transaction attributes that targets Australia
    1. Exclude any client specific attributes we might have loaded for AA
    2. Include any additional information that might be required for competitive sets
    3. Add more "prior spend in industry" attributes
    4. Figure out what geographies we care about for Australia and add mappers for those
  2. Design the architecture for multi tenant platform for AID (start with AIDCalc)
    1. Some of this might require revisiting the schemas of tables we store on the aid calc database.
    2. We can also consider a pooling infrastructure where a centralized database controls attribute permissioning as well as controls pooling for the calc queries to one of multiple calc databases based on load. 
  3. Develop a front end within the AID application that is targetted for merchants use case
  4. Revisit DataUsage rules for the merchants use case
  5. Create new KPIs that cater to merchants use case
  6. Spin up new instances within testing environment that will test out the multi tenancy. The configuration should be
    1. One common Client database
    2. Individual AIDWeb databases
    3. One common AIDCalc database

APT-127454 - Getting issue details... STATUS

This page is an attempt to keep track of the amount of time that team members spend working on issues that would not have arisen if a known technical debt issue has not been addressed. Hopefully by accurately recording the amount of time that we're spending on these issues, we'll be able to prioritize them correctly and actually be able to bring work into the sprint to get to a place where we're spending less time maintaining code and more time working on new features. The goal is to get to a place where we're not just addressing technical debt tasks because the code is ugly. We want to address technical debt because it will save us time in the medium/long run.

Here are some examples of issues that I think should be added to the technical debt page:

  • We have a flaky test suite that causes deployments to fail and requires us to spend time redeploying code in bamboo
  • The Australia calculation is not automated, so we need to spend time kicking off the calculation and monitoring it
  • We hit a bug that broke BI or the Production Instance of Transaction Attributes, we know that our tests are insufficient and have not invested time to writing better ones
  • This task took much much longer than it would have if we had a better data model that would handle a lot of the code

APT-131351 - Getting issue details... STATUS

There's currently no way to confirm that all attributes required by derived attributes are included in a run (i.e. if attribute 100 relies on attribute 1, and attribute 1 is not requested, I think it'll error out later).

As part of our validations, we should check that all derived attributes have the necessary other attributes being calculated. This will be much easier when we made the derived attribute mapping clause creation database driven.

Allie Ivener2 hours (for the validations/testing) + more to make this db driven30 min (causes regression test failures if it's not configured properly)

The Problem

GDV is calculated by ensuring that the spend of the benchmark group in a country is less than 15% of total spend on in that country. For non-USA clients, this numerator is in "spendAmountLocalCurrency". The denominator, however, is from the SpendAmountUsdByCountryByDay table, which is a view on the GdvByIssuerCountryDaily table on the TransactionAttributes database, and that is a sum of spendAmountUsd. So, we are determining GDV by comparing spendAmountLocalCurrency to spendAmountUsd.

Luckily, PI clients have all been in USD anyways, so this bug does not affect data usage accuracy for PI. For BI, the Brazil Real and the Australia Dollar conversation rates to the US Dollar is in our favor, so this bug would have caused more conservative GDV failures (which we haven't been seeing), so we have not been showing data that fails data usage. 

Solutions

Update GDV check to actually use spendAmountUsd

Pros:

  • Keeps GDV check consistently in USD for all clients 
  • No changes in TransationAttributesCalc repository
  • AID code would accurately represent what's being calculated (it's not actually spendAmountUsd all the time)

Cons:

  • Requires code changes in AID repository that updates how spend is handled. Right now, the view on the TransactionAttributes table does "spendAmountLocalCurrency AS spendAmountUsd", thus avoiding any code changes. If we choose to continue doing the GDV check in USD, we'll nee to pull through both spendAmountLocalCurrency and spendAmountUsd in the view on TransactionAttributes and include logic for which column a given instance should use for calculations. 

Populate GDV table in the currency specified by the client

Pros:

  • Few code changes required. We already have logic to determine which spend column to use for a given client's attribute calculations, so we can use that for GDV as well in the TransactionAttributesCalc repository.
  • No changes required in AID repository

Cons:

  • Spend Amount USD seems to be a very reliable currency column on the raw t-log (less custom logic), so may be ideal to continue using for this data usage check
  • Requires recalculation of GDV table for non-USA clients - need to manually delete from current tables, kick off calculation so it's repopulated

Problem

After merging in code to support chunking TA calculations by week, the production job was failing with this error:

Debugging

This was a relatively simple fix:

Analysis

This could have been caught in code review. The only reason it wasn't was because the job queue endpoint runner code was originally outside of the scope of my (Adam Gallagher's) pull request, but in code review, it was suggested that we add it anyway.

As is sometimes done, I added these lines after most reviewers had already approved the PR, making it difficult to catch this simple bug.

Next Steps/Discussion Points

  • Should we have a wider discussion on practices around pushing code after or during the approval process? Generally, I've been of the mind that small changes related directly to feedback from a pull request are OK to add on to the existing review, but anything larger than that is best handled in a completely new review. Perhaps I made the wrong call on that in this case.
  • Should we be more strict about adding unit tests to even simple components like job runners? The TransactionAttributeCalcJobRunner does not have a unit test, and a well-crafted one might have caught this bug.
  • Are there ways we can utilize a testing environment more effectively to avoid situations like this in the future?
  • Are there ways we can involve QAs more in this process to avoid situations like this in the future?

Error emails

Types

  • Blocking
    • Contains errors which, based on tag information, have been considered to be blocking a user from using the software as intended.
    • Due to this email being the most critical of the 3 types, it is recommended that these are consumed in one's Inbox or a particular Blocking folder that is monitored
  • Non-blocking
    • Contains errors which, based on tag information, have been considered to NOT be blocking a user from using the software. Rather, the errors could be indicative of negative performance or user experience impact. This also includes transient errors that may seem blocking on a first attempt, but actually are not blocking because subsequent attempts reliably bypass the error.
    • It is recommended that these emails are consumed in a particular Non-blocking folder that need not be monitored, but rather can be used as a resource if a user reaches out about a problem.
  • Untagged
    • Contains errors which lack any diagnostic tag information. This means that we cannot assert whether or not a given error is Blocking or Non-blocking or gauge user impact. It also means that it is likely that the product team is not aware of this issue.
    • It is recommended that these emails are consumed in an Untagged folder that is monitored relatively regularly. The hope is that this bucket is relatively small, and that engineers will work to maintain proper tag coverage. For errors in this bucket that seem frequent or have worrying error messages, consider filing a JIRA issue so that a product team can be aware of the new issue.

Engagement best practices

  • Triaging
    • If a bug, file JIRA issue and tag w/ the issue name (e.g. APT-12345)
    • If not a bug, tag w/ context and categories (e.g. ignorable? blocking or non-blocking? expiration? product vs infrastructure vs data setup etc.?)
    • Repy-all to any email for which a tag or JIRA issue was created w/ links
  • Triage timeframes
    • Triage blocking immediately
    • Triage untagged at least daily
    • No triage for non-blocking (used as an archive for debugging reference)
  • Each team is responsible for triaging the errors in its own digests
  • If a team digest receives an error which seems to belong to another team, protocol is to FWD to other team

pageTitle: Our Backlog is Actually 7 Backlogs and All of them are Dead
content:
On Slack last week Sam mentioned our Quick Wins backlog ins't working: issues from July are sitting untouched, and the entire list of issues appears to be unprioritized (almost every issue is 'Normal/Nice to Have' and the order appears to be fairly arbitrary). This is due to, in my opinion, two related problems:

  1. Our backlog is actually 7 backlogs
  2. All of them are dead

Our Backlog is Actually 7 Backlogs

If you open the backlog tab on JIRA you'll be greeted with something like this:

Ignoring the mystery sprint "Gates of the Arctic Nat Park", we have 6 sprints other than Active Projects floating around, all acting like backlogs, and a JIRA backlog. Some of these sound reasonable on their own: keeping a Quick Win backlog so SWAT can quickly pull in tasks when they're ahead seems like the right idea. There's also potential value in splitting out the backlog by other topics, like we do for BI and PI. However, this could also cause problems down the line: determining the relative priorities of tasks at the tops of different backlogs isn't easy, and will only get harder and more confusing as we roll out more products and features. How these extra backlogs relate to SWAT is unclear (if the quick wins backlog is empty, are the PI and BI backlogs fair game for SWAT, or are they where tasked out projects that are unstaffed happen to live?). How these extra backlogs relate to project planning is unclear.

Is there a solution?

First we need to clean up our backlogs. Everything in M Sprint and Gates of the Arctic should be somewhere else, and we should consider the value in consolidating other boards: for example having a "SWAT upcoming sprint" board seems like a good idea for prioritizing the Quick Win backlog, but only if the issues are eventually pulled into Active Projects. Right now the SWAT board tends to fill up with recently triaged issues – I don't think we typically look at the whole backlog when triaging to determine priority. Enforcing the idea of a sprint for SWAT is hard since individuals peel on and off of SWAT more flexibly than aligned 2 week intervals.

It might be worth it to merge other backlogs, but in the very least, we need to do a little cleanup and prioritization here.

Also, at some point, a few people should slog through the 400+ issue backlog. A lot of the issues probably are outdated but there's probably a few important things hidden halfway down.

All of them are Dead

We don't seem to be getting to important, but not urgent, backlog tasks (hence the callout last week). SWAT normally has two SEs and one QAE. If they were all fully devoted to SWAT, maybe the backlog would get hit more often. But right now the workflow is more: wrap up the project you're finishing up when you're not resolving important issues (which tend to come up daily). Maybe the solution here is to be stricter about ensuring someone on SWAT isn't staffed to a project, especially when we care about moving on backlog/techdebt tasks.

Thoughts?

 

 

Page viewed 44 times by 19 users since Jan 03, 2018
Please wait while the Viewtracker data is loading.

Symptoms

When PI instances try to create breakouts with large number of entities, we run into OutOfMemoryExceptions (but we won’t be covering that here). In order to temporarily circumvent these errors for the AA Demo on 9/20, we worked with PDR to increase the allocated memory for AidWeb and AidResults VMs from 4GB to 16GB. However, even after bumping up the memory, we still kept running into OutOfMemoryExceptions and go/hosts still showed our memory for application pool capping out at 4GB.  http://jira/browse/CM-2653 

Underlying issue

AidResults app is aware of “calculatable” entities or metrics that it can retrieve from AidCalc via AidDataUsage. AidWeb app retrieves these metrics(in memory) and generates KPIs as functions of these metrics. If you consider an attribute like “Ticket/Basket size”, AidResults app only knows about the spend and transaction count for a particular breakout. AidWeb app adds the business logic based on the ratio KPI to get the “Ticket/Basket size”. It is only at this point that we are able to order the breakouts to get the TOP X based on that KPI. We added a new functionality to the platform recently to allow user to breakout based on attributes with a large number of codes. While the front end currently defaults to “Top X”, in order to determine the breakouts that meet the “Top X” criteria, the AidResults needs to pull into memory all potential breakout values. This causes the app to start throwing OutOfMemoryExceptions. There are code changes we can make to change the results API so we do not run into these issues, however, we did not want to risk destabilizing production environment so close to the demo. Hence, we created a PDR ticket to bump up the memory available for AidResults and AidWeb as a bandaid fix. 

Debugging Process

1. Go/hosts

After PDR bumped up the memory available to  our apps, we tried to recreate the OutOfMemoryExceptions again. We were hoping to either have circumvent the issue altogether or to hit OutOfMemoryExceptions when memory consumption reaches ~16GB. However, go/hosts still shows memory footprint of these application pools capping out at 4GB

2. Wait for swap

Next theory was that perhaps the active application pools were still referencing the old memory limit based on the max memory available when code was last deployed (before increasing memory) so we decided to wait for next swap (which was <30min away at that point). Unfortunately that did not fix the problem either. 

3. IIS Application pool private memory limit (KB)

“Private memory limit”setting on an application pool allows us to define the max memory an application pool can consume. We suspected that we might have accidentally set this limit to 4GB and hence bumping up the memory on the VM level was being capped by the max memory the app pool could consume. Adam Bravo checked the setting on our VMs and it was set to 0 on all instances (0 indicates no limit)

4. 32bit framework investigation

At this point, Adam Bravo pointed out that if we were building or deploying under 32bit framework, we would hit this 4GB limit on the application pool so we started exploring that possibility. Quick search of console output showed that AID build was using msbuild.exe from program files (x86) folder while Nweb and NetworkOptimizer build jobs did not have any matches for “x86”. Turns out this was a red herring and AID pipeline was a different approach (cmd) to invoke the msbuild exe while others were using bash and bash approach does not handle space in “Program Files (x86)” correctly and  outputs “Program~2” and hence search on x86 was not returning any matches.

4a. Compare build job configuration

 We compared the console output for the AID build job with other applications that had high memory footprint (Network optimizer and Nweb). Turns out we were using buildpipeline 2.0 template for JJB compared to other two apps that were using 1.0. Further exploration revealed that the settings used to invoke both versions of the template were actually identical

4b. Changing build servers

AID was building on CONFUCIUS while NetworkOptimizer was building on DIOGENES . We forced AID to build on DIOGENES to see if that fixed the problem (assumption here being that 32 bit nature was a function of the build server). That turned out to be another dead end.

4c. Check if we are referencing any 32 bit assembies

I went through all nuget and GAC based reference within the AID solution to see if we were referencing anything that would force a 32 bit build but nothing came up. (Turns out we have a lot of projects in AID solution and each project has a lot of references. Scanning all that is not really a fun task)

4d. MSFT documentation scan

Further exploration of MSFT documentation revealed that just using x86 version of MSBuild does not force 32 bit configuration.

Cause

When we started deploying AID app to QWEST in November 2016, we did not have the repository replication available. This meant we could not build code outside of KIRK. In order to unlock the deploymemt pipeline, we decided to set a workaround where we would provide the deploy job with artifacts it needed via alternate sources and it would just deploy them directly. At this point of time, we would take artifacts generated by CWBAMBOO build job and egress then to a folder where the deploy job would pick it up. The way CWBAMBOO was setup, it was building in 32bit configuration and causing some deployment failures. 32bit applications require the application pool to also run with a 32 bit only setting. Since was a temporary pipeline anyway and we needed to deploy to QWEST for demos with AA, we decided to set that application pool setting to true. As chef scripts were being used to configure app pools, we updated the chef recipies for AID apps to reflect that setting.

In further iterations of the AID Jenkins jobs, we got rid of the hacky artifact pipeline and replaced that with the standard pipeline on JenkinsBuild. We, however, forgot to revert the changes to chef scripts.

Why did we not catch this?

1.Since we were building with “Any Cpu” configuration on JenkinsBuild, the code continued to be compatible with the 32 bit only application pool setting and we did not encounter any errors to indicate this strange configuration.
2.While debugging this bug, I was searching for strings “32”, “86”, “64” in all our repos(including site-cookbooks repo that houses our chef scripts”. Turns out this setting is named “thirty_two_bi_only” and hence plain text search did not yield any results.
3.We have been trying to make our pipelines as “standard” as possible so as to limit the number of customization within our app family for this very reason. This was one change that just slipped by

Next steps

  • Work with PDR team to revert this override (already have a PR out for this)
  • Audit any process from initial release of AID so see if there is anything else like this that might be lingering around ( APT-130166 - Getting issue details... STATUS )
Special thanks to Shwetha Choodamani, Adam Bravo and rest of PDR team for being an excellent resource and for being so patient with us through all this

How to read Testing Task naming format:

Knowing how to read testing tasks in the testing story helps better estimate when the feature is expected to release as well as knowing what testing method was used to test the feature. (eg. Toggle, QA branch, Local branch)  

 

 

Other changes

We edited the existing triage board (go/aidtriage) to also include bugs submitted on the 'story of bugs' as well.

  • Each day we will triage new bugs and support issues.
  • Issues which we do not intend on handling in the current sprint should be moved to the backlog.

Story of bugs

The "Story of Bugs" is making a comeback. Log all other bugs that is not a feature bug to this story. (Production, master Integration bugs etc.)

Feature bugs

If bugs come up during feature development and branch testing they will be filed under the corresponding 'follow up story'.

Support bugs (Client team logs a bug - futuristic)

Support issues that are part of existing features (anything that has moved beyond "active development") that the team intends to take on during a sprint will be added ad-hoc to the sprint as tasks and will appear on the bottom of the JIRA rapid board.  To facilitate this process:

Pushkar Rege tasked me with coming up with a sprint theme for the Merchant Insights team that we will start on 5/22. After much deliberation with the team in DC, we've landed on "International Ingestibles" - allowing us to explore the various cultures of the world while taking advantage of a team budget that Simon Krauss claims "isn't a real thing".

Nonetheless, each sprint will be named for a particular country (or region depending on how bad the eligible countries are for a particular letter). Near the end of each sprint, the team will enjoy a food and beverage from the eponymous country or region of the sprint.

This page tracks the countries we'd like to use for upcoming sprints, as well as the injestibles we'll enjoy from that country. Feel free to fill out each cell with suggestions, we can decide on each sprint during sprint planning.

Considerations

Datasets

APT-118213 - Getting issue details... STATUS

We should start with a small dataset (similar to the demo database that can be used for rapid iteration. We should prioritize the creation of this and unlock any development that depends on this. Having a smaller dataset will also give us the flexibility of adding more attributes relatively quickly as we get new requirements. We should try to use CBA data or subset of that data for initial development since Australian merchants might be our initial sales targets.

APT-118214 - Getting issue details... STATUS

This should be the actual dataset that will be released to clients. While designing this dataset, we should take a few likely client merchants that might be initial sales targets and make sure we load appropriate data for them.

Geographies

Two geographies we might be targetting for this product will be Australia (and maybe Brazil). While designing the transactionAttributes calc logic, we should keep these in mind and make sure we are ready to generate the transactionAttributeOutput database for each of them. We do not necessarily calculate residential zips for all countries and we do not have a target geography (e.g Zipcode) for each country that gets mapped to each account. We should try to make sure any AIDTA code we write can be scaled to our target geographies

Data size

The instance we set up for CBA (which also included some USA issues to pass issuer 5/25) has about 27MM accounts and about 33Billion transactions. We should estimate the size of the australian dataset and document that on AID Instances

Additional Attributes

In addition to the common attributes used in the AID application right now, we might also want to add a few special attributes for MI

  1. prior spend attributes at a few common industries
  2. residential location/zip/state attributes for each geography
  3. locationId or MMID attributes for transaction in case we decide to use those to identify a comp set.

Passing MI specific data elements

For MI use case, we might want to pass CompSetId or other constructs that may not be directly available via TransactionAttributes table (since those will be added on the fly). We might need to change the Calc API to accommodate for that.

Handling comp sets

For the initial version of MI calc, we might be able to assume that Competetive sets are defined by aptAggregateMerchants. However, addition of new comp set should not require us to reroll TransactionAttributes and hence we might need to create a separate pipeline for deploying Competetive sets for MI calc and join data in those tables to TransactionAttributes  in the calc code.

DataUsage rules to apply

Since we may not need to apply Issuer comp set checks for MI use case, we will need to make sure the DataUsage client accounts for that and has a separate pipeline that does not require passing resultsByIssuer. There might also be other changes we need to make to DU app to account for this special use-case

Productionalize AIDWeb changes form market-share-alpha-prototype branch

Louis created a bunch of custom cards and card types for the market share branch that are not scalable. We should work on developing those further to make them flexible so that we can access them from Dashboard manager while creating new cards

Create new KPI for market share

With the changes from KPI refactor merged in, we should be unlocked to create share KPIs that can represent market share using the aid.clientAggregateMerchants table and industry attribute.

Problem

After turning on the AidUseAttributeDatesAvailable toggle in Staging and Production, all BI instances and the PI Banking_Demo instance were inaccessible. This toggle was created to allow datesAvailable to diverge for different instances, namely the Citi and Barclays portfolios.

Debugging

There were 2 separate issues that led to BI and PI instances being down:

  1. BI - the toggle relied on having an isClient attribute, which was fixed by an open PR
  2. PI - the DbUp script to create the attributeValues.attributeDatesAvailable view was never added to the Banking_Demo instance

Next Steps

BI compatibility

  • Get access for devs to both BI and PI
  • Selenium-type integration tests
  • @QA - Make sure toggles were on by default on testing before moving them
  • Make sure there are testing tasks for these and communicate testing needs more actively
    • Retrospective topic to broadcast this
  • Add a task when a toggle is defaulted OFF in testing

PI DbUp

  • Think through this more thoroughly while reviewing PRs
  • Use the don't forget list more and add this to the list

Process

  • Try to release toggles with deployments
    • Broadcast this more on Slack when doing off-cycle
    • Mention use of #mcg-qa during retrospective
    • Kenny Chin send out toggles best practices page

Symptoms

After deploying AID-015 to QWEST and opening the Barclays instance, the parent merchant attribute appeared in the filter panel, but the merchant attribute did not.

Debugging

The merchant attribute was never created in production and thus never made available as a drilldown option. We were able to fix this by running the following scripts.

So what I wanted to run was this:
IF NOT EXISTS(SELECT * FROM aid.transactionAttributeMappings WHERE mastercardTransactionAttributeId = 501)
BEGIN 
EXEC aid.p_createAidAttributeFromTransactionAttribute 
       @transactionAttributeId = 501, /* aggregate merchant */
       @isDrilldownOption = 1,
       -- should be enabled for benchmark
       @isClientOnly = 0,
       @isCoded = 1,
       @isOrdinal = 0,
       @name = 'Merchant',
       @orderId = 552
END
GO


BUT, because I don’t have exec permissions, I had to just copy the contents of that stored procedure and run that manually, which is everything below:


-- Optional to override the DB generated ID
       DECLARE
       @aidAttributeId INT = NULL,
       -- if we are not specifying the aidAttributeId we can output the identity generated
       @outputAttributeId INT = NULL,
       @transactionAttributeId INT = 501,
       @name NVARCHAR(255) = 'Merchant',
       @isCoded BIT = 1,
       @isOrdinal BIT = 0,
       -- optional arguments for
       -- (1) attribute metadata
       @attributeType INT = 1, -- static
       @mask NVARCHAR(50) = NULL,
       @frontSymbol NVARCHAR(50) = NULL,
       @backSymbol NVARCHAR(50) = NULL,
       @isParentIssuerAttribute BIT = 0,
       @isAccountProductCodeAttribute BIT = 0,
       @isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute BIT = 0,
       @isClientAccountAttribute BIT = 0,
       @isClientTransactionAttribute BIT = 0,
       @isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute BIT = 0,
       -- (2) display configuration
       @isDrilldownOption BIT = 1,
       @isClientOnly BIT = 0,     
       @orderId INT = 552,
       @orderType INT = 1 /* Alphabetical */
       
       IF(@aidAttributeId IS NOT NULL)
              BEGIN
                     -- Turn Identity Insert ON since we're given an aidAttributeId
                     SET IDENTITY_INSERT aid.attributes ON
                     
                     -- add attribute
                     INSERT INTO aid.attributes (attributeId, attributeType, name, isCoded, isOrdinal, mask, frontSymbol, backSymbol, dateDeleted, isParentIssuerAttribute, isAccountProductCodeAttribute, isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute, isClientAccountAttribute, isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute, isAccountIssuerAttribute)
                     SELECT
                           @aidAttributeId AS attributeId,
                           @attributeType AS attributeType, 
                           @name AS name,
                           @isCoded AS isCoded, 
                           @isOrdinal AS isOrdinal, 
                           @mask AS mask, 
                           @frontSymbol AS frontSymbol, 
                           @backSymbol AS backSymbol, 
                           NULL AS dateDeleted,
                           @isParentIssuerAttribute AS isParentIssuerAttribute, 
                           @isAccountProductCodeAttribute AS isAccountProductCodeAttribute, 
                           @isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute AS isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute, 
                           @isClientAccountAttribute AS isClientAccountAttribute,
                           @isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute AS isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute,
                           -- For backwards compatability 
                           @isParentIssuerAttribute AS isAccountIssuerAttribute

                     -- Turn Identity Insert OFF
                     SET IDENTITY_INSERT aid.attributes OFF
              END
       ELSE 
              BEGIN
                     DECLARE @outputTable TABLE (attributeId INT)

                     INSERT INTO aid.attributes (attributeType, name, isCoded, isOrdinal, mask, frontSymbol, backSymbol, dateDeleted, isParentIssuerAttribute, isAccountProductCodeAttribute, isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute, isClientAccountAttribute, isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute, isAccountIssuerAttribute)
                     OUTPUT INSERTED.attributeId INTO @outputTable
                     SELECT
                           @attributeType AS attributeType, 
                           @name AS name,
                           @isCoded AS isCoded, 
                           @isOrdinal AS isOrdinal, 
                           @mask AS mask, 
                           @frontSymbol AS frontSymbol, 
                           @backSymbol AS backSymbol, 
                           NULL AS dateDeleted,
                           @isParentIssuerAttribute AS isParentIssuerAttribute, 
                           @isAccountProductCodeAttribute AS isAccountProductCodeAttribute, 
                           @isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute AS isAptAggregateMerchantAttribute, 
                           @isClientAccountAttribute AS isClientAccountAttribute,
                           @isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute AS isIssuerCountryCodeAttribute,
                           -- For backwards compatability 
                           @isParentIssuerAttribute AS isAccountIssuerAttribute

                     -- Set the output variable of outputAttributeId and the aidAttributeId for use in the remainder of the sp
                     SELECT TOP 1 @outputAttributeId = attributeId FROM @outputTable
                     SET @aidAttributeId = @outputAttributeId
              END
              

       -- Insert into custom attribute ordering table
       IF @orderId IS NOT NULL
              INSERT INTO aid.customAttributeOrdering (attributeId, orderId) VALUES (@aidAttributeId, @orderId)

       -- then create mapping
       INSERT INTO aid.transactionAttributeMappings (aidAttributeId, mastercardTransactionAttributeId)
       VALUES (@aidAttributeId, @transactionAttributeId)

       INSERT INTO aid.attributeDisplayConfig (attributeId, isDrilldownOption, isClientOnly, orderType)
       VALUES (@aidAttributeId, @isDrilldownOption, @isClientOnly, @orderType)

Root Cause

The attribute was manually created in testing, but a script was never added to create the attribute in production. And because the attribute was never created, the script to add merchant as a drilldown option could not run either.

Next steps

  • Ryan Allen to commit the SQL in Kirk to make sure we have a record of what was run
  • AID team will be more careful about never running manual changes on anything but dev and QA databases within Kirk

pageTitle: 2017-03-31 Split by Coded and Bucketted Attribute Bug
content:
Symptoms

While we worked on refactoring how the "other" bar is calculated, we chose various filter/split combinations to use to confirm that our calculations were correct. We discovered that splitting by both a coded and continuous attribute (both of which return data when as a split individually) resulted in no results and no data usage warning. If the first code was selected, then all data went into that bucket (i.e. all data went into Alabama for a state + continuous attribute split)

Debugging 

  • Discovered that a bucket was created for each filter set (as expected), but doing Distinct() on those buckets did not work, so we ended up with too many buckets. 
    • In the above example, there are 10 buckets for prior spend and 16 available codes for AAdvantage Product Line, which creates 160 filter sets. Only 10 buckets should have been used to filter data. Instead, 160 buckets were used, and these buckets were sets of 16 identical buckets (i.e. bucket ids 0-15 were the same, bucket ids 16-31 were the same, etc - see image below). 
    • Because the SQL query uses a CASE WHEN, all data was sorted into the first bucket of each identical set (i.e. all data into bucket 0, 16, 32, etc.). This caused a later JOIN to fail because each code had its own bucket.

Solution

  • Adding the Equals and GetHashCode functions to the TransactionFilter.Bucket class fixed the problem!

Why didn't we catch this?

There are a few reasons why we had't caught this bug until now:

  1. Incomplete mocked data
    1. The data mocked in the FilterSetTransactionExtractProviderTest inputs did not have all possible filter sets. Our tests created the correct transaction extract for those filter sets, but since we were missing filter sets, not all code/bucket combinations were created and this bug did not surface.
    2. Any test for which an attribute only had one code would not have found this bug because the number of filter sets would equal the number of expected buckets anyways
    3. But, even with that fixed we STILL wouldn't have caught this pesky bug. After fixing the input data, tests we expected to show this bug still passed...
  2. Object references versus value in Test Input Reader
    1. Data for these tests were mocked using a Test Input Reader which creates TransactionFilterSet objects from a csv input file. 
    2. However, when the filter sets were created, we were mapping FilterModels to create new TransactionFilterSet objects. This mapping caused buckets to share the same reference rather than creating new values, and thus be equal even without the Equals and GetHashCode functions. Since this was the case, the Distinct() did properly filter down to the right number of buckets
    3. This situation did not mirror what happens when an actual calc request is made. The buckets should not have had the same reference
    4. Updating the Test Input Reader to deserialize and then reserialize the FilterSetModel object fixed this problem because that creates new values for the TransactionFilter (and associated Bucket) objects.
  3. Missing front-end manual tests
    1. Originally, splitting by a continuous attribute was not supported. When this was feature was added in, it was during major AID crunch time and a note in a test plan to go back and check this case was missed

Problem

Users report transient errors where cards display "X"s unexpectedly (we cannot usually reproduce).

Examples:

  • Arthur Costa (Mastercard) - 5/4 ~9:30am (EST)  See email attached.
    • 3 of 4 dashboard cards loaded as "X"s. 
    • Screenshot: 
    • No server-side errors.
      • There were some warnings (e.g. https://apt.aptplatform.com/exceptions/secure/detail/8281?expirationDate=20170518&exceptionAccessToken=0BB885C20C397B88805AB6B77D20C3B55B0EA211&exceptionId=59131692399080778343748927688905) around this time, however 1) these jobs still completed when the queries were automatically retried, and 2) these exceptions are in MetricResultsTerminalJobStatusUpdater, which should not block or impact the user; the job is effectively a "fire-and-forget" cleanup job that runs decoupled from the actual data requests.
    • No logged JS errors (though we are not 100% confident in JS logging, and there are a couple bug fix PR's outstanding)
    • Cannot reproduce
  • Daniel Mace - 5/4 ~11:50AM (EST)
    • No server-side errors from Daniel's account around this time
    • No logged JS errors
    • Cannot reproduce
    • "X" appeared immediately (no spinner)
    • Settings for the output I was trying to generate:
      • Metric: Spend
      • Metric format: Actual values
      • Timeframe: Last month (2/1/17 - 2/28/17
      • Split: Airline - Top 10 by Spend & Other
      • Filters: Age Range (18 - 25, 26 - 35)
    • I re-ran the output on 5/5/17, and the output returned without errors:
      • URL (from 5/5/17 re-run, not original: https://apt.aptplatform.com/aid/drilldown/1/1304/1485907200000/1488240000000
      • Screenshot: 
 Expand source 
[‎5/‎4/‎2017 11:54 AM] Chris Piccoli: 
 
daniel is hitting errors. do you see anything weird going on?

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 11:55 AM] Alex Franz:

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 11:56 AM] Alex Franz:

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 11:57 AM] Chris Piccoli:

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 12:23 PM] Chris Piccoli:

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 12:24 PM] Alex Franz: 
yeah, I've been trying a whole bunch of things too

I assume something just came back as an "X"?
[‎5/‎4/‎2017 12:25 PM] Chris Piccoli:
