it was weird
[‎5/‎4/‎2017 12:26 PM] Alex Franz: 
Okay.  Feels like there's some issue on the JS side that we aren't logging.
I was looking into Arthur's issue before you pinged and I don't think we understand that one either
the error that we identified this morning was a warning (the job ended up finishing just fine),
and it that code shouldn't have resulted in an error anyway, so I don't think we've tracked that one down yet either

[‎5/‎4/‎2017 12:28 PM] Chris Piccoli: 
interesting that's odd

Next steps

Unfortunately, without a clear diagnosis it's difficult to come up with a good strategy for fixing this issue.  The first course of action should be to get more information:

  • Our logging seems to currently be insufficient to detect and report on this issue
    • We should add JS logging around any situation that can mark results as errored.  APT-118414 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • We should ass JS logging around the code that sets a to the errored state, and include any context we can.  APT-118415 - Getting issue details... STATUS
  • When possible we should get specific URLs, screenshots, and devtools dumps when this happens
    • Daniel Mace or Chris Piccoli, if either of you are able to get this information for today's issues that would be helpful.
  • Everybody should be on the lookout for this issue during the course of testing and development and try to look into this if we happen to catch it live with DevTools open

There are a number of things that might be going on here that we can better protect against:

  • Handling dropped requests and errors
    • It does seem like most of these errors (including both examples we have so far on this page) happen outside of the APT network (in this case either w/ Advisors or AA).  We should double check how we are handling these.
      • For Polling it looks like we do decent handling  APT-118418 - Getting issue details... STATUS
      • But for CreateResults we set the "ERROR" status immediately; we may want to "retry" these requests too.  (OutputDataProvider.getresultsInternal())  APT-118420 - Getting issue details... STATUS
    • Logging any time we get an "error" on an AJAX request may be useful.  APT-118421 - Getting issue details... STATUS
  • Retry logic: While we don't have evidence of Metric Results jobs failing in the jobqueue, we could add retry logic to JS code that tries to get results from any given MRRID more than once if the job's status comes back as failed or canceled, in case this is a transient issue.  This would be a bandaid fix, but being overly cautious in this situation wouldn't hurt because it is a very visible error that we should try very hard to avoid.  APT-118375 - Getting issue details... STATUS

Symptoms

There was an analytic bug when displaying Share of Wallet Year over Year.

  • The correct calculation is to display 100 * (SoW_ty - SoW_ly).  (this year share of wallet - last year share of wallet, * 100 to get bps).  
  • This could also be written as 100 * ((client_ty / all_ty) - (client_ly / all_ly)).  (e.g. client spend this year over all spend this year - client spend last year over all spend last year, *100 to get bps).
  • We were incorrectly computing ((client_ty / client_ly) - (all_ty / all_ly)).

 

The issue was identified when comparing results from a refactor of the AID Web code (Web Tier - Trees).  The new code resulted in different values.  Upon further investigation we determined that the new implementation was correct, and there was a bug in the old version.

 

Debugging

We have confirmed that results were manually tested and correct as of 12/14/2016.  This implies that some change since then introduced this bug.  There were a number of changes to the code that creates settings and consumes results from AidResults.  Both are complex and could easily have introduced this bug.  It is likely that the creation of settings was changed from requesting settings from [N_ty, D_ty, N_ly, D_ly] (where N = numerator, D = denominator) to [N_ty, N_ly, D_ty, D_ly], though it has proven difficut to track down the exact commit that made this change and when.

Testing

There is not sufficient automated testing for this calculation.

  • The structure of AID makes this particularly difficult because the bug lies in the integration of the code in AidWeb creating settings for AidResults, and the subsequent code in AidWeb asynchronously consuming those results.
  • The new code design (outlined in Web Tier - Trees) should significantly reduce the chance of this sort of bug because the tree will be created during setting creation and result consumption.
  • We should consider adding a level of integration testing that allows testing of the complete process from HTTP request to AidWeb to create results, and subsequent response containing results.
  • Another path to test would be Selenium.

Both integration and Selenium testing have been challenging in the KIRK environment and we have pushed off investment here.  We should reconsider and/or reevaluate our timeline to sanitized data and a testing environment outside of KIRK.

Next steps 

  1. We have fixed the old code (bugfix to master and hotfix to production).  This will be pushed following code review, and deployed after testing.  We expect to turn around in < 24 hours.
  2. Chris Piccoli followed up with the AA client team.
  3. We will schedule a meeting to discuss how we can get to automated testing of these results.

Meeting notes from (3)

  • Testing is challenging:
    • We should have had opportunities to flag these changes as a case where additional manual testing was necessary for Share YoY.  We didn't catch this edge case - possibly because we didn't identify the specific case of Share + YoY, or possibly because we assumed the refactor was not going to be related / need front end manual testing
    • The only reliable way to cover these numbers would be through automated integration testing with two options:
      • Integration testing is currently challenging in KIRK.  Would require:
        • Creating an AID_REGRESSION environment in KIRK
        • Setting up nightly integration tests on Bamboo
        • Setting up ability to run these tests locally or against AID_REGRESSION
      • Selenium in KIRK is a possibility
        • Need to bring Selenium in to KIRK (unknown work; Pushkar Rege thinks this wouldn't be too difficult.  Conrad Rybka do you have any opinion?)
        • Would then need to develop front end tests that point to a drilldown and validate some results.
      • Selenium in QWEST (hitting the sanitized demo test case we have) could be a possibility.
        • Conrad Rybka can you provide more context on feasibility of doing this in qwest in particular?
        • Downside is we won't be testing issues until Staging.
      • When we get a sanitized testing DB in UUNet we can set up Selenium and integration/regression unit tests more easily in this environment.
        • We don't think we have DU permission to move the current demo DB into a testing environment.  Dave Pacifico / Chris Piccoli is this a possibility at all at this point?  Otherwise I'm think we'll be waiting to follow up on this some time after the POC data is sanitized and generated.

We're going to start pursuing the second and third options here (Pushkar Rege, Hai-Ri Park)

pageTitle: 2017-01-25 APT-107920 Request for Getting results takes over 3 minutes
content:
Symptoms

When running splits that result in large number of results (i.e., split by product group & industry), results take a long time to show up on the page, even if they are precomputed.

Debugging

There were two issues at play:

  1. We were storing off IEnumerables in nested object types that were not ToList()'d - this caused additional overhead when Running AsJsonNetResult() since that is lazily evaluated
  2. MetricResultCombiner when combining results was using a join with a custom comparator that required n^2 time. 
    1. The join itself introduced n^2
    2. The comparator itself had several performance issues just by itself:
      1. It was using Switch.On which evaluates all paths
      2. It was using an "All" for equality comparison, which required evaluation of more elements than necessary
    3. The comparator was also in charge of filtering down to the meaningful set

 

Solution

We removed the join and comparator, and optimized the code by filtering to the required subset of elements, ordering the elements in a consistent way, and using Zip to correlate the two lists of elements.

 

 

Next steps

Fill in here during next retrospective

pageTitle: 2017-02-21 Db setup and jenkins DbUp job bring down production
content:
Symptoms

After Hai-Ri Park deployed AID-006 code to staging, the platform went down and we started hitting errors below

Debugging

It was clear that the view definition for the external views had been reset to their default value. We already had client specific setup scripts that would configure these external views so first step was to figure out why external scripts ran again and why the client specific scripts were not run.

  1. When we ran the following sql on Aid instances on hardwell we saw there were two version of Schema versions table. The latest of those "dbo.SchemaVersions" had been created the day of deployments and had run all the Dbup Scripts from the begining. One of the last scripts it ran was setting the External views to their default value (where it throws a message asking for client specific setup). There should have been client specific scripts that ran after that but those we missing from the log table.

    	select s.name as schemaName, t.name as tableName, t.create_date as createDate
	from sys.tables t
	join sys.schemas s	
		on s.schema_id = t.schema_id
	where t.name like 'SchemaVersions'

  2. When we looked at the deploy jobs, the all seem to have run successfully.
  3. We decided to dig in deeper and looked at the console logs of each dbup jobs in Jenkins. Turns out the Dbup job had encountered the errors but had failed to mark the job as a failure. Looking at the errors in the console, it was clear that we were missing a table "dbo.aidClientId" that was required for the client specific setup (this is a manual one-time initial setup step so that the dbup executable knows that client specific scripts to run). Since the QWEST databases were created before we added client specific setup, we had not run this step for those databases. 


 

Root Cause

Changing schema for DbUp and writing non-idempotent sql

We recently switching the DbUp log table(SchemaVersions) to always use "dbo" schema. This table logs all the scripts that have already been run on the database and runs the remaining scripts. By default the deployment account in QWEST used a custom schema "APTPRODUCTION\MCDBDepQ$" when it created the SchemaVersions the first time it ran DbUp. The change of schema to "dbo" meant that all the scripts were run again and any script that was not idempotent ended up putting the database in an undesirable state. In this case, the view on TransactionAttributes got overwritten to their default state that throws errors

Not running Setup in QWEST databases

We recently added client specific steps to each of our DbUp process. This was a placeholder for any DataImport processes that could be configured in the future. This setup requires us to create certain tables on each AID database before DbUp gets run. Since this step was not completed on QWEST databases, the client specific scripts started throwing errors. If we had run the setup steps before dbup ran, even with the change of schema to "dbo" the external views would have been configured correctly and this error would have been avoided.

Jenkins "MAX_ACCEPTABLE_DB_FAILURES" threshold for running Dbup

The script we use for running Dbup executables on databases has a hard-coded "MAX_ACCEPTABLE_DB_FAILURES" setting which is set to 5. This setting checks for number of databases that had errors when running dbup and if that number is less than 5, it return success code and logs the following in the console - "Encountered 2 errors while executing DbUp. This is below the max number of allowable failures (5), so the script is considered a success.". We only have 2 databases in QWEST on which AID DbUp scripts are run (AACiti and AABarclays) and even though both of them failed, the deploy job was marked as a success.  

Next steps 

  1. AID team to be more careful when rolling out changes like these. In hindsight, we should have created tasks to run the initial setup on QWEST databases
  2. Work with DevOps team so that DbUp jobs report errors when DbUp exe fails on databases

 

Page viewed 39 times by 24 users since Feb 22, 2017
Please wait while the Viewtracker data is loading.

Problem

A bug was encountered where we had filters, which act as cache keys, collide in a dictionary (error). The root cause of this was the difference in properties/columns of a filter. Changing the filter definition leads to Staging (newer code) having a filter with N+1 properties and Production having a filter of only N properties. In this scenario, any filter added by Staging with the new property will be read by Production as the same (e.g. filter of type A with NewProperty=TRUE and filter of type A with NewProperty=FALSE looks the same to Staging, since NewProperty column is not known by the old code). Specifically in this case, the 'IsComplement' property was added to the filter definition (so the entity and table).

The quick fix for this was to correct the Equals/GetHashCode functions for a filter and ensure that we were calling Distinct() on these filters so that duplicates wouldn't collide (APT-109729). This, however, only fixes a hard failure due to a dictionary key collision. It does not address soft failure where we still have collisions on filters. The same scenario described above, where different filters can be 'read' as the same by Production code, will happen any time new properties are added to the filter definition. While we avoid a hard-failure with Distinct() calls, we will be getting incorrect results potentially by grabbing a filter that does not actually match the desired type (e.g. Production wants filter of type A, and we show the result, but actually the filter is of type A with IsComplement=TRUE, yielding the inverse of what we want). Critically, the environment most impacted here is Production since that is the outdated code, and worse, these problems in Production are caused by Staging and thus cannot be tested nor investigated in the Staging.

 Potential solutions

(A) Versioning

  • Add a version ID to the underlying filter table, and make it so that code of version X can read filters created by version X or lower
  • Simple and explicit
  • Not automatic (any change to filter would require the developer to advance the version)

(B) Environment differentiation

  • Add EnvironmentType to the underlying filter table, and make it so that code Staging can read filters made by Staging and Production, while Production can only read filter made in Production
  • Simple but less explicit
  • Automatic (environment acts as the versioning barrier automatically)

(C) Filter inconsistency detection

  • When reading filters, inspect current code's FilterModel (and implementations) properties to verify that they can include certain rows from the filter table
  • This might require that any additional properties added are nullable? I haven't fully thought through this solution, so this is speculative and might not really be feasible
  • Main idea here is to avoid the versioning scheme

(D) Ignore problem for now

  • If we don't see ourselves adding to the filter definition any time soon, we can push this back
  • If we figure out a way to not need to support dual-RC compatibility on the same database, then we don't ever need to do this
    • The idea here is: just because APT has always respected this constraint, must AID? 
    • Would we be able to separate ourselves from this constraint by slightly changing out deployment methodology?
    • Would require:
      • Addressing Staging and Production sharing the same databse (e.g. we could spin off a copy of the db for Staging to use for each deploy, so that Staging can still be used as a testing ground before deploying to Production)
      • Addressing the fact that idle tests run new code on the database while Production runs old code, and so even if Staging is solved, this is another instance of where dual-RC compatibility is expected

(E) Write features with cross-RC compatibility in mind

  • When writing features always think about compatibility with the previous release branch
    • In this example there are two possible approaches:
      1. In the next release branch add the feature functionality but do not use it (e.g. we add the ability to read NOT IN filters, but we never write them to the DB in this release).  In the following release, begin using the feature.
        • pros: You do not have to modify "production" or cherry-pick code
        • cons: It takes an extra release cycle to get the feature
          • With weekly deployments this process could be unfeasibly slow, but since we control release
      2. "hotfix" the current release with code that has the bare minimum code to support the new feature; e.g. filtering out unsupported filters; then writing the feature into the next release branch as-is
        • pros: You get the feature sooner
        • cons: You're patching the branch in an active production environment, which is more dangerous
    • We've done this a lot at APT.  As an institution I think we're pretty good at it, though as a team/product we haven't done been careful about this in quite a while
  • The challenges here are detecting a problem before it happens
    • We can be attentive in code reviews
    • We can remember to add "RC compatibility" as a task when we pre-task stories
    • The holdout testing environment is directly aimed at detecting this sort of issue, since we use a "next-RC" database with the old RC codeset

(F) Any other proposals?

pageTitle: 2017-01-20 - Deploying new dataset on QWEST brought down production instance
content:
Symptoms

After deploying a new instance of Transaction attributes database, we started encountering binding errors on the attributeValues.TransactionAttribute view in Calc. This was preventing us from kicking off new calc on Staging as well as Production in QWEST.

Debugging

There was a column name changes on the transactions attributes table on the newer copy of TransactionAttribute that broke the view on AID calc database. We were able to fix that by running the following scripts

Football + Hardwell:

  update transactionattributes.attributevalues.attributemetadata
  set attributecolumn = 'citiAggregateMerchantId'
  where attributecolumn = 'citiAptAggregateMerchantId'

Football:

    Renamed column citiAptAggregateMerchantId in TransactionAttributes.attributeValues.transactionAttributes to citiAggregateMerchantId

Root Cause

When MCDI rolled up the new copy of TransactionAttributes, the column 'citiAggregateMerchantId' was renamed to 'citiAptAggregateMerchantId'. This was a breaking change that went unnoticed. Ideally, we would have deployed the new TransactionAttributes database to TITAN (on kirk) and tested it out before deploying it to QWEST. However, since we wanted to get the new dataset out before the meeting on 01-23-2017, we had to skip the KIRK testing step.

Also, since the view on the AIDCalc databases lists out all the columns that are being referenced on the TransactionAttributes database, whenever MCDI team wants to make a breaking change (e.g. rename a column), they need to coordinate with the AID team which is sub optimal.

Next steps

  • Set up a process to test changes in kirk before deploying to production (if time permits ofcourse)
  • MCDI team will be more careful about maintaining backwards compatibility
  • MCDI team and AID team will try to switch the view logic so that TransactionAttributes database has two views attributeValues.AACITI_TransactionAttributes and attributesValues.AABARCLAYS_TransactionAttributes that list out all the columns that the respective aid calc instance should be allowed to access. AID views can then just be "SELECT *" view on top of them. This will give MCDI team more flexibility to refactor their code and rename columns and make the system a little more robust. APT-109234 - Getting issue details... STATUS
  • MCDI team and AID team will come up with a stored procedure that can be used to validate a new Transaction attributes database so check if it is ready for deployment. Few examples are
    • Check that attributeMetadata, intAttributeCodes and varcharAttributeCodes have all the expected columns
    • Check if all column names mentioned in attribute metadata actually exist on the attribute values views
    • Check if the code-name mapping for any attribute has changed (e.g. code 1 for state attribute used to be Alaska but now is Florida etc)
      APT-109235 - Getting issue details... STATUS

go/NYCAID links here


Important Links

AID general persistent hangout

go/AIDHang

Jackson Augustus Fiore Hamburger's Personal Hangout

go/jhamburger



A space for tracking things pertaining to the AID effort in NYC

Symptoms

One of the developers pushed some change to RC that were database related and after those changes were deployed, we started hitting javascript errors on RC. Reverting to the old build made the errors go away. Rebuilding or clean build did not help resolve the issues. After some time, we starting seeing the same error on master as well. On both master and rc within KIRK: we would get a JavaScript error like the following

( also ref https://github.com/webpack/css-loader/issues/240)

 

When developer tried to reproduce this locally, they were not hitting the same error.

Debugging

AID teams in DC and New York were investigating this in parallel.

DC investigation

Ryan Allen, Pushkar Rege were investigating this and we pulled in Mathew Hartje for some help with npm.

Since the code that caused us to notice this error only consisted of database changes, we suspected that the issue was not code based but related to the build process or something that was bamboo related. Since we were unable to reproduce this locally, we thought it might be related to the subtle differences in how bamboo builds the solution .The build on Bamboo differs from local in a few ways

  1. Bamboo starts with a clean repository every time while for local build we do not clean out the nuget and npm packages before each build
  2. Bamboo builds in release mode since it has to pass certain build flags that are not required for local development.
  3. Bamboo also generates minified bundle js file along with the un-minified one.

#3 was easy to rule out as the cause since we were able to hit the same error in minified as well as non-minified mode in RC. 

To reproduce #2 locally, we built the AID solution with the exact same parameters as used by Bamboo but still could not reproduce the error locally.

With #1 being our last hope, we tried to clean the entire folder, delete all npm packages and nuget packages and build everything from clean start with the same build parameters as Bamboo. The hypothesis being that since we all had npm packages locally, we did not necessarily need to query the remote npm server to download new packages. However, since bamboo starts with clean working directory, it was perhaps downloading a newer version of some package that was not compatible with the rest ( we used to specify the minimum version of each package with open max version). However, we could still not reproduce the error locally.

At this point, we decided to kick off another Bamboo build so we could compare the bamboo working directory with the local one to see if there were any changes. When the build completed and deployed the new artifacts, the error was gone from RC and master as well. There had been no code changes in last 4 hours but the issue had been magically fixed. 

NYC investigation

Louis Antonelli and I (Rishab Malhotra) tried rebuilding, turning off uglification, reverting the changes to support minified / unminified first. After no success, I spent time diffing build logs between successful runs and came across the following within our build server logs (which didn't appear in any other environment):

"Module build failed: BrowserslistError: Unknown browser query `basedir=$(dirname "$(echo "$0" | sed -e 's,\\,/,g')")`"

A quick google search of that error resulted in us finding someone else with the same symptom: 

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/3938

They resolved it with a cleaning out of all modules and force reinstallation. We did this and it solved our problem.

Root Cause

The NPM project.json file had the minimum versions of packages we required. NPM by default takes those versions and installs all latest package versions of packages that "work together." Some third party developer of one of these packages pushed a bug that lasted several hours on one of the minor versions. They identified the bug and pushed a fix, but did not update the version number - therefore the build server thought it had already had the latest version of the package. A simple clean of the build directories and forced re-download and reinstallation of packages fixed the issue. 

Next steps 

  • We should use explicit version dependencies, because npm install will always download the latest (from the internet):  APT-108165 - Getting issue details... STATUS
  • Try out npm shrinkwrap

Take aways

  • Members of the web team were more careful about cherry picking team members on their pull requests while the calc team seems to have used the default set of reviewers a lot. This lead to the web team being put on more reviews than were relevant to them. As a team, we should strive to only put relevant people as reviewers.
  • We need to come up with a strategy to maximize the Approval percent for all developers. This can be achieved by changing our Pull request policies
    • Only add people who NEED to approve your Pull request as reviewers. Other developer who need to be informed of the changes but don't necessarily need to approve the PR should be tagged on the pull request by referencing them in the description.
    • We should set a fix expiry for each pull request type
      • Feature pull request - 1 day
      • Minor bug fix - 1 day
      • Urgent bug fix - maybe an hour or so (lower if it is blocking)
      If you do not have approval from all the reviewers, you should reach out to them and ask them to review the PR. If the reviewer is not able to engage but other reviewers have approved the PR, you can merge the PR

This page tracks story points completed by sprint vs. developer days with an attempt to compute team velocity to make better estimates.

Before you dive in to the numbers, here are some notes in interpreting:

  • Everything involved in this calculation is an imperfect measure.  Story-points are based on intuition (not tied to "days of development").  The characteristics of a "developer day" vary wildly (1 dd != 8 hours infront of the computer), etc.
  • Given the imperfections involved, the goal is to identify trends:
    • How much chaos do we typically see
    • Are we reducing the "delta" column (perhaps the most valuable measure; "are we accurately estimating what we can do"
    • Is velocity tending to change over time (which could suggest overall performance, but could also suggest a shift in our understanding of a "story point"
  • There will almost always be "notes"; we miss an estimation, people get sick, etc.  Rather than trying to adjust or interpret results differently we should just let this be factored into our long-term averages and expectations.

Steps to spin up a new client demo

I've added  APT-114928 - Getting issue details... STATUS  to iterate on this documentation / make sure we have a blueprint for the next time we do this.

Data

    • SWAT team and AID team will be starting to figure out exactly what we want the methodology to be; intend it to be something we can automate and routinize

In the 30 minutes I had waiting in line for Chipotle day, (alone after Albert Liao stood me up (whatever, no big deal)) I read a few chapters of a book written by the CEO of Zapier a 100 % remote company.

Book link 

The first few chapters had a few ideas that I think could be applicable for the distributed team. 

  1. Idea - Zapier makes heavy use of Slack. The book suggests that all chat communication should be done in the minimal number of channels. It claims that they employed just one conversation group in slack until they had over 10 employees.  The idea is that it is easiest to keep everyone informed if everyone is presented with all the information. 
    Takeaway - Use a single, persistent chat for the AID Web team (PM, QAE and SEs) for all team info (we already have on in skype but we should add everyone and use it). Really, for any questions that one would ask aloud in the office, a reference should be made in the group chat. This also deemphasizes individual chat unless it is truly for things that are irrelevant to the team (recruiting, other team communications, feedback etc). 
  2. Idea - There are important topics that may slip through the noise a large chat, so those need additional documentation. Zapier solves this by using what they equate to an internal reddit. This allows all important decisions and conversations to be visible in one place. 
    Takeaway -  We don't have a directly comparable tool here at APT but confluence is probably our closest. We should have a consistent casual blog that we document the one of design discussions and important decisions (whether or not they happen in a chat channel). These should be kept short and we should definitely be engaging on them through comments and likes. 
  3. Idea -  Much of their development process is very similar to ours interms of managing code, tasks and pull requests. They use different tools (Trello, github, etc) but for essentially the same functions
    Takeaway - Our Jira, Stash Bamboo setup will continue to work well


    I will be continuing to read some of the chapters on things like, How to End Internal Emails and Communicate Effectively in a Remote Team, How to Build Strong Relationships in a Remote Team, and How to Run a Remote Team Meeting and will continue to update this page

pageTitle: Brainstorming: Plan for Integration with Platform
content:
General Questions

  1. Should we reconsider the fact that we are sharing the T&L database?

 

Platform elements we would like to use

Architectural ElementIntegration Issues / QuestionsSteps / Plan / Options to Integrate
Items / Item PermissioningIf we are sharing a T&L database, do we need to create duplicate named items (i.e., dashboards, metrics, etc.) with different IDs and control access to Citi and Barclays? Doing this seems like it will be very easy to make mistakes in permissioning as an APT User 
Helptext

The new architecture helptext is available via a Widget Helper (within CSHTML) or via a YUI JS component with additional YUI module dependencies.

Since we are primarily a JS only application, option the widget helper is not an option; we currently do not support distributed JS within AID nor have plans to support it.

Build our own implementation of helptext, copying styles where necessary.
Database Settings

We currently share one T&L database, which is where database settings are currently stored.

We have potential options, each with their own set of consequences:

  1. Use separate T&L databases
    1. Pros:
      1. Use database settings as written
      2. Can move AA and Citi database settings at different cadences
    2. Cons:
      1. Data cannot be shared across instances (but maybe we can do magic with sharing TRX, Attr, databases?)
  2. Create unique database settings for the shared clients (Hack around this, i.e, dbSettingName_someImmutableIdentifier)
    1. Cons:
      1. Pollutes the database and limits discovery
      2. Database settings are differently named across instances
  3. Do nothing:
    1. Cons:
      1. We must move Citi and Barclays in tandem
  4. Create our own database settings model
    1. Cons:
      1. We are further divorced from the platform stack
      2. Another table to update the same concept
      3. How do we give access to this table and get CS to manage them?
Internationalization

We are a JS only application, and therefore really need to simply serialize a resx file to a JS file; We currently do this by configuring resx assets within Autofac.config (i.e., http://stash/projects/APP/repos/outputs/browse/Outputs/Apt.Platform.Outputs.Web/App_Start/AutofacConfig.cs)

Since, we don't use YUI within AID - we are also unable to request / consume this resx module.

  1. Switch over our hardcoded JS strings to use a single resx file.
  2. Serialize the resx file as a dictionary in HomeModelProvider or similar
  3. Update JS to make use of the serialized dictionary
  4. Deploy and enable globalization within KIRK
  5. Work with Koverman / Productivity to enable translations of the AID repository.
Image CaptureNone.
  1. Once stateless URLs are done and we have the ability to save / apply context to charts, etc., create some "standalone page" for a drill down
  2. Deploy Image Capture within KIRK
  3. Add the "capture-ready" div 
  4. Use the Image Capture API as written
Image Utilities (for client logo)

None.

Requires CF (but can be worked around by editing the router urls within KIRK)

  1. Add images to CF images folder, which is auto mirrored across environments
  2. Update code to pull images from these URLS (either with relatives paths or using a copy of image utilities)
TogglesWe don't have a great way of mirroring toggles from outside KIRK into KIRK
  1. Figure out mirroring strategy
  2. Start using

The Surface Hub allows for easy, high quality use of a whiteboard, directly integrated with Skype for Business. This page documents how to use the Surface Hub for a couple basic use cases.

Connect Surface Hub to One Caller

Following these steps will allow you to share the whiteboard or screens with someone else.

  1. On the Surface Hub, find the correct input and open Skype
  2. Select call
  3. Type the name of the person you'd like to call and invite them to the meeting
  4. They should be prompted to accept the call
  5. If you want to present the whiteboard:
    1. Select Present Screen at the top of the Surface Hub
  6. If you want to present your screen:
    1. Open the Start menu
    2. Select Connect
    3. Use the HDMI cable in the room to connect
    4. Select Present Screen at the top of the Surface Hub

Connect Surface Hub to Multiple Callers

While you're on a call, there's an option to invite additional people in the Call menu. This does not currently work.

  1. Begin a Skype call from your laptop to someone else you want to include (not the Surface Hub)
  2. Once someone else is in the call, call the Surface Hub
    1. The name of this will depend on the conference room. In Vaughan, this appears in Skype as VaughanSurfaceHub.
    2. Others can be added to the call after the Surface Hub is added. The key here is that neither of the first 2 people in the call are the Surface Hub.
  3. The Surface Hub should start to ring and prompt you to accept the call
  4. If you want to present your screen, select the Present Desktop option in Skype
  5. If you want to present the whiteboard, select Present Screen at the top of the Surface Hub

Save the Whiteboard

  1. Select the Share icon at the bottom right of the whiteboard
  2. Select Email
  3. Enter your email address to save the whiteboard

Ending the Session

  1. Touch the End session button at the bottom of the screen

Basic Troubleshooting

The DP input isn't working

  1. Restart the system using the power button on the right side of the Surface Hub

I can't hear the other person

  1. Let the partner know via chat
  2. Check your system volume
  3. Check your sound mixer volume for this instance of Skype
  4. Make sure the sound is set to be played where you expect it (i.e. your headphones)
  5. Play the Skype Test sound
    1. Go to the settings gear in the top right of the main Skype Window
    2. Scroll to 'Audio Device'
    3. Click the Play button to the right of the 'Speaker' section
  6. If you do all this and hear the sound, you're off the hook

The other person can't hear me

  1. Ensure Skype is picking up your sound
    1. Go to the settings gear in the top right of the main Skype Window
    2. Scroll to 'Audio Device'
    3. Speak and ensure that the bar to the right of 'Microphone' lights up when you speak
    4. Click the drop down to select the device you want to use for sound input
      1. This normally resolves the problem 
    5. Click OK

The HDMI connection isn't displaying on the Surface Hub

  1. Try using Crestron to connect to the Surface Hub
    1. Once you're in a Skype call, sharing your screen is the same as before

For hardware issues, make sure everything is plugged in. Contact the Byte Bar if problems continue.

Additional Functionality

  • If an Outlook invite is explicitly scheduled as a Skype for Business meeting in a Surface Hub conference room, the Surface Hub allows you to call in without entering any additional information.
  • Accessible via the Start menu, you can create and edit Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files without needing another computer. Each Surface Hub conference room has a keyboard for this purpose.

 

Additional documentation can be found here:

  • Microsoft Surface Hub - Quick Reference Guide
  • 5 Tips and Tricks for using the Surface Hubs

Welcome to the AID V1 Retrospective.  We have a lot to cover (late July through early January).  Since this is our first large cross-office retrospective we're going to be trying a couple collaborative tools to make this go as smoothly as possible.  A such, you'll need a laptop to fully engage.

Hopefully the tools work well, but we'll have to be flexible and make adjustments if necessary.  Who knows - making collaborative retrospective tools could be a great future hackathon project!

Because of the size and scope of this group the discussion will be split into two sections, with the first hour focused on development teams, process, and the product, and the second hour

Homework (Optional)

We have a lot to cover in this retrospective, so if you would like to get a head start please feel free.  If you don't want to do anything ahead of time that's fine too.  There will be time to do everything in the meeting, though I suspect you may feel a little constrained.  If there are a lot of topics left to discuss at the end of the entire meeting we can follow up with some smaller meetings as appropriate.

The three things you can do ahead of time are:

  • Add to reference material for any of the sections below
  • (Dev) Start to fill out the AID V1 Timeline
  • (Dev) Come up with some ideas on the AID V1 Starfish Retrospective Board
  • (Dev/Data/Ops) Come up with some ideas on the AID V1 Data/Ops Retrospective Board

More detailed instructions for each can be found below.

Hour 1: AID and MCDI Development teams

During the first hour we will reflect on the development process.

AID V1 Timeline (~15 minutes)

  • 10 min We'll start by putting together a time-line of key events.  I'll send this out ahead of time in case anybody wants to get a head start, but we'll also take ~10 minutes as a group to add any additional events, features, etc. that happened during this time.
  • ~5 min We'll take ~5 minutes to talk through the diagram.

Instructions are simple:  Copy/paste a box and plug in your comment.  Feel free to add lines, pictures, or anything else that will make the diagram better!  I've added a couple events to establish the general timeline, and added a legend toward the bottom, but feel free to add colors or new categories.

Here's the link.

AID V1 Dev Starfish (~45 minutes)

Next, we're going to do the starfish retrospective exercise.  Reflect on the past few months of AID V1 Development.  The goal here is to classify your observations as things we should "Keep Doing", "Do More Of", "Start Doing", "Stop Doing", or "Do Less of".  The diagram we typically draw on the whiteboard looks like this:

We'll be using a slightly simpler version on a site called IdeaBordz that has six sections; to start we'll be using the first 5 sections.  As we discuss, we may add "Action Items" as well (or we may just add them here on Confluence!)

During the retrospective we'll do the following:

  • 5 min Take about 5 minutes to brainstorm new ideas without looking at the board.  Challenge yourself to come up with at least one idea in each section
  • 5 min Add your ideas to the collaborative board here and continue coming up with new ideas
  • 5 min We'll quickly try to consolidate duplicate ideas in the same section.  Take a minute or two to vote for the ideas you're most interested in talking about!
  • ~30 min We'll walk through the topics with the most votes, spending no more than ~5 minutes on each.  If we feel like some topics need more discussion to get to real action items we should follow up with that discussion using other avenues.  Given that we need to switch topics after only an hour we'll almost certainly have some things left to talk about.

Here are a few points to keep in mind:

  • Consider brainstorming independently before looking at what others wrote
  • There is no way to "remove" a vote, and while you can technically make unlimited votes in this program, let's try to be reasonable
  • The scope of this discussion doesn't include coordination with the operations and data teams; we'll get to that in the next hour!

Overview

The AID team recently released the custom dashboard feature to production, a significant enhancement that allows users to create custom dashboards and outputs that best align with their specific business questions.

For this feature, we decided to take a different approach to the development life cycle. Rather than develop a full set of requirements and mockups before beginning development, we instead aligned on a general proposal for the feature so that Louis Antonelli could begin development on the larger building blocks of the feature. In parallel, Natalia Em, Chris Piccoli and Chris Piccoli worked to finalize the details of the UX. This work included several usability sessions with Tom Bittleman and the AA client team, working sessions to identify an ideal user flow, sketching sessions and high fidelity mockups. The team met all together at a weekly cadence to review the current status of the feature and provide feedback. Once development had wrapped up, the QAs began testing and also coordinated a team-wide testing blitz. 

Some specific differences from normal development worth calling out

  • Less of a focus on formal requirements
  • Development carried out in parallel with requirements/UX work
  • More frequent reviews of current status of feature rather than one review of the finalized feature - both in formal meetings and through individual walkthroughs via a development branch Louis set up on the VDI

The goal of this retrospective is to identify what worked with this new process, what could be improved, and whether new features should consider a similar approach.

 

Timeline/References

  • 01/10/2017 - begin work on My Dashboard requirements - Brainstorming on Custom User Dashboards
  • 01/23/2017 - first user flow working session 
  • 02/01/2017 - 03/13/2017- ongoing UX feedback using Louis' feature branch and webex meetings - My Dashboard Walk-through Notes
  • 2/27/2017 - 02/28/2017 - usability sessions with Tom and AA client team - Usability feedback on card interactions
  • 03/13/2017 - QAs test custom dashboard - 2017-03-13: Test Custom Dashboard
  • 03/14/2017 - Team-wide testing blitz - 2017-03-14: Testing Blitz: Custom Dashboards & Visualization Swapping
  • 03/23/2017 - Deployed to Production - 2017-03-22 Release: AID-009

Notes

Early Requirements

  • What worked well
    • user flow sessions very helpful
    • Louis was able to start on development on the clear requirements while we worked on solving the open questions
      • how did we id the clear requirements? Chris and Louis had a couple initial sketching sessions, allowing Louis to begin work on the overall organization of the custom dashboards. There were also a lot of similarities between the default dashboards and the custom dashboards so that probably helped
  • What could be improved
    • Better documentation of decisions
      • there were several locations for decisions:
        • feedback iteration page
        • couple "requirements" pages
        • sometimes decisions just weren't written down anywhere
        • made things more difficult from a QA perspective
    • a couple items were harder to come to a clear consensus on
      • "edit mode"
      • should have established a decision from the get go
  • Start doing
    • Pulling in client services, client users would be helpful, although with AID, limited number of CS/client users to pull from
    • Documentation of decisions - someone should be on point for every meeting
      • allows 
    • Identify major milestones, scope of work to prevent pull in of additional features that could be put off to a V2

    • Identify splunk logging to help answer open questions at an early stage rather than as an afterthought 

  • Stop doing

Development

  • what worked well
    • access to Louis' branch via the VDI enabled very rapid iteration w/out interrupting developer time
    • contrasts other features where PM may not see the feature until on staging
    • centralized feedback page was useful for knocking out quick wins that would otherwise have not been implemented until a V2
    • however, this informal approach wouldn't work for larger feedback or prioritizing features
    • John Reagan benefitted from a code walkthrough led by Louis
      • with such a large, new codebase, saved time when reviewing since he had all the context up front rather than learning everything on his own
  • What could be improved
    • occasionally, Louis' dev branch was inaccessible due to active development
  • Start doing
    • set up a stable branch with regular updates so that branch remains relevant for feedback but also easily accessible

Testing

  • what worked well
    • this feature was a good application of a testing blitz due to
      • scope of testing required
      • UX focus of the feature
  • what could be improved
    • w/out formal requirements and with many of the requirements spread out over several pages, took a while to get a sense of requirements
    • Hai-Ri ended up making assumptions for some of the requirements
    • high-level overview led by PMs was helpful to get context, but ultimately not too helpful for testing
    • reviewing the many requirements pages and meetings pages was confusing due to the extreme iteration involved
  • start doing
    • when decisions are made or changes made to requirements or mockups, emphasize the final decision and archive the iteration or store the iteration in meeting notes instead of on a "requirements" page
  • overall, not a ton lost from a testing standpoint, however, this approach would NOT work for an analytic feature
  • need to carefully evaluate whether this approach works before diving in for future features

Key Takeaways

Requirements

  • Establish milestones and scope of work at beginning of requirements development to avoid expanding scope of work, easily divide up work and prioritize most important sub-features
  • Ensure that early sketching sessions, user flow brainstorming sessions consider entirety of interaction to prevent "thrashing" over unaswered aspects of the UX
  • Establish clear separation between requirements, brainstorming, and feedback pages from an early standpoint. Separate decisions/final requirements from transient meeting notes or brainstorming
  • Expand scope of brainstorming by reaching out to more people in client services and engineering
  • Establish desired splunk logging from an early point in requirements writing to allow engineers to help answer our open questions through usage data

Development

  • Set up a stable branch in addition to an active development branch to allow constant access for feedback from PMs/UX
  • For these larger new features, lead a "code walkthrough" before individual code reviews to quickly get engineers up to speed on new code

Testing

  • Clearer requirements early on will make it easier to write testing plans and carry out testing
  • Testing blitz are efficient for testing larger UX-heavy features with less formal requirements

      • "can wait" items should be turned into JIRA tasks so they don't get forgotton and can move independently of the branch
      • "needs to be done before the merge" should be done immediately. Developer can decide to branch off the current branch that gets reviews and merged into the branch at hand, or close the current pull request and create a new pull request with feedback
    • Need to establish dependencies and APIs between different JIRA tasks up front 
    • Note this may have solved some issues, but development where we are moving a ton of entities, test utilites, etc as needed cause chaos and this model wouldn't have solved that
  • Come up with list of rolling deadlines for testing and individual smaller sized features Alex Franz Radha Sambasivan
  • Schedule pre-planning meeting for calc work Radha Sambasivan
  • Write a poem to perform at tomorrow's BBQ Alex Franz Allie Ivener

Development discussion

VDI

  • NY thinks it's good enough
  • Technical discussion
  • Dave says we need to get out of the VDI
  • Testing infrasturcture is stronger outside of the VDI
  • VM development actually  has some benefits, like running a long query when you leave your desk

Actions

  • We have an epic that includes data sanitization and getting out of the VDI

Planning

  • There are a lot of "Plan This" or "Task That" stories that demand more context at tasking so we aren't getting to fine-grain tasks
  • One week springs probably make this harder because the cycle is shorter
  • Two week sprints may be better; Less meetings and NY can have trouble getting meeting space
  • We may be ready to go to 2 week sprints with pre-tasking
    • Requires a pre-tasking planning session (may not be the whole team)
  • Confluence discussions aren't always ideal; it's async and people may not react at the cadence you need

Actions

  • We could try planning and assigning stories to be tasked ahead of time
  • There seems to be interest in moving to a 2 week cadence

Aid/Mcdi collaboration

  • Things that didn't go great
    • Didn't have an understanding of all of the calculation bottlenecks (distinct accounts, DU data)
    • Some difficulties in communication led to needing to recalculate attributes
    • There were some places where having both teams in design discussions would have been better; there were some places where the APIs didn't sync up
  • Could have considered MCDI as an AID team
  • Attend cross-standups
  • Have a cross team standup in general
  • There was confusion on both sides about things like which columns we'd need to use; should have figured this out sooner if possible
  • When we put the demo together with "hacks" we didn't really remember to go back and consider all of these things until the end
  • Should have shared the front-end with MCDI sooner for general interest
  • More communication from MCDI (or in general) about data behavior
    • Could be clear about who a specific point person is on each team / topic and make it clear to eachother who that is
  • On the bright side, each team involved had a clear division of work
  • Hai-ri thinks having perspective on both sides was good for testing context
  • For smaller "burst" efforts consider a "borrow an engineer approach"

Actions

 Indexed Metrics

Updated requirements:

  • Data Usage
    • Check actual account count cell size rather than indexed account count
    • Pass all 6 metrics for non-benchmark case where data passes actual
    • Pass only 3 indexed metrics for benchmark case where data passes indexed
    • Pass only 3 indexed metrics for non-benchmark case where data fails actual but passes indexed
    • Pass nothing if none of the above conditions are met
  • GetResults
    • Indexed metrics can be retrieved from cache
    • Derived metrics are based on indexed, not actual, metrics
  • CalculateResults
    • Indexed metrics always calculated alongside basic metrics
  • Calc
    • Indexed metrics calculated alongside basic metrics
    • Actual metrics are passed to breakdowns instead of indexed metrics
  • Indexed Metrics (2016-12-07 Index Metrics Implementation Details)

This is a APT USER ONLY feature. 

Quick Links testing is conducted in the following instances on Master Kirk. After test cases pass on these instances, we can safely assume that it should work safely across all instances. 

PI instances:

  • PlatformDb_Dev
  • PlatformDb_Citi

BI instances:

  • GenericRetailer

SQL query for permissioning, depermissioning, and look up permission for this feature is stored in VDI folder \\aptproduction.com\KirkFileShare\VDI\Yqu, and file name is "Test quicklinks scripts"

There are two modules permissions involved in this feature:

  • Global.DevSetting.TogglePanel module permission controls Toggle Panel menu quick link. (on MckirkAppdb select * from permissions.permissions.userPermissions where permissionId = 3 and userID = X)
  • ManageUsers module permission controls Manage Users and Manage Users (New) quick link. (on MckirkAppdb select * Platformdb_dev.dbo.modulePermissions where moduleId= 1206 and UserID = X)

Planned FE Testing

Three involved KPIs:

  • Spend per Active Customer 
  • Transactions per Active Customer
  • Transactions per Active Customer vs. Industry Total

Two involved attributes (transaction level attributes that will only be applied on numerator value e.g. "spend" portion of "Spend per Active Customer"): 

  • Day of Week
  • Transaction Channel (BI-version, which is just limited to online/offline)

Instance tested on Master: GenericRetailer

Testing is conducted by comparing numerator and denominator of the metric being tested with corresponding single metrics with same filters/splits selected to determine if the numerator and denominator are filtered.

For example: for Test ID 2 value of the numerator will be compared with value generated by results of Spend + Day of Week Split times 1.2153 (index factor), while denominator will be compared with value generated by results of Active Customers + Day of Week Split times 1.2153 (index factor). Specifically,  \( \text{Spend per Active Customer (With Day Of Week Split)} = \frac{1.2153\times \text{Spend (With Day Of Week Split)}}{1.2153\times \text{Active Customer (Without Split)}} \)  

Note: Different from the other two afffected KPIs, Transactions per Active Customer vs Industry Total = Transactions per Active Customer / Industry Transactions per Active Customer = Transactions (filtered) per Active Customer / Industry (Transactions (filtered) per Active Customer (not filtered)),

specifically,

  \( \text{Transactions per Active Customer vs Industry Total} = \frac{\text{Transactions per Active Customer}}{\text{Industry Transactions per Active Customer}} = \frac{\frac{1.2153\times \text{Transactions}}{1.2153\times \text{Active Customer}}}{\frac{1.2153\times \text{Industry Transactions}}{1.2153\times \text{Industry Active Customer}}} \) while Transactions per Active Customer and Industry Transactions per Active Customer are both affected metrics. Therefore, although the metric Transactions per Active Customer vs. Industry Total itself is not set up to be affected by semi-static filters, both of its ratio components are affected metrics, thus making Transactions per Active Customer vs. Industry Total a passively affected metric.

Tuesday:

Numerator (Sales with filter): 13.44MM*1.2153 = 16.33 MM

Denominator (Active Customers without filter): 1.11MM*1.2153 = 1.35 MM

metric is filtered on numerator only

Actual Values

metric is filtered on numerator only

Transactions per Active Customer vs Industry Total: 0.4397/0.49397 = 0.89

Numerator (Transactions (with filter) per Active Customer (without filter)): 0.44

Denominator (Industry Transactions (with filter) per Active Customer (without filter)): this is not a front end metric so we have to get Industry Transactions and Industry Active Customers from database, Industry Transactions (with filter) = 3335396, Industry Active Customer (without filter) = 6752207 so

Denominator = 3335396/6752207 = 0.49397

metric is filtered on both numerator and denominator

Denominator (Active Customers with filter): 3.25MM*1.2153 = 3.95MM

Numerator (Sales with filter): 83MM*1.2153 = 100.9MM

Denominator (Active Customers with filter): 426k*1.2153 = 517.7k

Last Quarter 04/02/2017-07/01/2017

Actual Values

metric is filtered on both numerator and denominator

Transactions per Active Customer vs Industry Total : 2.395/2.635 = 0.909

Numerator (Transactions (with filter) per Active Customer (with filter)): 2.39

Denominator (Industry Transactions (with filter) per Active Customer (with filter)): this is not a front end metric so we have to get Industry Transactions and Industry Active Customers from database, Industry Transactions (with filter) = 423080, Industry Active Customer (with filter) = 161359, so

Denominator = 423080/161359 = 2.62 (close enough)

The attribute for Merchant State used is attribute_712. There's quite a few very messy merchant state attributes in the database that should be cleaned up.

Background

As we are are getting more and more users to our software overseas, we are looking into translating our software into other languages so that foreign users could easily understand and use our AID software. 

There are terms on the front end that could be easily identified as needing translation already because developers used function get_resex for defining those terms. Pushkar Rege identified them by making those found terms to be "#internationlized", and I, Yufei Qu, picked it up from there to further investigate on other terms that still need to be translated but have not yet been identified by Pushkar Rege, which are probably strings that were hard coded in the software. 

This #internationalized version of AID software was deployed on QA2 (mctesting01:10403/aid) branch on Kirk. I used databases of PlatformDb_Barclays, PlatformDb_Citi, and GenericGroceryStore to test the translation for both PI and BI cases. And my results are documented below. 

Note: there are a few things that I ignored when checking translation because they are defined by ourselves instead of utility vocabularies. Specifically, I ignored Dashboard Names (PORTFOLIO HEALTH, USAGE, etc), Metric Names (Spend, Net Transaction Count, etc), Split Names (Industry, Transaction Channel, etc), Filter Names (MCC Code, Product Group, etc, and their checkboxes/dropdown content), and some content in Definition Bubbles for filters and splits (filter/split name, definitions, etc). 

Daniel Mace, Simon Krauss, Chris Piccoli, please use this document as a reference for organizing and keep tracking of translation tasks. And Pushkar Rege, there will be an engineering task with sub-tasks reflecting each cases below created for G Sprint. Related documentation is MCI Internationalization Best Practices.


Update by 8/31/2017: for the hard coded front end utility terms that I identified earlier when creating this documentation, engineers (mainly Pushkar Rege) have changed the way that they are implemented. And a new branch is deployed to QA1 branch on Kirk similar to the one described earlier. I'll use this document as the test plan for checking if all of the identified terms are fixed on the new branch (ie. if they are not hard coded anymore). After test passes, code will be merged into master.

Making sure old Australia data is similar to new Australia data - basic data

This tests that calculation is considering the right set of rows and is using the correct transaction log. Even though data was restated, we don't expect results to change substantially between the old and new data

  • Validate that SUM(spendAmountUSD) is similar between old data and new data
  • Validate that SUM(spendAmountLocalCurrency) is similar between old data and new data - Note, we fixed the bug where returns were positive, sales were multiplied by 100
    • Split out by isGco - isGco = true - very close
    • isGco = false, added in logic to multiply by 100, values are off by ~5% which makes sense given we didn't take into account returns
  • Validate that SUM(distinct accountCount) is similar between old data and new data
  • Validate that SUM(transactionCount) is similar between old and new data
  • Validate that the number of rows per day is similar between old data and new data

Make sure old Australia data is similar to new Australia data - new attribute breakouts

We've added 11 new attributes for the Australia calculation. We want to verify that the old and new data have the same distribution for those attributes by breaking out by those attributes.

We'll group by the attribute and verify that the transactionCount and SUM(spendAmountUsd) are similar for all attributes - except when mentioned otherwise

Attributes that were added

  • 411 - Spend Amount Local Currency - verify values, broken out by isGco
  • 412 - Spend Amount Local Currency code - all should have same code
  • 413 - IsOnline (values within 0.08%)
  • 512 - Merchant State - numbers don't tie out exactly, but it's likely due to a SAN sync and merchant locations changing over time. It's very close to the current calculation
  • 513 - Merchant Country Code - should all be AUS
  • 514 - Merchant Residential Zip
  • 515 - Merchant Channel of Distribution Code
  • 605 - isGCO
  • 707 - Merchant State As Int (Verify data is same as 512) - OT is excluded but that's intentional
  • 708 - Merchant Country Code As Int - should be all AUS 
  • 709 - Merchant Residential Zip As Int (Verify data is same as 514)
  • 710 - Merchant Channel of Distribution Code as Int
  • 711 - Australia State Excluding online trx as int (Verify data is same as 707) - Found that the online code has values and every other code had its values go down which is expected

Validating new Australia data - sanity checks

This does some very simple checks on attributes that we didn't modify at all in the calculation. However, we want to make sure the data is still reasonable - verified against old data

  • Verify we have a reasonable number of distinct aggregateMerchantIds
  • Verify we have a reasonable number of distinct mmhIds
  • Verify we have a reasonable number of industry codes
  • Verify we have a reasonable of NAICS codes
  • Verify we have a reasonable number of MCC Codes

Validating new Australia data - new attribute codes

Verify that the int coded attribute has the same data for all codes as when we join to the int attribute codes with descriptions

  • Online
  • IsGCO
  • Merchant State
  • Merchant Country Code
  • Merchant Residential Zip
  • Merchant Channel of Distribution
  • State Excluding Online Trx

Validating US data

Everything country specific is tested in the Regression test

In file MetricResultGeneratorJobRunner.cs, create function ValidateCalcSetting and call it in RunAsync. ValidateCalcSettings includes all of the Throws for calc settings that were originally located under RunAsync function.


I will need to test the Throws mentioned above in file MetricResultGeneratorJobRunnerTest.cs, the leftover test case from data composition will be tested here.
In MetricResultGeneratorJobRunnerTest.cs, a new Testing function has been created, TestValidateCalcSetting. And I will need to populate the test cases to test the throws. Along with the test cases, I should also create the input files coupling specific test cases. Other tests here on this file will serve a good example as of how to write test cases and how to write input/baseline files. It's probably helpful to learn more about baselines and inputs before jumping on testing it.


As of having isClient TransactionAttribute together with industry filter. On the front end, it is simply impossible to trgger because isClient AccountAttribute and isClient TransactionAttribute are all set to 0 for all attributes on BI. However, it might still be worth adding one throw for this just in case that BI_web settings are mistakenly changed on Web.

 Does not exist and recommended for better coverage

 

There are totally two test files involved in the unit testing for the new Data Usage Logic. One is AggregationLevelGeneratorTest.cs and the other one is DataCompositionTest.cs. In DataCompositionTest.cs, both TransactionDataComposition and AccountDataComposition are tested, and in AggregationLevelGeneratorTest.cs, the aggregated results for combining TransactionDataComposition and AccountDataComposition to determine which DU tests should be runnning are tested.

This bug was fixed but the calculation for Brazil data was run on the branch where the bug still existed. Therefore, current testing should be using ETL table.
